item.title: Tracker: the most-watched US drama series in almost a decade is finally coming to the UK
item.description: Tracker has enjoyed such phenomenal success that itâ€™s already been renewed for a second season â€“ so, whatâ€™s it all about?Â
item.dc:creator: Kayleigh Dray
item.content:encoded:
Itâ€™s always tough deciding what to watch on TV, especially as thereâ€™s just so many things to choose from. Thatâ€™s why a show tends to shoot its way to the top of our must-watchlist if it has already proven itself to be something of a resounding success overseas.Â

Tracker, which has been crowned the most-watched new series on US broadcast TV in six years and the most-watched new drama series in nine years, definitely fits the bill.

Watch the trailer for Tracker below:

Yes, itâ€™s another tale of a nomadic hero. Yes, itâ€™s giving us Jack Reacher vibes. And yes, Selling Sunset fans: that is Justin Hartley.

Intrigued? Hereâ€™s what you need to know.

What is Tracker about?

Based on the bestselling novel The Never Game by Jeffery Deaver, Tracker tells the story of Colter Shaw, a â€œa lone-wolf survivalist who roams the country as a reward seeker, using his expert tracking skills to help private citizens and law enforcement solve all manner of mysteries while contending with his own fractured familyâ€.

So, heâ€™s a bounty hunter. And, in typical procedural drama fashion, this means we get a â€œmystery of the weekâ€ with each episode â€“ as our troubled lead struggles to make sense of his traumatic past (while whipping his shirt off at every opportunity and showing off his comprehensive mastery of survival percentages, of course).

Who stars in Tracker?

This Is Us star Justin Hartley, as mentioned already, takes the lead in this one as our eponymous tracker.Â

Heâ€™s joined by Abby McEnany and Robin Weigert as Velma and Teddi Bruin, Eric Graise as Bobby Exley, and Fiona Rene as attorney/love interest Reenie Greene.

What are people saying about Tracker?

With an 88% â€˜freshâ€™ rating on Rotten Tomatoes, it seems Tracker has gone down an absolute treat with fans of the genre.

Admitting that he fell in love with his character, Hartley tells The Hollywood Reporter: â€œWhat an amazing idea of a life, where you live in an Airstream, youâ€™re self-sustaining, go wherever you want to go and help people. Youâ€™re not an antihero, youâ€™re just a good guy, a good man.â€

He adds: â€œI guess it made me think about how rare that is. I remember sitting there thinking heâ€™s just a good guy. Colter Shaw is not agenda-driven, necessarily. Heâ€™s a businessman. He takes the money, thatâ€™s how he makes his living. Heâ€™s not politically driven. Heâ€™s driven by doing the right thingâ€¦ [and] he is not a superhero; heâ€™s living a very dangerous life. If he gets shot, he bleeds, he will die.

â€œI think itâ€™s a throwback series, sort of like The Rockford Files. We just donâ€™t have that anymore and I get nostalgic about that kind of television.â€

When and where can we watch Tracker?

The first episode of Tracker will be released on Disney+ in the United Kingdom and Ireland on Wednesday 3 April 2024, and new episodes will be released weekly.

Will you be tuning in?

Images: Disney+

item.title: I had my hair X-rayed and itâ€™s changed the way I think about my mane
item.description: Did you know you can get your hair X-rayed? I gave it a try and I learned a lot â€“ not just about the health of my hair, but what I want for it.Â
item.dc:creator: Aidan Milan
item.content:encoded:
When I was offered the chance to have a near-infrared scanner reveal the true health of my hair, I was absolutely intrigued. What beauty devotee wouldnâ€™t want to know exactly what state their strands are inÂ â€“ and how to help them improve?

Philipp Haug, of Haug London Haus,Â describes the Schwarzkopf Professional SalonLab Smart AnalyzerÂ as an X-ray, for the sake of simplicity.

It was at this salon â€“ which Haug founded with his business partner and wife, Siobhan HaugÂ â€“ that I gave the tech and the subsequent recommended treatment and products a try. They donâ€™t charge extra for this scanning service, offering it to every new client as standard, to gain a better idea of a customerâ€™s unique needs.

The scanner is a small handheld tool that allows a stylist to scan hair from root to tip, via a light beam that calculates the reflection of light from the hairâ€™s outer cuticle, thus measuring the inner hair condition and strength.Â

Customersâ€™ hair is then given a score out of 100 and the salon recommends a tailored treatment, including a selection of products either custom-blended and shipped to you, or taken straight off the salon shelves (plus, if youâ€™re taking that plunge, a colour that suits your specific hair needs). I went with a tailored treatment on the day, and also took home some non-custom-blended wash day and styling supplies.

The Haugsâ€™ process also involves a survey to help your stylist determine your hair type, the state of your scalp and your haircare priorities (options include â€œrepair and nourishmentâ€, â€œcolour shine and brillianceâ€, and â€œvolume and strengthâ€). Until I was asked, I had never really thought of volume being a big priority to me. After all, Iâ€™ve got naturally big, thick curly hair, so flatness or fineness isnâ€™t my struggle; itâ€™s moisture that I really craved.

But when I actually thought about it, I realised I love volume so much that I constantly want more. Iâ€™m always fluffing up my hair during the day, to help it be as big as possible, and smooth ringlets just arenâ€™t my vibe. Instead, if I feel like my curls are too tidy, I separate them a little to add a bit of 80s-inspired fluff. On top of that, curly hair can be dry and prone to breakage, and Iâ€™m trying to grow it as much as possible for my looming wedding, so Iâ€™ll take all the strength I can get.Â

So, to my surprise, â€œvolume and strengthâ€ is the option I chose. And Iâ€™m so happy I did, because â€“ if I do say so myselfÂ â€“ you can see from the before and after photos above that my treatment left my hair looking fantastic, with just the right amount of volume, moisture and structured curl.

My chosen preferences also helped inform the selection of shampoo, conditioner and styling products I was recommended after the treatment. I walked away with the Schwarzkopf Professional Fibre Clinix Volumize Shampoo and Conditioner, the Fibre Clinix Bonding Light Oil and the Fibre Clinix Fibre Clinix Hydrate Spray Conditioner, the latter of which I use to style my hair on and between wash days.

Iâ€™m obsessed with these products, and wouldnâ€™t have considered giving most of them a try if it werenâ€™t for this process becauseÂ â€“ in addition to never having thought consciously about adding volumeÂ â€“ Iâ€™ve never got on with an oil the way I have with this one. Itâ€™s light, it smells amazing and is perfect for between washes, when my hair needs a bit of moisture to help it through the day.

And my strength score? An impressive 74%, which is way higher than I thought I would get, considering I put a box dye on my hair less than six months ago.

â€œ74% is a really good score,â€ says Haug, â€œand with antioxidant products, the score would go up. The small damage you have would be due to external factors like the sun and the lack of ozone in the atmosphere now, causing free radicals to break down the bonds in the hair if itâ€™s not protected. Itâ€™s a bit like exposing the skin to the sun without an SPF.â€

Haug added that products like the Fibre Clinix oils, shampoos and conditioners â€œcontain the bonds to replace those that are broken and re-strengthen the hairâ€.

Sun damage to my hair is another thing I would never have spent much time thinking about â€“ my main worry was the impact of the box dye. But now that I know to protect my precious bonds, Iâ€™ll make that a focus in my newfound quest for volume.Â

Images:Â Schwarzkopf; Aidan Milan

item.title: â€œBig Mood perfectly illustrates the messy reality of mental health and friendships â€“ you need to watch itâ€
item.description: Big Mood is a powerful representation of the messy reality of friendship and mental health issues, writes Chloe Laws. Hereâ€™s why you need to watch it. Warning: this article contains spoilers for season one of Big Mood.
item.dc:creator: Chloe Laws
item.content:encoded:
Every so often a piece of art is created that encapsulates the magic, tenderness, heartbreak, chaos and beauty of female friendships. Sometimes thatâ€™s a book (Everything I Know About Love, anyone?) or an album (looking at you, Lorde). This time, itâ€™s a TV show, specifically Channel 4â€™s Big Mood. AndÂ â€“ you guessed it â€“itâ€™s a big, huge, colossal mood.

The series is written and created by playwright Camilla Whitehill, starring Nicola Coughlan (Derry Girls, Bridgerton) and Lydia West (Itâ€™s A Sin) as its leads. Whitehill has actually been friends with Coughlan since they met at drama school 15 years ago, and the pair have been wanting to work together on a project for a long time.

Maggie (Coughlan) and Eddie (West) live in Dalston, East London and are best friends. More than best friends, even, they are life partners and family. Some (me) might even go as far as to call them codependent.

The synopsis of Big Mood reads: â€œMaggie and Eddie have lived in each otherâ€™s pockets for ten years, through thick, thin, and multiple challenging eyebrow trends. But with the rest of their lives looming, careers hanging in the balance and Maggieâ€™s bipolar disorder making an unwelcome return to form, Eddie begins to question whether this friendship is really in their best interests.â€

Ths synopsis further notes that this is â€œa pivotal point in both their lives, bringing to the surface those all-important questions â€“ could sleeping with your former History teacher be the key to happiness? Is a basement Rat Hotel a functional alternative to pest control? With their 20s behind them, Maggie and Eddieâ€™s relationship faces the future â€“ can it survive?â€

Throughout the six-part series we see Eddie grapple with her own needs as she tries to be the â€˜strong friendâ€™, a role she has both cast herself in and been cast in. We see Maggie try to stay afloat as her bipolar disorder takes control and she can do very little but try to survive.

Eddie rarely asks for anything, and she is always the one supporting, organising and rescuing Maggie from a multitude of shenanigans. At first, this is a fun adventure; they are the yin to each otherâ€™s yang. Then the cracks begin to show, as mental illness intertwines itself into their friendship â€“ Maggie becomes manic, depressed and has periods of memory loss. Eddie becomes frustrated after needing support (she loses the bar she runs and has to deal with an unplanned pregnancy) and not finding it in Maggie. The series ends with an open-ended friendship breakup, as Eddie steps into a cab and Maggie sobs on the pavement.

Like Maggie, I have accidentally been selfish in friendshipsÂ

Big Mood is a painfully relatable show. The language Eddie and Maggie use could have been lifted directly from my personal WhatsApp chats: â€œIf I could finally get a big Le Creuset things might turn aroundâ€, â€œMost perfect special angel girlâ€, and â€œI donâ€™t have Â£800 in my bank accountâ€¦ that would be wildâ€. The most relatable part, however, is their friendship. And how I have been both an Eddie and a Maggie at different times in my life. Iâ€™m sure you have been, too.

Like Eddie, I have routinely been described as â€˜independentâ€™ and â€˜strongâ€™. Like Eddie, I have made outlandish statements like â€œIâ€™m the only one who can take care of meâ€ and â€œI donâ€™t need anyoneâ€. And, like Eddie, I have resented friendships where my needs were always secondary because the other person was in more of a â€˜crisisâ€™, and so I silently made myself a martyr.

Like Maggie, I have struggled with complex mental health which, at some stages, has taken over my life. Like Maggie, I have made outlandish statements like â€œIâ€™ve got depression down to a fine artâ€. And, like Maggie, I have accidentally been selfish in friendships because survival mode temporarily took away some of my self-awareness.

While itâ€™s clear that Maggie definitely fucks up more out of the pair, itâ€™s not so much her actions but her dishonesty that really makes the friendship go off the rails. When Eddie asks her â€œI need help. I need you to help me, Maggie, is that OK?â€, she should have said no and told her friend about the memory loss and hallucinations.

The truth is that mental health can detrimentally affect the relationships in our lives. That feels like saying the quiet bit out loud, but itâ€™s a reality we should not shy away from. If we wonâ€™t admit this to ourselves, how can we learn the tools to manage? How can we avoid our mental health ending friendships? How can we not â€˜doâ€™ a Maggie? People are not required to love you at your worst, despite what Marilyn Monroe may have said. Friendship is conditional, not unconditional, and your friends are allowed boundaries and limits. Just as you are.

However, this is not a show of absolutes or moral judgements. We are meant to sympathise and dislike both Eddie and Maggie at different times, because neither of them is â€˜perfectâ€™ at friendship. None of us are.

Art that reflects the powerful friendships between women has become mainstream in the last decade, and rightfully soÂ â€“ they are instrumental in society and deserve to be platformed. However, oftentimes only the joyful elements are portrayed, which can leave women feeling like theyâ€™re doing something wrong. Friendships are a relationship, and those will always be messy and require navigation. Big Mood is the finest representation of this truth that I have ever seen. Letâ€™s hope we get a second season.

Images: Channel 4

Bobbi BrownÂ senior pro make-up artist Zara Findlay tells Stylist: â€œI love that lip liners give your lips the subtle definition to enhance your natural lip shape, and really make your lip colour or gloss pop.

The best way to apply lip liner

item.title: Good Eggs: 3 creative brunch recipes that are made for long, lazy weekends
item.description: Whatever youâ€™re up to over the long weekend, make sure that these delicious egg recipes are a part of your plans.
item.dc:creator: Annie Simpson
item.content:encoded:
Weâ€™ve made it. For many of us, the clock hitting 6pm (or even earlier) today will signal the start of the long-waited four-day weekend. And it doesnâ€™t matter what the weather has planned, weâ€™re going to enjoy our time off as much as we possibly can. But whatever your plans might be, we suggest fitting a long, lazy brunch into your agenda.

As much as we love classic scrambled eggs or avo and poached eggs, if youâ€™re looking for something different, weâ€™re turning to chef and food writer Ed Smith and his new cookbook,Â Good Eggs. Featuring over 100 recipes and ideas that make eggs the star of the show, the book promises all the inspiration you need, including recipes for fried, poached, boiled, baked, scrambled and more which work for breakfast through until dinner.

From a Dishoom-inspired dish to the flavours of Italy, these three recipes are perfect for the weekend ahead.Â

Pizza baked eggs

Ed says: â€œThe base for these eggs echoes the flavours of a pizza alla marinara. Iâ€™ve added a few olives and anchovies at the end, partly because they go so well with eggs, but also because theyâ€™re the best pizza toppings (donâ€™t @ me).

For the bread, anything you have will work (although note that toasted supermarket pitas do an excellent impression of leftover pizza crusts).â€

For 2

Ingredients

  • 1 x 400g can finely chopped tomatoes (or passata)
  • 1 clove garlic, finely sliced
  • 2 tsp dried oregano
  • 1 tbsp extra virgin olive oil
  • 6â€“8 small olives (such as the Taggiasca variety)
  • 1 basil sprig, plus a few extra leaves to garnish
  • Pinch flaky sea salt
  • 2â€“4 medium eggs
  • 2â€“4 salted anchovies in oil
  • Freshly grated Parmesan
  • Warm bread, to serve (pitas or similar puffy flatbreads work well here)

Method

Empty the tomatoes into a 26â€“28cm sautÃ© pan or low casserole with a lid and place over a medium-high heat. Add the garlic, oregano, olive oil, olives, basil sprig and a big pinch of salt. Stir and simmer energetically for 5 minutes until slightly thickened (but not stiff).

Crack the eggs into the sauce, ideally far enough apart that they donâ€™t immediately touch each other. Reduce the heat a little, cover and gently simmer for 2Â½â€“3 minutes until the whites are set. Remove from the heat. If the whites arenâ€™t firm by this point, keep the pan off the hob, but return the lid and check again after 30â€“60 seconds.

Spoon the eggs and sauce into shallow bowls. Lay an anchovy over each egg and garnish with a few basil leaves and a dusting of Parmesan. Serve with warm bread for swiping.

Also consider:

Other additions to the sauce: â€™nduja; crumbled sausage meat; a handful of baby spinach; pepperoni at the point the lid goes on.

Other garnishes: capers; chilli oil; hot honey.

Fried eggs in naan

Ed says: â€œThe freshness, pliability and quality of the bread makes or breaks an egg-filled naan. But when itâ€™s good, oh boy is it good. If you (as I am) are lucky enough to be able to source fresh naan locally, then do that. If not, then you can find plenty of recipes for making your own naan online, including Dishoomâ€™s (the British Bombay-inspired restaurant group, whose Bacon Naan Roll prompted my love of this particular form of Good Egg).â€

Per person

Anchovy, butter and parsley salad naan:Â

Ingredients

  • A handful of flat-leaf parsley leaves, roughly chopped
  • 20g red onion or shallot, very finely sliced
  • 1 tbsp moscatel or other white wine vinegar
  • 1 fresh naan, warmed
  • 1â€“2 fried eggs
  • Your preferred fat, for frying
  • 5â€“10g butter, in slices
  • 4â€“5 salted anchovies in oil

Method

Combine the parsley, onion and vinegar in a small bowl â€“ set this to one side while you warm the naan and fry your egg(s).

Arrange the butter slices and anchovies over one half of the warm naan. Add the parsley salad and top with egg(s). Fold the naan to close it, then cut in two to serve.

Dishoom-style bacon and egg naan

Ingredients

  • 1 fresh naan, warmed
  • 1 tbsp full-fat cream cheese
  • 1 tbsp spiced tomato chutney
  • 2 rashers cooked bacon
  • A few coriander (cilantro) leaves
  • 1â€“2 fried eggs

Method

Spread one half of the warm naan with cream cheese, add the chutney, and arrange the bacon and coriander on top. Top with the fried egg(s), fold the naan to close it, then cut in two to serve.

Poached eggs with 'nduja butter and spinach

Ed says: â€œCalabrian â€™nduja is fiery, fruity and salty. Ideal with eggs, then. It mellows a little once incorporated into melted butter â€“ although admittedly that is still a rich combination; even more so when joined by molten egg yolk. But thereâ€™s balance here, with the ooze offset by the purity of the poached whites, plus a soft bed of spinach and English muffins, which soak everything up. Glorious.â€

For 2

Ingredients

  • 35g â€™nduja
  • 20gÂ unsalted butter, plus extra for the muffins
  • 200g baby spinach
  • Flaky sea salt and ground black pepper
  • 2 English muffins, halved and toasted
  • 4 eggs

Method

Gently melt the â€™nduja and butter together in a small saucepan over a very low heat. Prod and stir until combined. The sauce should be loose and glossy â€“ donâ€™t let this boil or fry, otherwise the pork in the â€™nduja hardens and the butter and sauce will split. Remove from direct heat while you assemble the other components.

Wilt the spinach in a large sautÃ© or frying pan (skillet) set over a medium-high heat. Add a tablespoon of water to encourage the cooking process (no need for butter or oil thereâ€™s enough already in this dish). Once cooked, squeeze away any excess liquid. Season generously with salt and pepper.

Meanwhile, toast and butter the muffins and poach the eggs (page 60).

Serve, topping the toasted muffins with mounds of spinach and the poached eggs. Give the â€™nduja butter a good stir, then spoon over the top.


Also consider:

Replacing â€™nduja with Mallorcan sobrasada. There are also some vegan â€™nduja products, if you want to remove meat from this dish.

Thick-cut, toasted sourdough, ciabatta or crumpets instead of muffins. Spooning the sauce over fried eggs.

Good Eggs by Ed Smith (Quadrille, Â£22) is out now

Photography: Sam A. HarrisÂ

item.title: Move over Sambas: these are the 8 trainer styles set to be the next big thing in 2024 â€“ from Nike Cortez to Puma SpeedyCat
item.description: When it comes to cult trainers, the Adidas Samba has reigned supreme in recent years â€“ but which pairs are about to outrun them? Be one step ahead of the next bestsellers with the help of our fashion experts. Warning: youâ€™ll be adding a pair from our sneaker rundown to your spring/summer wish list.Â
item.dc:creator: Harriet Davey
item.content:encoded:
If seeing a new colourway of the Samba on Instagram (hello, burgundy) sends you into a frenzied search for your size, youâ€™re not alone. Seen on the feet of Hailey Bieber and Bella Hadid, along with fashion editors and influencers alike, the power of these go-with-everything kicks is as strong as ever in 2024. But they arenâ€™t the only styles weâ€™ve been lusting after: elsewhere, Salomonâ€™s XT-6 trainers (a favourite of East London satire account The Real Housewives of Clapton), New Balance 550 and Onitsuka Tiger Mexico 66 all reached cult status last year and continue to coveted.

If, however, youâ€™re casting your eyes forward to what might come next before you click â€˜add to cartâ€™, then youâ€™re in luck â€“ weâ€™ve enlisted the help of women in the know (from sneakerheads to fashion trend forecasters) to determine the styles that will be massive in 2024.

According to Rachel Makar, senior director at StockX, sporty nostalgia is on the horizon. â€œBe prepared to see more people serving all-white looks as tennis silhouettes are set to be a key trend this year. From Wimbledon to Zendayaâ€™s latest film, Challengers, Tenniscore is expected to have a similar impact as soccer silhouettes last year,â€ she says. â€œOn StockX, we have already seen a 35% YoY increase in trades on tennis shoes, including Nike Trainer 1 and Adidas Stan Smith.â€ Yep, thatâ€™s right: the Stan Smiths I loved in 2015 are making a big comeback a decade later.Â

So, whether you swap your rainbow Gazelles for a throwback Stan Smith, your Salomons for a pair of La Sportiva (more on these rising stars later)Â or your yellow Onitsuka Tigers for a pair in futuristic silver, these are the styles to buy now before they inevitably sell out.

New Balance 1906Â

When you think of New Balance, their chunky â€˜dadâ€™ style trainers most likely come to mind (a recent ad for the 990s even reads â€œworn by supermodels in London and Dads in Ohioâ€). But whatâ€™s the brandâ€™s latest style getting insiders all excited? â€œThe 1906 have got my heart this year,â€ shares Stylist columnist, freelance brand consultant and trainer lover Billie Bhatia. â€œThere is a real demand for performance-looking trainers to wear casually, and these tick all those boxes â€“ plus the metallic colourway brings a fashion-forward feeling to the trainers.â€

When it comes to ways to wear them this season, Billie suggests incorporating them into your weekend wear. â€œIâ€™ll be wearing mine with leather trousers, an oversized chunky knit and sunnies for the rest of spring,â€ she says.Â

New Balance 1906 trainers

Net-a-Porter also has this style in a classic white and cream colourway. Or, if you want to stick with the coloured trainer trend, white with a touch of pastel blue, pink, yellow and mint green.Â

Shop New Balance 1906 metallic sneakers at Net-a-Porter, Â£155

BUY NOW

Adidas Stan Smith

You might associate Stan Smiths with 2015/16, when they were everywhere: even the queen of stiletto heels, Victoria Beckham, was seen sporting a pair for New York Fashion Week back then. But now, almost a decade later (and 60 years after they were first created), theyâ€™re back on the fashion scene. Thanks to tenniscore, Iâ€™ve seen editors and influencers alike digging out their old pairs in recent months. And so, I predict â€“ along with all the other Sambas â€“ that these Adidas classics with continue to surge in 2024, especially for minimalists. See you on the court!Â

Adidas Stan Smith trainers

Since 2021, Stan Smith trainers have been made from recycled and vegan materials. Adidas has committed to using only recycled materials by 2025, and with Net-a-Porter reporting that thereâ€™s been a 200% rise in search for â€˜faux leather trainersâ€™ this is a wise move.Â

Shop Adidas Stan Smith trainers at Office, Â£85

BUY NOW

Nike CortezÂ

If youâ€™ve watched Forrest Gump, you may recognise these Nike trainers as the pair worn by Forrest for his casual 15,000 mile run (the exact pair recently sold at auction for $57,000). Now in 2024, The Cortez is being unboxed on Instagram as a must-have trainer style. According to Sanne Poeze, aka @girlonkicksÂ and author of She KicksÂ (a coffee table book highlighting women who are making waves in the sneaker world), these are the kicks to have on your radar.Â â€œI think styles like the Nike Cortez and other vintage-inspired styles like the Puma Palermo are going to be a thing in line with the 90s-revival weâ€™re seeing elsewhere. In terms of colourways, muted colours are popular with this style.â€

Nike Cortez trainers

For an extra Â£40, you can customise your own pair over at Nike.com with different colours and materials to suit your style.Â

Shop Nike Cortez trainers at Zalando, Â£89.95

Nike Nocta Hot Step 2

Thereâ€™s been no shortage of bright, bold trainers for the last few seasons â€“ and dopamine kicks are continuing to be key well into 2024. Already spotted on the streets during fashion month, the Nocta Hot Step 2 in zesty orange in collaboration with Drake are set to be everywhere this year. â€œChunky trainers arenâ€™t going out of style anytime soon and I predict that the Nike x Nocta will be popular in 2024,â€ says sneakerhead and content creator Kai Kho. â€œTheyâ€™re the perfect silhouette and I love how I can easily add them to any outfit when Iâ€™m in a rush.â€

Kai adds: â€œIâ€™ll be styling them with straight pants and a baggy T-shirt with an oversized jacket or with a hoodie/sweater and oversized joggers for a cosy look.â€

Nike Nocta Hot Step 2

After dropping only a matter of weeks ago, they of course sold out as soon as they landed. The good news? You can still find them on sites such StockX, Farfetch and Depop.Â

Puma SpeedyCat

According to influencer Selma Kaci, a re-release of a 90s classic will be the next big shoe of 2024. First created back in 1999, the Puma SpeedCat turned speedtrack-inspired trainers into street style favourites. This year, model Emily Ratajkowsi has already been spotted wearing a red pair with a black mini dress â€“ and theyâ€™re about to be re-released. â€œPuma has been teasing the launch of a new SpeedyCat set to drop in June this year,â€ says Selma. â€œTheyâ€™re a similar shape toÂ Onitsuka Tiger, but where the Onitsuka Tiger is rising star the SpeedCat is still quite niche, and so lesser-known. I think Puma is about to take over from OT when it comes to sneakers.â€

Puma SpeedCat trainers

Inspired by race tracks, the current SpeedCat is available in red, black, monochrome and navy. Of course, we back red for 2024.Â

ShopÂ Puma SpeedCat trainers, Â£100

Onitsuka Tiger Mexico 66

As the second most-popular trainer of 2023 (after the Adidas Samba, of course), you may have already heard of the Onitsuka Tiger Mexico 66. A celebrity favourite, theyâ€™re worn by Hailey Bieber, Bella Hadid and Kaia Gerber, and are setÂ to stick around for 2024, albeit with a new colourway on the scene. â€œRetro low-rise sneakers are emerging as a significant trend in 2024, undergoing a transformation with thinner sole units and a nostalgic aesthetic,â€ says chief commercial and sustainability officer at Mytheresa, Richard Johnson. But it wonâ€™t be the yellow youâ€™re clamouring for this year, but rather the brandâ€™s futuristic silver version. La Sportiva TX4

Salomonâ€™s practical, stylish shoes (the XT-6 in particular) were the first trekking trainers to become popular among the fashion elite (including being worn by Rihanna) â€“ but it looks like La Sportiva could be set to take over.Â Â â€œThis kind of functional shoe shape is so popular right now, especially with the â€˜Gorpcoreâ€™ trend being key,â€ explains sneakerhead Kai Kho. â€œSalomon has managed to build such a reputation within the industry, but itâ€™s only a matter of time before Sportiva are also worn by celebrities and stocked at big retailers, just like Salomon.â€Â

With TikTok already backing La Sportiva TX4s, and the practical punchy kicks already being spotted around London hot spots, watch this space.Â

La Sportiva TX4

Equal parts comfy and cool, we love the contrasting colours of this lilac, red and black pair.Â

Loewe + ON Cloudtilt

Aptly-named the Cloudtilt, thanks to the springy extra-comfy sole, Loeweâ€™s collaboration with Swiss running trainer brand ON is set to be one of the key styles of 2024. Net-a-Porter has reported that both brands are among the most popular on the site at the moment, with a 75% rise in searches for Loewe in the last six months and a huge 200% jump for ON in the last year. So when you combine the two most sought-after labels, you are certain get the coolest designer trainer around. Loewe + ON Cloudtilt trainers

item.title: Apple TV+â€™s Bad Sisters: the brilliantly dark comedy is back back back
item.description: This article contains spoilers for series one of Bad Sisters; if you havenâ€™t yet watched series one you might want to veer away nowâ€¦
item.dc:creator: Helen Bownass
item.content:encoded:
Bad Sisters was originally intended as a one-off.Â

The pitch-black comedy on Apple TV+ about the Garvey sistersÂ â€“ and the murder of one of their awful husbandsÂ â€“Â was one of our favourite shows of 2022, and also scored a very rare 100% fresh review on Rotten Tomatoes (meaning the critics approved), as well as acrruing a raft of Bafta TV nominations.

Thankfully Sharon Horgan, the showâ€™s creator and one of its stars, has seen the light and fans will get to revisit the murderous siblings. She has told The Radio Times: â€œI had no intention of doing any more, but while we were on set I kept thinking of this one idea that could be a possible second season. The first series did have a lovely end, but I think when you kill a man, when you put yourself through that â€“ and there were five of them in it â€“ life is going to change. You donâ€™t just dust yourself off and get on with your life. I was interested in what would happen to these women next. And weâ€™ll find out.â€

Hereâ€™s what we know about the show so far.Â

What is Bad Sisters season two about?

Based on a Belgian series called Clan, the chaotically brilliant 10-part series begins at the funeral ofÂ John Paul (Claes Bang) - and his rigor mortis-induced erection. The casket is surrounded by his wife Grace (Anne-Marie Duff) and her four sisters, and we quickly learn that all of them hated himÂ â€“ rightfully so, as he was manipulative and abusive to his wifeÂ â€“ and that his death wasnâ€™t an accident.Â

Via a series of flashbacks, the series follows the sistersâ€™ attempts to save Grace from her marital nightmare and take down â€˜The Prickâ€™. But things go awry when two insurance brokers come to investigate the claim, determined to prove he was murdered, to prevent having to make a huge payout.

While we donâ€™t know much about where the plot of the new season will take them, Horgan has given a strong hint that it wonâ€™t be plain sailing. â€œI mean, let this be a lesson to you â€” you donâ€™t usually just kill a man and get away with it.â€

Who stars in Bad Sisters season two?

The cast for series two is yet to be confirmed, but weâ€™re hopeful the whole Garvey clan will be back. That includes Sharon Horgan as Eva Garvey, Anne-Marie Duff as Grace Williams, Sarah Greene as Bibi Garvey, Eva Birthistle as Ursula Flynn and Eve Hewson as Becka Garvey. Weâ€™re also hopeful for the return of Daryl McCormack as Matthew Claffin, who was entangled romantically with Becka, and his brother and fellow insurance broker Thomas (played byÂ Brian Gleeson).

When can I watch Bad Sisters season two?

There is no confirmed release date for the series, but a recent post on X (formerly Twitter) leads us to hope we might not have to wait too long.Â

With the long bank holiday weekend within touching distance, youâ€™ve got plenty of time to catch up/rewatch series one if you havenâ€™t yet treated yourself yetâ€¦

Watch Bad Sisters on Apple TV+ here

Images: Apple TVÂ

item.title: Do smoothies really spike your blood sugar? Nutritionists explain the impact of blitzing fruit and veg
item.description: Nutritionists explain the science behind smoothies and blood glucose, and whether we should be eating fruits whole instead.Â
item.dc:creator: Miranda Larbi
item.content:encoded:
When it comes to quick, easy and healthy breakfasts, smoothies often come out on top. Bung a scoop of protein in for a recovery shake, add a spoon of flax or husk for added fibre or top with yoghurt and cacao nibs for a probiotic hit. For years, smoothies were often favoured over juices, because a smoothie often involves the blitzing of whole fruit and veg â€“ keeping in all that gut-loving fibre â€“ while juices tend to strip away most of the bulk, leaving behind a sugary (but delicious) liquid.

But, perhaps predictably in an age of blood sugar panic, smoothies are now in the firing line. Dr Idress Mughal (AKA Dr Idz) recently shared a video by a wellness podcaster who claimed that blending fruits â€œquadruples the glycemic profileâ€. This influencer went on to explain when you blitz a fruit, you disperse the fibre, which he argued leads to a four-time elevation in blood sugar compared with eating a whole fruit. Thatâ€™s a worry, he said, because â€œblood sugar is the root of all evilâ€.Â

Now, leaving aside the hyperbole of that last statement, this all sounds quite worrying. Even if you arenâ€™t fully subscribed to the glucose fear doing the rounds at the moment, no one wants to see a huge surge at breakfastÂ â€“ especially if you canâ€™t afford to take an 11am crash break.Â

So, whatâ€™s the truth? Are smoothies still a good way to start the day or are we better off eating whole fruits and nuts?

Dr Idz cleared up the claims by pointing to a controlled trial which compared the blood sugar effect of eating whole and blended apples and blackberries. It found that blended fruits actually resulted in a 15% lower blood sugar spike, with the research suggesting that the reduction was down to that fibre being dispersed around the drink.Â Â

Thatâ€™s seconded by Sophie Medlin,Â director and specialist dietitian at CityDietitians.Â â€œFirstly, there is evidence that smoothies cause less of an increase in blood sugars than whole fruit does,â€ she says. â€œThis is thought to be because the fibre is dispersed amongst the fructose from the fruit, allowing us to process it more slowly. Adding protein will further dampen any increase in blood sugars.Â

â€œSecondly, we donâ€™t need to worry about normal fluctuations in blood glucose from things like fruits or smoothies because people who are free from diabetes are perfectly capable of managing this without any harm being caused.â€

Smoothies cause less of a glucose spike than whole fruit

In other words, for the majority of us, this whole hoo-hah over glucose spikesÂ is just noise. â€œ[Spikes] are a completely normal function of the human body and not a concern for most people,â€ says Rohini Bajekal, nutritionist and co-author or Living PCOS Free.Â

â€œAfter we consume carbohydrates (like fruits and veg), they are broken down into sugars that enter the bloodstream to deliver energy to the muscles.â€ She says that a smoothie containing only fruit will have more of an impact on blood sugar than a smoothie with additional fats and protein, but a â€œâ€™spikeâ€™ in itself is not something to worry about and there is no solid evidence that these normal fluctuations are harmful in people without diabetes.

As such, she says that smoothies are â€œabsolutelyâ€ a healthy meal or snack. But she also says that smoothies should be more than just blended fruit, veg and water. â€œThey an be a great vehicle for nutrients such as healthy fatsÂ â€“ including plant milks, avocado, soya yogurt, ground flaxseed, chia seeds, nuts, nut butter or tahiniÂ â€“ which make smoothies more satiating. These ingredients also boost the protein content â€“ you could even use silken tofu or a vegan protein powder.

â€œDrizzle nut butter on top and add some granola for crunch or fresh fruit and seeds. You can also add in fresh herbs such as mint for a refreshing taste, or cinnamon.â€

Bajekal also says theyâ€™re great for anyone struggling to eat enough â€“ those who are nauseous post-workout of during pregnancy, for example. â€œWhen you blend ingredients, you break down plant cell walls, which makes many nutrients even more digestible. They are also an excellent way to add some greens into the diet. You can hardly taste the kale in a banana, soya milk, kale, cacao and peanut butter smoothie.â€Â

Are whole fruits better than smoothies?

Are there any benefits to eating fruits whole rather than blitzing them? â€œEating or blending fruits makes very little difference to me as a dietitian,â€ says Medlin. â€œAs long as people are eating plenty of plants, theyâ€™ll be fine. That said, blending fruits and vegetables will mean you get less insoluble fibre â€“ the type of fibre that comes from skins, peels and pips â€“ from them, so this may reduce the bulk of your stools, making it harder for your bowel to move them along the gut.â€ But she also says that smoothies contain plenty of soluable fibre, so your gut bacteria will still have plenty to feed on.

The only people who mightÂ be better off plumping for whole foods over smoothies most of the time are people who struggle with blood sugar control, like women with PCOS or pre-diabetes.

For the most part, â€œissues with high blood sugar are only a concern for diabetics who maintain high blood sugar levels over a period of years â€“ after which it starts to damage their bodies,â€ says PT and dietitian Adam Enaz. â€œWith the new hype of everyone glucose monitoring, a fear has built around having raised glucose levels after eating.â€

In a rare form of humility, the influencer called out by Dr Idz actually took his feedback on board and wrote in the video comments that heâ€™d been wrong in his conclusions.Â

3 ways to make your smoothie more nutritious

Enaz offers three tips for making the most nutritious smoothie:

Keep it to two fruits

Along with milk, he recommends using two fruits and more veg. If you are concerned about sugar, then make one of those fruits a berry, as these tend to be slightly less sweet and are packed with antioxidants and other micronutrients. Just be aware that blending bananas and berries can corrupt the nutrients of berries, so you might be better off keeping the two apart.

Add fibre

By adding extra fibre, youâ€™re going to slow down the energy production, meaning the smoothie will leave you fuller for longer.

Load up on protein

â€œAdd in a source of protein like Greek yoghurt or plant-based protein powder to balance the macronutrients,â€ says Enaz.Â

Refreshing green smoothie recipe

Bajekal offers the following tip for her go-to breakfast smoothie: â€œFreeze a medium sized ripe banana in advance and chop it into thirds to make it easier for your blender. I usually dice several bananas at once, separate them on a plate and pop the plate in my freezer for an hour or so. Then I remove the plate and add all the diced bananas to a ziplock silicone bag and freeze. This prevents the banana pieces sticking together, which is what usually happens if you dice and freeze them immediately in the bag.â€

Ingredients

Â½ cup unsweetened soya, pea or oat milk

1 medium-sized frozen banana

1 cup frozen mango

80g cucumber (1 small or Â½ medium)

20g (around a thumb-sized/2-inch piece) of fresh ginger

1 sprig of fresh mint, including the leaves

1 tbsp hemp seeds

MethodÂ

Blend for a minute until smooth and enjoy immediately. Top with a sprig of mint and hemp seeds.Â Â

â€œIf you donâ€™t have frozen mango, you can use 1 cup frozen pineapple or Â½ a medium fresh mango. A cup of frozen blueberries works, although the colour wonâ€™t be pretty! If you dislike the taste of banana in smoothies, try 1 frozen courgette instead, and add a date for sweetness. Add a soft date (e.g. Medjool date) or two to the smoothie for a sweeter flavour.â€

Images: Getty

item.title: 3 sleeping positions to relieve lower back pain, whether youâ€™re a side, back or stomach sleeper
item.description: Back pain keeping you up at night? Check out these tips from a musculoskeletal expert for nailing your sleeping position.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Geall
item.content:encoded:
Whether you enjoy curling up tight in a ball, lying flat on your back or collapsing face down in a starfish position, everyone has their own favourite sleeping position. Itâ€™s probably not something you think of that often; in most cases, itâ€™s simply what feels most comfy.

But the position that feels good when you first climb in between the sheets may not be best for you in the long run. In fact, adopting the wrong sleep position can not only exacerbate pre-existing back pain, but also create new issues. So, while contorting your body in a certain way might feel natural, it could also be the reason you wake up in agony.

Of course, you canâ€™t always control what happens while youâ€™re asleep, as anyone whoâ€™s woken up with a sock flung halfway across the room and the legs of their pyjamas hoisted up above their knees will know. What you can do, however, is go to sleep in a position which will best support your back as youâ€™re nodding off â€“ and thatâ€™s where this guide comes in.Â

â€œThere isnâ€™t one â€˜rightâ€™ sleeping position that will guarantee everyone a restful and pain-free sleep â€“ everyone experiences pain differently and what works for one person may not work for another,â€ explains Karen Beattie, a leading musculoskeletal expert and corporate clinical lead at Vita Health Group. â€œHowever, there are some simple tricks you can try thatâ€™ll help to take the pain and strain off your back and give you a restorative nightâ€™s sleep.â€

Below, Beattie talks us through the best sleeping positions to relieve back pain for back, side and stomach sleepers, as well as some easy tricks you can use to reduce pain before you get into bed.Â

The best sleeping positions for relieving back painÂ Â

For side sleepers:

Side sleepers with lower back or neck pain will benefit from using pillow supports, Beattie says.

â€œTry drawing your legs up slightly towards your chest and putting a pillow between your legs,â€ she explains. â€œThis can help to align your spine, pelvis and hips.â€

The pillow between your legs can also prevent your upper leg from falling forward, which can cause your torso to twist and increase tension across your back.

â€œAvoid tucking your chin to maintain the natural curve of your neck,â€ Beattie adds.

For back sleepers:

Back sleepers can also benefit from using a pillow to support their alignment.

â€œPlacing a pillow under your knees can help to relax your back muscles and maintain the curve of your lower back,â€ Beattie explains. â€œTo hold your body in place, you could also try putting a small, rolled-up towel under the small of your back.â€

For front sleepers:

Itâ€™s worth noting that sleeping on your front isnâ€™t ideal for your musculoskeletal health because of the extra strain it places on your neck and lower back.

But if sleeping on your front is the only way that feels right, you can also use a pillow to relieve some of the tension, Beattie adds.

â€œPlacing a pillow under your hips and lower stomach can take the pressure off your lower back,â€ she says. â€œYou may also want to try having a pillow under your head [if you sleep without one] if your neck feels strained.â€Â

How to enjoy a comfortable, pain-free sleepÂ

While your sleeping position will make a big difference to how your body feels while youâ€™re in bed and when you wake up in the morning, there are some things you can do to relieve tension and prevent pain from arising before you even get into bed in the evening.

1. Do some light movement

â€œIf you take just a few minutes to stretch and move your body before you go to bed, it can help to ease muscle tension thatâ€™s built up during the day,â€ Beattie says. â€œStretching and light exercise can also help to reduce stress before going to sleep.â€

The key word here is light: anything too heavy that elevates your heart rate could make it harder for you to fall asleep, so make sure to take things nice and slow.Â

2. Get the temperature right

During deep, restorative sleep your muscles do not move, so maximising the amount of time you spend in this state will allow you to maintain your sleeping position and prevent too much tossing and turning, which can put strain on your muscles and joints.Â

Ensuring your bedroom is the right temperature for a restful nightâ€™s sleep is a good place to start, Beattie suggests. â€œHaving a bedroom thatâ€™s hot and stuffy, or too cool, could cause you to have a restless nightâ€™s sleep. Think about the tog rating of your duvet: a lighter one is best in summer and a heavier one is best to support sleep in winter. Focus on creating an environment thatâ€™s comfortable for you and gives your body the opportunity to have a restful night sleep.â€

Having a hot bath before bed can also help your body to feel cooler once youâ€™re in bed, as the hot water will cause your bodyâ€™s cooling response to kick in. This cooling effect can also make it easier for you to fall asleep, as the drop in temperature stimulates the release of the sleep hormone, melatonin.

3. See an expert

If youâ€™re struggling with persistent back pain, itâ€™s time to seek professional help.

â€œReassuringly, most episodes of back pain will resolve naturally over time,â€ Beattie says. â€œBut for those stubborn episodes that donâ€™t resolve as quickly as you would have hoped, musculoskeletal experts â€“ such as physiotherapists, musculoskeletal clinicians and rehabilitation specialists â€“ can support you with your recovery by providing tailored programmes consisting of advice, coaching, and tailored exercise programmes, with your goals at the core.â€

A GP appointment is a good place to start, as they should be able to refer you to any specialists or recommend additional treatments.Â

item.title: Women are more at risk of chronic inflammation â€“ hereâ€™s what that means for our mental and physical health
item.description: Inflammation is a natural process, but too much of it could be putting our wellbeing at risk.Â
item.dc:creator: Eve Delaney
item.content:encoded:
Inflammation may sound scary, but itâ€™s very useful. Not only does it help to heal wounds and fight off infection, but itâ€™s also a natural byproduct of our womb lining shedding during menstruation. As with anything, however, you can have too much of a good thing. Autoimmune diseases such as endometriosis, rheumatoid arthritis, inflammatory bowel disease, cystic fibrosis and Crohnâ€™s disease have all been linked to an abnormal inflammatory response and research suggests chronic inflammation could play a role in conditions ranging from cancer to stroke.Â

Women tend to experience higher levels of inflammation than men, putting us more at risk of those unwanted consequences. But why is this? And is there a solution?Â Â

What is inflammation?

When you get a papercut, it may become red, swollen, warm and painful. These symptoms occur for several reasons, but mainly because blood and immune system cells are quickly pumped to the site of injury. They are all signs of inflammation â€“ a process that forms part of the bodyâ€™s defense system.

Inflammation happens all over the body (internally and externally) as a result of injuries, but also germs (bacteria, viruses or fungus). Bronchitis, for example, is a common internal inflammatory condition in the airways and lungs, usually triggered in response to a virus (eg the common cold, flu or Covid). The symptoms can include a cough, a fever, tiredness and a runny nose. These are all signs of inflammation, which might temporarily make you feel rough but are a vital defensive tool.

The fever, for example, helps to create an unfriendly atmosphere for the pathogens to thrive. Inflammation in the bronchial tubes can also lead to an increased production of mucus, which helps to provide a protective barrier against harmful foreign particles and lubricates to prevent injury. Coughing then expels the mucus, which carries the infection, preventing it from accumulating in the airways and causing a more severe reaction.

The inflammatory process is smart but also tiring. You feel exhausted when you have acute inflammation because your body is doing a lot to try to protect you.

But this kind of inflammatory response is typically short term, so most people can deal with it. Itâ€™s when inflammation hangs around and becomes chronic that things become problematic â€“ and itâ€™s women who are more likely to be affected.Â

The link between inflammation and sex (and what it means)Â

Research has shown that adult women have stronger innate and adaptive immune responses than men, which is a good thing when weâ€™re fighting off dangerous infections. But it also means weâ€™re at increased risk of autoimmune conditions, which occur when the immune system malfunctions or goes into overdrive, attacking healthy cells.

Statistics show that up to 80% of people with autoimmune diseases are women, and many of these inflammatory conditions are chronic. While acute episodes of inflammation are mainly positive, chronic inflammation can be problematic. â€œItâ€™s like a fire erupting in a village. Everyone pours water on the fire, and it goes out without any lasting damage,â€ explains Natasha Seaton, a researcher in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) from Kingâ€™s College London. â€œBut if the villagers continue to pour water on a fire that no longer exists, youâ€™d get damaging flooding throughout the town.â€Â

80% of people with autoimmune diseases are women

Symptoms of chronic inflammation present differently for everyone. Someone living with chronic cystitis might experience bladder pain and urgency, while an IBD patient could struggle with severe abdominal pain or anaemia. Tests like stool samples, blood tests, ultrasounds and biopsies are used as diagnostic tools to reveal autoimmune conditions and excess inflammation. But despite a general understanding of the issue, the cause is less understood.

As with most areas of womenâ€™s health, the reasons and impacts are not yet fully understood. While hormonal factors are likely important â€“ particularly the role of oestrogen in modulating inflammation â€“ research now points to chromosomal differences as a big component, with the genes in the extra X chromosome women possess directly relating to the immune response.Â

Is poor mental health caused by inflammation?

According to the Mental Health Foundation, women are three times more likely than men to experience common mental health problems such asÂ anxiety and depression. That disparity can be linked to several factors, such as gendered pressures and excess stress levels, but it may also be linked to all the inflammation women are dealing with.

Professor Valeria Mondelli, clinical professor of psychoneuroimmunology at Kingâ€™s College London, tells Strong Women that an â€œincrease in inflammation can lead to mental health problems, and up to 30% of people living with depression also have an inflammatory disorderâ€.

Edward Bullmore explores this further in his book The Inflamed Mind, in which he refutes the belief that inflammation canâ€™t travel into the brain. He suggests that his patients with rheumatoid arthritis are not simply depressed because of the limiting factors of their disability, but because the inflammation associated with the condition itself was reaching the brain and causing depression.Â

All of this raises the question: are women more at risk of depression and/or anxiety than men if weâ€™re more likely to be chronically inflamed? Professor Mondelli tells us that while more research in this field is still needed, thereâ€™s some evidence to suggest that the answer may be â€˜yesâ€™.

The â€˜chicken and eggâ€™ conundrum here makes separating cause and consequence very difficult. What came first â€“ the lupus or the trauma? The psychosis or the polymyalgia?â€¯Is the number of women suffering with mental health issues the result of inflammation or are the mental health issues causing the inflammation in the first place?Â

As someone who lives with chronic health conditions, Iâ€™ve always found the whole â€˜mind-body connectionâ€™ an extremely hard pill to swallow. If my physical symptoms and conditions â€“ which include asthma, chronic fatigue, migraines, chronic cystitis and so on â€“ are linked to my mind, am I in some way responsible for them?

Seaton explains that itâ€™s not that simple. The mind-body connection doesnâ€™t mean people are thinking the problems into existence; rather, itâ€™s a term used to describe a physiological response.

â€œAutoimmune conditions have been shown to arise following stressful periods,â€ she explains. Indeed, stress can cause the sympathetic nervous system to become dysregulated and create a â€˜biochemical cascadeâ€™ that can result in various symptoms.Â

You canâ€™t think health problems into existence

This link between stress and inflammation could also explain why more women struggle with high levels of both. After all, being a sick or disabled woman â€“ as with any minoritised group â€“ can come with high levels of distress.Â

The gender health gap has left many women unfairly treated. Women in the UK are 50% more likely to be misdiagnosed following a heart attack (which can be caused by inflammation) and women with dementia (the risk of which can be exacerbated by inflammation) tend to receive worse medical treatment than men. Weâ€™re also up to four timesÂ more likely to suffer from an autoimmune disease (which, as we already know, has been linked to that inflammation response).Â

So, is oppression making us sick? Certainly, recent findings highlight the need to â€˜tackle discriminationâ€™ to improve the wellbeing of pain sufferers and potentially â€˜reduce the risk of pain onsetâ€™.Â Â

Sarah Lees, 28, lives with rheumatoid arthritis (RA), which causes swelling and pain in her joints and extreme fatigue. She believes that long-term medical stress is inextricably linked to her inflammatory condition, claiming that institutional sexism stopped her from accessing necessary medication.

â€œThe patriarchal structure of the medical system meant that I wasnâ€™t able to access the medication that I needed for a long time,â€ she says. Lee claims that her needs were ignored because she was seen as â€œtoo emotionalâ€ during medical appointments. It wasnâ€™t until her dadâ€™s friend told her about Biologics (an injectable drug that has transformed her life) and encouraged her to â€œpush for the treatment no matter whatâ€ that she was able to make some progress with her recovery.

How to deal with chronic inflammation

Change wonâ€™t happen overnight, but a growing understanding of the link between inflammation and mental health could improve things. After all, for mind-body obstacles, we need mind-body solutions, as Professor Mondelli highlights.Â

â€œWe have found that for patients who have both inflammation and depression, we can regulate their depression by using anti-inflammatory medication,â€ she says.

Seaton has similarly found that treatments for mental illness can lead to significant improvement in patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Her research explores what happens to an IBD patientâ€™s inflammation if you treat their anxiety, depression and distress, and has found that psychological therapy including cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) can cause the largest reductions of inflammation in IBD. This is likely because of the link between mental health and physical inflammation, but it may also be linked to the fact that people with better mental health are more easily able to look after their physical health â€“ including taking medication on time and exercising.

There are a number of lifestyle and wellness interventions that have been found to reduce inflammation, from infrared saunas to cold water. Iâ€™ve certainly found the latter helps massively in reducing the severity of my symptoms.

But as Iâ€™m reaching for my next bottle of salted caramel kefir in the supermarket (jam-packed with sugar which is, you guessed it, inflammatory), I canâ€™t help but wonder if the diet and wellness industryâ€™s use of the term â€˜anti-inflammatoryâ€™ is just another marketing scheme targeted at women who are more informed than ever about the damaging effects of inflammation but less aware of the reasons why they have it.Â

While more research is needed, findings that reinforce the link between mental health and physical inflammation are promising. Letâ€™s hope more research into the issue â€“ and growing awareness of the gender health gap and the impact it has on women who are struggling â€“ could provide a way forward.Â

Images:Â Pexels

item.title: The 2024 Womenâ€™s Prize for Non-Fiction Shortlist has been revealed
item.description: From a memoir on a turbulent life in rural Jamaica to an exploration of how AI is taking over the world, hereâ€™s the shortlist for the inaugural Womenâ€™s Prize for Non-Fiction.Â Â Â Â
item.dc:creator: Vicky Chandler
item.content:encoded:
With thousands upon thousands of books published each year, it can be overwhelming to find the ones truly worth reading. But the Womenâ€™s Prize is a great place to start, a community that brings people together through their shared love of books written by women.

And while their Womenâ€™s Prize for Fiction awards have been running since 1996, this is their inaugural year for a non-fiction alternative. Judges include historian and broadcaster Professor Suzannah Lipscomb, fashion campaigner Venetia La Manna, academic and author Professor Nicola Rollock, biographer and journalist Anne Sebba and author and Womenâ€™s Prize for Fiction 2018 winner Kamila Shamsie.

The shortlist has now been revealed for the Womenâ€™s Prize for Non-Fiction 2024, showcasing six incredible books exploring everything from a turbulent life in rural Jamaica to how AI is taking over the world.Â

Thunderclap: A Memoir of Art and Life And Sudden Death by Laura Cumming

On the morning of 12 October 1654, a gunpowder explosion in Delft left the Dutch city devastated. Among the victims was Carel Fabritius, 32, a painter who left behind his haunting masterpiece â€˜The Goldfinchâ€™, among a few other pieces of artwork.

Cummingâ€™s book explores Fabritiusâ€™s life before the disaster and the connection between art and life, interweaving her own life and the death of her Scottish painter father into the story, along with appearances from the great artists of the Dutch Golden Age.

â€œI love this book because of the way she intertwines a subtle and tender love of her father with a deep understanding of Dutch art,â€ says judge Anne Sebba.

BUY NOW

DOPPELGANGER: A Trip Into The Mirror World by Naomi Klein

What if you woke up one morning and found youâ€™d acquired a double?

Klein discovered that a woman who shared her first name, but had radically different, harmful views to her, was being mistaken for her. At first it was too ridiculous to take seriously. But then it took a dark turn, as she began grappling with a distorted sense of reality, becoming obsessed with reading threats and insults on social media from the followers of her doppelganger.

Klein decided to follow her double into a bizarre, uncanny mirror world of conspiracy theories and anti-vaxxers â€“ lifting the lid on our own culture, from public shaming to deep fakes.

â€œSuch a clever book, because [Klein] takes what, on the face of it, is a simple idea of having a double, someone who is frequently thought of as her, but then expands this to construct a dark comedy of a rather terrifying mirror image world,â€ writes Sebba.

BUY NOW

A FLAT PLACE: A Memoir by Noreen Masud

Masud has always loved flatlands since her early memories of wide, flat fields spanning the horizons as she drove in the back seat of her fatherâ€™s car in Lahore. As an adult in Britain, she has discovered many more â€“ Orford Ness, the Cambridgeshire Fens and Morecambe Bay, to name a few.

However, these bare, haunted expanses remind her of the flat place within her, created by trauma. Suffering from complex PTSD, Masud embarks on a pilgrimage to Britainâ€™s flatlands to seek solace and belonging, weaving in poetry, folklore and history, with recollections of her own early life.

â€œI love this for its originality and its intelligence. It is revelatory about both people and places,â€ says judge Kamila Shamsie.

BUY NOW

ALL THAT SHE CARRIED: The Journey of Ashleyâ€™s Sack, a Black Family Keepsake by Tiya Miles

In 1850s South Carolina, Rose, an enslaved woman, faced a crisis: the imminent sale of her daughter Ashley. Thinking quickly, she packed a cotton bag with a few items. Soon after, the nine-year-old girl was separated from her mother and sold. Decades later, Ashleyâ€™s granddaughter Ruth embroidered this family history on the sack in spare, haunting language.

How does one uncover the lives of people who, in their day, were considered property? Harvard historian Tiya Miles carefully traces these womenâ€™s faint presence in archival records and, where archives fall short, she turns to objects, art and the environment to write a singular history of the experience of slavery, and the uncertain freedom afterward.

â€œA vital re-telling and re-imagining of stories lost under enslavement. A bold and beautiful book, I loved it,â€ says judge Venetia La Manna.

BUY NOW

CODE DEPENDENT: Living in the Shadow of AI by Madhumita Murgia

What does it mean to be a human in a world of artificial intelligence? Through the voices of ordinary people, this book explores the impact of a set of powerful, flawed and often exploitative technologies on individuals, communities and our wider society.

How can AI strip away our collective and individual sense of agency? How will we be governed by algorithms in years to come? Why are we relinquishing our moral authority to machines? Murgia, the Financial Timesâ€™ first Artificial Intelligence Editor, not only sheds light on this chilling phenomenon, but also charts a path of resistance.

â€œThis is a chilling and essential read about AI and the way it imports and exacerbates existing social inequalities,â€ says judge Professor Nicola Rollock.

BUY NOW

HOW TO SAY BABYLON: A Jamaican Memoir by Safiya Sinclair

Born in Montego Bay, Jamaica, where luxury hotels line pristine white sand beaches, Sinclair grew up with a volatile reggae musician father who was a strict believer in a militant sect of Rastafari. To protect the purity of the women in their family, he forbade almost everything: nowhere but home and school, no friends but this family and no future but this path.

Her mother did what she could to bring joy to her children with books and poetry. But as Safiyaâ€™s imagination reached beyond its restrictive borders, her burgeoning independence brought with it ever greater clashes with her father. Soon she realised that if she was to live at all, she had to find some way to leave home. In seeking to understand the past of her family, Sinclair takes readers inside a world that is little understood by those outside it, and offers an astonishing personal reckoning. An unforgettable story of a young womanâ€™s determination to live life on her own terms.

â€œA lyrical, evocative, and beautifully written memoir about growing up Rastafari in rural Jamaica,â€ says Rollock.Â

BUY NOW

Images: From the publishers

item.title: Elisabeth Moss and Kerry Washington to star in Apple TV+ psychological thriller Imperfect Women

Based on Araminta Hallâ€™s novel, Imperfect Women is packed with suspense and drama and explores guilt and retribution, love and betrayal and the decisions we make that ultimately alter our lives forever. Mysterious, right? Well, hereâ€™s everything we know so far about the series.

What is the plot of Imperfect Women?

As the series is an adaptation of the book, we can only assume that itâ€™ll follow a similar story. Nancy Hennessy is murdered, leaving behind her two best friends (Eleanor and Mary), her husband and daughter, and a secret lover whose identity she never revealed to anyone. From the outside, Nancyâ€™s life was perfect. But, â€œas the investigation unravels, so does the truth about how even the closest relationships can change over timeâ€, warns the synopsis.

Imperfect Women poses the question: how well do we really know our friends, or even ourselves?

Who will star in Imperfect Women?

As the project has only just been announced, not much is known about the casting apart from Elisabeth Moss and Kerry Washington being on board. Itâ€™s likely that the pair will play the two friends, Eleanor and Mary, but thatâ€™s just speculation at this point.

Speaking about the series, Moss said: â€œFrom the moment I received Aramintaâ€™s novel, I couldnâ€™t put it downâ€¦ I fell in love with it immediately. When will Imperfect Women be released?

As the series is in production, itâ€™ll be a long while until we get a release date for Imperfect Women. Weâ€™ll be sure to update you with any new details as theyâ€™re announced.

item.title: Are habit trackers an effective way to build new healthy habits?
item.description: Whether you want to wake up earlier or eat more plants, a habit tracker could be the tool youâ€™re looking for. We ask a psychiatrist to explain how best to use a tracker to reap the biggest benefits.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Geall
item.content:encoded:
It doesnâ€™t matter what time of year it is, building a new habit is difficult. We want to wake up earlier but weâ€™re exhausted after a couple of days of 6am starts. We vow to eat 30 plants a week but soon find that weâ€™re back to making the same old meals every day.

But one increasingly popular way of diverting habit hell and making it to the resolution promised land is using a habit tracker. Designed to help people keep track of the behaviours they want to implement and celebrate their successes, habit trackers are everywhere these days and come in various forms, including standalone habit tracker pads, apps and journals.

But is keeping track of our behaviour in this way an effective technique for building healthy habits? Does ticking off small wins make introducing new routines easy? Or do habit trackers oversimplify the hard work required to make a routine second nature? We asked the experts for their take on this trending approach.Â

What are the benefits of using habit trackers?Â

We all know how important it is to celebrate the small wins, and habit trackers are a brilliant way to tap into this feeling, especially if youâ€™re someone who likes to visualise your progress.

â€œThe most important feature of a habit tracker is the sense of progression it offers,â€ saysÂ Dr Galyna SeleznevaÂ a psychiatrist and aesthetic doctor. â€œIt allows you to keep a better eye on your own activity, build self-awareness and reduce self-sabotage, and frequently tracking progress towards your goals is incredibly motivating.â€

It might not seem like habit trackers have the power to stop you from sabotaging your progress, but their ability to make you accountable for your actions â€“ by ticking things off day by day â€“ is a useful tool to keep you focused.

Michele Ferron, founder of Once Upon A Tuesday, a stationery brand that counts habit trackers among its offerings, adds that habit trackers are a useful â€œvisual reminderâ€ of the goals youâ€™ve set.

And while using a digital habit tracker may not be quite as visually prominent, the satisfaction of ticking off your daily tasks â€“ as well as seeing them add up over time â€“ can be equally motivating.Â Â

Are there any downsides to using a habit tracker?Â

A habit tracker can be a useful tool when youâ€™re introducing new behaviours, but only if you take the time to use it properly. After all, a habit tracker isnâ€™t some magical quick fix: you need to put in the effort and know what youâ€™re trying to achieve if you want your new habits to stick.

Failing to make your new habits clear and achievable is one of the biggest mistakes people make, Ferron says. â€œHabit trackers are only effective if you formulate your habits in a certain way,â€ she explains. â€œâ€˜Eating healthyâ€™ is too big a habit to start with â€“ itâ€™s too easy to break and then abandon because itâ€™s too overwhelming. In my experience, itâ€™s best to break that down into small habits you build over time.â€

If you want to eat a healthier diet, that might mean starting with a goal to eat a certain number of plants per week or cooking a healthy meal from scratch once every couple of days. To begin with, those tasks might feel quite challenging, but over time they should become easier. Then, once they donâ€™t feel so overwhelming, you can set yourself new goals to tackle, so youâ€™re slowly adding to the number of behaviours youâ€™ve ticked off.Â

How to use a habit tracker to build new habitsÂ

Inspired to start habit tracking? Here are some tips to ensure you get the most out of your new approach.

1. Start small

You wouldnâ€™t try to run a marathon after one day of training, so donâ€™t set yourself up for failure by forcing yourself to make a bunch of big changes. Start with one or two habits, and make sure theyâ€™re realistic.

2. Share your journey with others

â€œCommunity support is one of the best tools you can use to build new habits,â€ Dr Selezneva says. â€œSharing your journey and exchanging support with those who are passionate about your success is important.â€

To do this, you could try keeping your habit tracker in a shared area of your home or simply sharing updates with a trusted friend or family member at various points throughout your journey. This will not only help to keep you accountable, but also give you someone to celebrate with when you reach important milestones.

3. Prioritise simplicity

There are plenty of different habit trackers out there these days but try not to opt for one thatâ€™s too complicated or long-winded. Designers like Ferron have made products that are incredibly easy to use. And if you donâ€™t fancy investing in a habit tracker app or physical pad to start with, then you can create your own using a pen and paper â€“ simply write down your habit and put a tick next to every day you manage to achieve it.Â

item.title: Mercury retrograde is back again on 1 April: this is your need-to-know guide to survive it
item.description: The first Mercury retrograde of 2024 kicks off on 1 April and will stick around until 25 Aprilâ€¦ meaning weâ€™ve got over three weeks of chaos ahead. Hereâ€™s your survival guide.Â
item.dc:creator: Ellen Scott
item.content:encoded:
Brace yourself: Mercury retrograde is officially around the corner, and that means chaos is about to reign. There are three Mercury retrogrades in 2024, and the first one begins on 1 April. This spells disruption in the realms of communication and travel, so anticipate typo-packed emails, misunderstood messages and many delayed trains.Â

But donâ€™t panic too much: there are ways to survive this rocky period. Ahead youâ€™ll find your need-to-know guide to all things Mercury retrograde.Â

What is a Mercury retrograde?

A retrograde simply means that a planet appears to be going backwards, rather than its usual forwards orbit. Of course, Mercury never actually reverses its spin, as that would be a pretty major planetary catastrophe, but due to all the planetsâ€™ orbits around the sun, along with the Earthâ€™s rotations, there are points when it will look closer to us and as though itâ€™s sped on ahead.Â

The times when Mercury appears to go backwards occur every 88 days (the length of the planetâ€™s cycle around the sun), meaning you usually get three retrogrades in a year.

When is Mercury in retrograde in 2024?

Youâ€™ve got three Mercury retrogrades to prepare for this year. The first one hit from 21 April to 14 May, and was in the sign of Taurus. Next up, thereâ€™s a Mercury retrograde that goes from 23 August to 15 September, then finally, thereâ€™s one in Capricorn and Sagittarius, between 13 December and 1 January 2024.Â

The last Mercury retrograde of 2023 ended on 1 January 2024, but Mercury will be in retrograde three more times in 2024: 1 April 1, 2024 to 25 April, 5 August to 27 August and 25 November to 15 December.Â

How will Mercury retrograde impact us?

Astrology fans believe that Mercury retrograde affects us all, regardless of our star signs. Because Mercury is the planet thought to rule communication, travel and logical thinking, when it goes retrograde, these are the areas it affects negatively.Â

This means that throughout Mercury retrograde, you might experience issues with communication â€“ think crossed wires in conversations, accidentally missing an important work email, WhatsApping the person you were bitching about rather than the mate you intended; travel â€“ missed flights, train delays, your favourite shoes falling apart; and logical thinkingÂ â€“ emotions may be heightened, so thinking rationally can be tough.

Youâ€™re not doomed to a terrible few weeks, of course, but things might just be a littleâ€¦ trickier, particularly in these areas. The good news is there are ways to navigate it.Â

How to get through the Mercury retrograde

Give yourself more time for travelÂ

If you know a journey usually takes an hour, perhaps give yourself a little bit of a cushion on either side. Leave 15 minutes earlier than you think.Â

Why? Because Mercury retrograde has a rep for really messing with all things travel related. Expect cancelled buses, trains stuck at stations and a puncture in your bike tyre. Giving yourself a little extra time in case of any bumps in the road will lessen the stress.Â

Triple check all messagesÂ

Mercury retrograde also tends to mess with communication. To avoid any mishaps, make this a time youâ€™re super stringent with checking, checking and checking one more time. That goes for emails, texts, WhatsApps, the lot. Watch out for embarrassing typos, important emails landing in your spam folder, and texts sent to the wrong people. Better safe than sorry.

Donâ€™t have any big, important conversations during this time

On the topic of communication, perhaps consider holding any big, important chats until Mercuryâ€™s back to normal. This is a time when misinterpretation is rife and communication might hit blocks.Â

Triple check all your travel tickets and timings

Weâ€™ve already warned you about travel issues, but hereâ€™s a reminder. Have a proper look at any booked tickets and planned trips to ensure youâ€™ve got everything nailed. If thereâ€™s a time when youâ€™ll turn up for a flight on the wrong day, itâ€™s Mercury retrograde.Â

Remain calm

Please remember that all this Mercury retrograde chat is highly theoretical, and could well be total nonsense. Even if it actually does have an impact, stressing about the potential chaos wonâ€™t help matters. Donâ€™t catastrophise, donâ€™t assume everythingâ€™s doomed, and take some time for deep, slow, calming breaths when any issues rear their head. Remain laidback and youâ€™ll be far better equipped to deal with whatever mix-ups occur.Â

Do a digital detox day

On the note of bad communication, perhaps Mercury retrograde is a good time to down tools and steer clear of social media and screens, where thereâ€™s potential for things to go badly. Always nice to have an excuse for a phone-free day, right?Â

Reminisce and reflect

The clueâ€™s in the name: the retrograde also brings a â€˜blast from the pastâ€™ energy. Itâ€™s a great time to reminisce on good times and reflect on what youâ€™ve learned. Rather than taking action during Mercury retrograde, have some space to think back over the pastâ€¦ and brace yourself for long-gone exes and friends to make an appearance, as that often happens during retrogrades, too.Â

Embrace the challenge

Look, sometimes things go wrong, retrograde or no retrograde. Accepting this is a key first step in better dealing with stress, but the next step is embracing it. When things donâ€™t go to plan, consider what you can learn as a result. Pat yourself on the back for overcoming struggles. Take on the challenges in your path as a chance to display your problem-solving skills and resilience. Youâ€™ve got this.Â
