item.title: In 2024, the feathered bob is the textured crop of your dreams
item.description: Feathered layers and bobs are both massive trends right now. Putting them both together just makes sense.Â
item.dc:creator: Aidan Milan
item.content:encoded:
â€˜Feathered hairâ€™ describes a haircut with loads of layers that creates a tumbling, light and plumage-esque effect about the ends. Itâ€™s perfect for adding a bit of volume, since the ends arenâ€™t weighed down. Think the opposite of â€˜bluntâ€™, and youâ€™ll get the idea.

Feathered hair has had a bit of a branding problem since the heyday of icon Farrah Fawcett, who was so famous for rocking the style that her headshot is the photo on the Wikipedia page for the cut.

But with the likes of BeyoncÃ© dabbling with feathered layers recently, and bobs having utterly taken over the world, combining the two just feels right.

Lâ€™OrÃ©al Professionnel UK editorial artist Louis Byrne tells Stylist: â€œAs we step into spring there is a desire from clients to change up their style for something new and fresh. Weâ€™ve seen long-waved locks as a prominent look in the fashion space this year. However, the constant heat styling can take its toll on the hair. This is why the feathered layers and bobs are so popular right now, as these styles will allow for healthier-looking hair while also creating balance, shape and form for more bounce and volume.â€

How can feathered layers work with a bob?

Byrne explains: â€œItâ€™s the feathered layers that bring out individual personality in a bob. A good hair cutter will know where to take the layers and how much to feather according to your features. Always invest in a good haircut, as this should last you between three and five months. Itâ€™s also very important to take good care of your hair between salon appointments. I recommend always finishing with an oil for added shine and to keep ends hydrated.â€

How will a feathered bob look on different hair textures?

â€œThe feathered bob works on all hair textures,â€ says Byrne, â€œas long as it is cut well. I recommend booking a consultation with your stylist before to explain exactly what you want from this cut. Your stylist will then be able to advise you, depending on your hair type and texture. I actually use feathering in all my haircutting to personalise the cut with an undone but precise finish to ensure the hairstyle fits each of my clients.â€

What to tell your stylist if you want to get the look

Byrne says: â€œFirst of all,  you need to find the right stylist for you. Research their work beforehand to ensure they are the right fit for the style you want. Make sure you tell your stylist you would like a feathering technique, because using thinning scissors will not get you the same results â€“ they will make your hair look drier and wirier. I also recommend asking for colour to enhance the texture of this style.â€

Feathered bob inspo

item.title: 28 books you need to add to your reading list now theyâ€™ve been turned into films and TV series
item.description: We all became obsessed with One Day, when it arrived last month. So, here are 28 of the best book-to-screen adaptations.Â
item.dc:creator: Hollie Richardson
item.content:encoded:
Anyone whoâ€™s ever been nervous about seeing their favourite novel being adapted for the screen will agree that adapting books for TV and filmÂ is a contentious issue (â€™did they really cast that actor as your favourite character? Why did they cut the best chapter?â€™). But the past few years have given us some brilliant book-to-screen adaptations. Just look at the success of Sally Rooneyâ€™s Normal People on BBC Three, season five of OutlanderÂ on Amazon Prime Video and the modern movie retelling of Jane Austenâ€™s Emma.Â

From One Day to All The Light We Cannot See, books continue to provide the inspiration for so many films and series. So, with that in mind, letâ€™s take a look at the books that have been turned into films and TV showsÂ â€“ and add them all to our reading lists.

One Day

In perhaps the most anticipated adaptation of 2024, David Nichollâ€™s best-selling novel One Day, which follows the lives of Emma Morley and Dexter Mayhew after they meet for the very first time on 15 July 1988, the night of their graduation, arrived on Netflix last month.

While the book was previously adapted into a film starring Anne Hathaway and Jim Sturgess back in 2011, this is the first time the book will be making its way to the small screen, starring Ambika Mod and Leo Woodall.

Buy now

All the Light We Cannot See

Having premiered last year, the Netflix adaptation of All the Light We Cannot See followsÂ a blind teenager in occupied France during World War II who meets up with a German soldier, Werner.Â

The novel traces Marie-Laure and Werner as they cross paths and both try to survive the devastation of World War II, and the series is being helmed by Peaky Blinders adapter Steven Knight and Stranger Things director Shawn Levy.

Buy now

The Last Letter From Your Lover

Who doesnâ€™t love a Jojo Moyes love story? And when Felicity Jones, Shailene Woodley, Callum Turner, Nabhaan Rizwan, and Joe Alwyn lead the cast, you know itâ€™s going to be a must-see.

The Last Letter From Your Lover follows Ellie Haworth, an ambitious journalist who discovers a trove of secret love letters from 1965 and becomes determined to solve the mystery of the forbidden affair at their centre.Â

BUY NOW

House Of Gucci

Directed by Ridley Scott,Â Â House Of Gucci is based on a book by Sara G Forden about the shocking real life murder of Gucci heir, Maurizio Gucci. Starring Lady Gaga and Adam Driver in the lead roles, itâ€™s set to be one of the biggest films of the year.

The story starts with his marriage to Patrizia Reggiani. They spent over a decade as frequent fixtures on the Italian social scene and enjoying the finer things in life together. The power couple also had two children.

But in 1985, they dramatically split. 10 years later, Maurizio was shot dead by a professional hitman. Reggiani was convicted of ordering his murder and was sentenced to 29 years imprisonment. She was released in 2014 and still maintains her innocence. Talk about high drama.

BUY NOW

Foe

Paul Mescal and Saoirse Ronan star in a film adaptation ofÂ Iain Reidâ€™s bestselling novel, Foe. The psychological thriller is set in a future where corporate power and environmental decay are ravaging the planet.

They playÂ Junior and Hen, a young married couple living a solitary life on their isolated farm until a mysterious stranger finds his way to their home and knocks on their door, bringing news that throws their lives into turmoil: Junior has been randomly selected to travel to a large, experimental space station orbiting Earth.

BUY NOW

The Wonder

Emma Donoghue is the author of Room, a best-selling 2010 book that became an Oscar-winning film starring Brie Larson. in 2022, she brought her 2016 novel, The Wonder, to the big screen too, with Hollywood favourite Florence Pugh playing the lead role.Â

Inspired by numerous European and North American cases of â€˜fasting girlsâ€™ between the 16-20th centuries, The Wonder follows the story of a girl who has survived without food for months.

BUY NOW

The Underground Railroad

Prepare to hear Thuso Mbeduâ€™s name everywhere from this point forwards, because we predict that after the release of Amazon Primeâ€™s highly anticipated series,Â The Underground Railroad, the breakout actor will beÂ in big demand.Â

Based on the Pulitzer Prize-winning novel by Colson Whitehead and directed by Moonlightâ€™s Barry Jenkins, The Underground Railroad chronicles Cora Randallâ€™s (Mbedu) desperate bid for freedom from a cotton plantation in the antebellum South. She escapes in pursuit of the fabled Underground Railroad, only to discover a secret, subterranean network which picks up fugitives wherever it can.

Throughout her journey, she must navigate the unique terrors for Black people in the pre-Civil War era, and evade capture at the hands of herÂ bounty hunter Ridgeway (played by Joel Edgerton), who will stop at nothing to bring her back to the plantation she escaped.

All 10 episodes of the original series landed on Amazon PrimeÂ and are still available to watch.

BUY NOW

The Pisces

Claire Foy might be best known for leading roles in excellent period dramas (Wolf Hall, The Crown) but this project is something truly different.

Foy will take the lead role in the movie adaptation of Melissa Broderâ€™sÂ The Pisces. The 2018 novel tells the story of Lucy, a PhD student in her 30s who has just broken up with her boyfriend. After trying to write her thesis on Sappho for nearly a decade, Lucy feels lost and disconnected. She agrees to dog-sit for her sister in Los Angeles for a summer, where she joins a love addiction group and goes on a string of Tinder excursions. But Lucyâ€™s outlook starts to change when she meets and falls for a merman called Theoâ€¦

Itâ€™s a darkly funny, erotic and, at times, uncomfortable story, which takes a refreshing and sharp take on what romance, fertility, ambition, identity, pleasure, boundaries and love all mean for women today.

BUY NOW

Daisy Jones & The Six

Back in 2019,Â Reese Witherspoon announced she is adapting the best-selling book, Daisy Jones & The Six.Â

The book follows the story of lead singer Daisy Jones, who is born into privilege but ignored by her selfish parents. She is a spirited and enigmatic singer/songwriter who comes of age and rises to rock superstardom against the backdrop of the LA music scene in the 1970s.

Riley Keough plays Jones in the Amazon Prime Video limited musical series, available to stream now.Â

BUY NOW

Americanah

Americanah, the award-winning book by Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie, is being turned into a mini-series byÂ Lupita Nyongâ€™o and Danai Gurira.Â

It of course follows the love story betweenÂ Ifemelu, a bright, young Nigerian woman who shows great academic promise, and an ambitious boy in her class called Obinze. The pair discuss their dreams for the future, and with Nigeria being under military rule, find themselves believing that western cultures may have more to offer.

BUY NOW

Conversations With Friends

For those who fell in love with Normal People, BBC Three alsoÂ produced Sally Rooneyâ€™s first novel, Conversations With Friends. It tells the story of two college students â€“ Frances and Bobbi â€“ living in Dublin, who form a complicated connection with an older married couple called Nick and Melissa.Â

You can expect the same dramatic, intimate and beautiful production that we were treated to with Normal People.

BUY NOW

The Pursuit Of Love

Lily James, Dominic West and Andrew Scott lead an all-star cast in a BBC adaptation of Nancy Mitfordâ€™s classic novel The Pursuit Of Love.Â Â Â

Set in Europe between the two world wars, the story follows the adventures and misadventures of the charismatic and fearless Linda Radlett, played by James, and her best friend and cousin, Fanny Logan, played by Emily Beecham.

The series premiered on BBC One and BBC iPlayer, with all three episodes are still available to stream now.

BUY NOW

Where The Crawdads Sing

Another best-seller being produced by Witherspoon, the film adaptation ofÂ Where The Crawdads SingÂ by Delia OwensÂ stars Daisy Edgar-Jones.

Owensâ€™ novel follows the story of Kya Clark from a young age, when her mother walks out on her family in search of a different life. One by one, Kyaâ€™s siblings leave home to escape their abusive father, until he himself disappears one day, leaving Kya to fend for herself in the middle of the marsh. She is forced to adapt and learn to live with her surroundings as she grows up.Â Â

BUY NOW

The Water Dancer

Oprah Winfrey and Brad Pitt are joining forces to produce best-selling novel The Water Dancer by Ta-Nehisi Coates.Â

The book follows young Hiram Walker who was born into bondage. When his mother was sold away, Hiram was robbed of all memory of her but was gifted with a mysterious power. Years later, when Hiram almost drowns in a river, that same power saves his life. This brush with death births an urgency in Hiram and a daring scheme: to escape from the only home heâ€™s ever known.

BUY NOW

Anatomy Of A Scandal

Sienna Miller leads the cast in Netflixâ€™s adaptation of Anatomy Of A Scandal by Sarah Vaughan. The plot revolves around James, a high-flying Home Office minister whose marriage to Sophie is plunged into crisis after the aide that he has an affair with, Olivia, accuses him of rape.

BUY NOW

Queenie

In 2019, Candice Carty-Williams let slip to Stylist that her best-selling modern coming-of-age novel,Â Queenie,Â was being adapted for the small screen.

Queenie is a 25-year-old Black woman working on a newspaper in London, whose life starts to unravel when she takes a break from her long-term boyfriend. She sleeps around, isolates herself and makes career-jeopardising decisions. Itâ€™s a darkly funny take on millennial life from an underrepresented perspective, and is often very, very close to the bone for its readers.

The series is being produced by Channel 4 and is expected to come out later this year.

Buy Queenie by Candice Carty-Williams from London Review Bookshop, Â£8.99

BUY NOW

Stay Close

Cush Jumbo and Sarah Parish star in a the Netflix eight-part adaptation of Harlan Cobenâ€™s thriller Stay Close,Â Â produced by Nicola Shindler and Richard Fee, the same team behind hit Netflix thriller The Stranger.

Jumbo takes on the role of Megan, a busy suburban mum whose life is torn apart after Lorraine (Parish), a friend from her past, delivers some shocking news.

BUY NOW

Exciting Times

In 2021,Â the rights to Naoise Dolanâ€™s 2020 debut, Exciting Times, were snapped up by production company Black Bear Pictures, with Bridgerton star Phoebe Dynevor set to take the lead role.

Based in Hong Kong, this sharp, witty debut explores a love triangle as newly arrived English teacher Ava finds herself torn between the different worlds offered by non-committal banker Julian and alluring lawyer Edith.Â

BUY NOW

Nine Perfect Strangers

Big Little Lies fans will love thisÂ adaptation of another Liane Moriarty book: Nine Perfect Strangers, available on Amazon Prime Video.

Set at a remote wellness resort where nine stressed-out strangers go to get on a path to a better way of living, each has their own reasons for visiting from losing weight to getting over heartbreak. Nicole Kidman andÂ Melissa McCarthy are just two of the seriesâ€™ stars.

BUY NOW

She Said

Carey Mulligan stars alongside Zoe Kazan in theÂ film based on She Said by Megan Twohey and Jodi KantorÂ (the two New York Times journalists who broke the Harvey Weinsten scandal).Â

BUY NOW

The Woman In The Window

We were gripped and slightly creeped out after watching the tense trailer for Amy Adamsâ€™ adaptation of psychological thriller The Woman In The Window.Â

Adams plays Anna, an agoraphobic psychologist who only sees the world from her window and sends people away if they arrive on her doorstep. She unexpectedly befriends her neighbour from across the road, Jane, who confides in her about her â€œcomplicatedâ€ family. But then, while looking out of her window one evening, Anna appears to see Jane being brutally attacked in her home.Â Did Jane just imagine things? Or did she really witness a murder?

Woman In The Window landed on Netflix on 14 May 2021 and it is still available to stream.

BUY NOW

Spy Princess

Freida Pinto plays war heroÂ Noor Inayat Khan in this adaptation of the war heroâ€™s biography.Â

Noor was the first female wireless operator sent to occupied France in 1943, where she was captured by the Germans and tortured. She was kept imprisoned for 10 months, never once betraying the British, before she was taken to Dachau concentration camp, where she was shot on 13 September 1944.

Pinto has described her as â€œa fierce and amazing woman, the most unlikely heroine of World War Twoâ€.

BUY NOW

Are You There God? It's Me, Margaret

Judy Blumeâ€™s coming-of-age taleÂ Are You There God? Itâ€™s Me, Margaret was first published in 1970 and it has been both challenged and celebrated for its frankness over the years. The young-adult novel tells the story of a sixth-grader who has grown up without a religious affiliation due to her parentsâ€™ interfaith marriage. Margaret is trying to balance navigating life as a teenage girl and finding her identity.Â

Starring Rachel McAdams, the adaptation is currently available to watch on Amazon Prime Video and Apple TV.

BUY NOW

Lady in the Lake

Natalie Portman and Lupita Nyongâ€™o are both set to star in a limited series adaptation of Laura Lippmanâ€™s murder-mystery novel, Lady in the Lake.Â

Apple TV+ are setting up the show that will see Portman play a 1960s Baltimore housewife and mother who becomes an investigative journalist in light of an unsolved murder. Nyongâ€™o will play Cleo Sherwood, a woman balancing multiple jobs and a family, who is committed to advancing Baltimoreâ€™s Black progressive agenda.

BUY NOW

Writers and Lovers

Lily Kingâ€™s Writers and Lovers became an instant New York Times bestseller when it was released last year and itâ€™s now being adapted for TV by Topic Studios. The novel tells the story of Casey Peabody, an aspiring writer in 1990s Boston whose world is transformed by a love affair and her motherâ€™s sudden death.

Toni ColletteÂ will direct the series in her directorial debut and she describes the novel as â€œan empowering story that speaks to me as a woman and an artistâ€. The cast and release date are yet to be announced but that leaves you with plenty of time to read the acclaimed novel.

BUY NOW

The White Tiger

Priyanka Chopra stars in the film adaptation of New York Times bestseller and 2008 Man Booker Prize-winning novel The White Tiger by Aravind Adiga.

It tells the epic and darkly humorous tale of Balram Halwai, a rickshaw driverâ€™s son who ascends from servant to self-made entrepreneur in modern India.

The movie arrived on Netflix on 22 January 2021 and it still available to stream.

BUY NOW

Black Narcissus

GemmaÂ Arterton returned to the small screen with an intriguing three-part drama adaptation of the classic 1939Â Black Narcissus by Rumer Godden.

The story of sexual repression and forbidden love takes place in 1934 on a remote clifftop palace in the Himalayas, once known as the â€˜House of Womenâ€™.Â

Black Narcissus aired on BBC One in December 2022, but you can still catch up with all three episodes on BBC iPlayer.

BUY NOW

The Dig

John Prestonâ€™s The Dig, which was published in 2008, is an account of the most famous archaeological dig in Britain in modern times â€“ the discovery of the Anglo-Saxon burial ship at Sutton Hoo, known as â€œBritainâ€™s Tutankhamunâ€.

Set against the intense backdrop of a nation on the eve of war in 1939, the story channels class tensions, love and loss through the eyes of those affected by the dig and its treasures.

Lily James and Carey Mulligan starred in Netflixâ€™s movie adaptation, which landed on the streaming platform on in 2022.

BUY NOW

Remember to check online independent booksellers and Black-owned bookstores to stock up your reading pile with. Happy reading!

Images: various publishers

item.title: The best Japandi kitchen accessories for a home refresh
item.description: From Toast to John Lewis, here are the best Japandi kitchen accessories to shop now for spring.
item.dc:creator: Shahed Ezaydi
item.content:encoded:
Spring is all about welcoming in a new season through a whole house clean, swapping the winter duvet out for a lighter one or even doing some home refreshes. And one aesthetic thatâ€™s particularly fitting for the warmer and lighter season is the JapandiÂ style.

Combining the sleek lines and clean minimalism of Japanese interior design with the warmth and cosiness of Scandinavian styles, Japandi is all about bringing simplicity and calm into the home. We know the kitchen is an area of the home that invites more chaos than most, so weâ€™ve rounded up some of the best Japandi kitchen accessories to add some calm and relaxation into the space.

H&M salt and pepper set

We love this salt and pepper set, in true Japandi style. These small stoneware bowls (each with its own serving spoon) are speckled with a reactive glaze that gives each piece a unique appearance.

Shop H&M reactive-glaze salt and pepper set, Â£14.99

item.title: 5 ways to streamline your life, avoid burnout and get off the hamster wheel, according to productivity experts
item.description: Always feel too busy? From Googleâ€™s former on-site therapist to a top time management coach, five productivity experts share their genuinely useful (and easy-to-action) advice for streamlining your life.Â
item.dc:creator: Holly Bullock
item.content:encoded:
When was the last time you stepped off your hamster wheel? You know the one â€“ it makes you feel like youâ€™re always busy but never accomplishing as much as you need to, whether thatâ€™s at work or at home (or often both). Perhaps you only everÂ take a break when you go on holiday. Maybe youâ€™re able to relax every other Sunday. But if these periods of peace are few and far between, youâ€™re not alone. According to the Mental Health Foundation, 74% of UK adults have been so stressed at some point over the last year they felt overwhelmed or unable to cope. And for women, this number rises to 81%, compared with 67% for men.

While advice for how to halt this hamster wheel is everywhere â€“ meditation, daily walks and booking annual leave are among the usual suggestions â€“ sometimes, these fixes donâ€™t quite cut through. So, we put together a panel of productivity experts to share the nuggets of advice that help them streamline their days. From the easy hack to stop meetings making you busier to the scheduling technique a time management coach swears by, hereâ€™s what they told usâ€¦Â

Get things done in your meetingsÂ

Helen Tupper is the co-founder of Squiggly Careers and author of You Do You: How To Overcome Challenges And Take Control Of Your Career.

â€œWhen Iâ€™m trying to maximise my time to make my work fit my capacity, my first port of call is to look at my meetings. Weâ€™re often going from meeting to meeting and accumulating actions in those meetings â€“ sometimes leaving them even busier than we were before we went in. To prevent me from leaving the meeting with a huge to-do list I donâ€™t have time for, Iâ€™ll often just say: â€œCan we get this sorted now?â€ The more we can do actually in the meetings, rather than carrying them over to our to-do list or subsequent meetings, the better.

â€œOne example is when someone asks everyone to have a look at their diaries once the meetingâ€™s over to see when we can all arrange another time to talk. Rather than five people going off and looking in their diaries, Iâ€™ll suggest finding a time there and then. Similarly, if someone suggests touching base with a colleague to see whether they can come to the next meeting, as thatâ€™s a two-minute job, Iâ€™ll say: â€œWhy donâ€™t you carry on this conversation, and Iâ€™ll just take two minutes to get that sorted?â€ Equally, you could arrange a 45-minute meeting (rather than an hour) to give everyone a 15-minute window for all the follow-up actions. We donâ€™t naturally leave ourselves that time, so making a conscious effort to slot it in will leave you a lot less overwhelmed.â€Â

Make an inventory of â€˜shouldsâ€™Â

Madeleine Dore is a writer specialising in routines and the author of I Didnâ€™t Do The Thing Today: On Letting Go Of Productivity Guilt.

â€œSomething I do regularly is make an inventory of my own â€˜shouldsâ€™, because I think when we have that busy feeling, itâ€™s important to check where thatâ€™s coming from. It might be the sheer volume of work, but it could be that there are some â€˜shouldsâ€™ in there. Maybe itâ€™s something you told yourself five years ago that you should do and itâ€™s since expired as a goal for you, yet youâ€™re still feeling bad about not getting to it. It could also be something thatâ€™s borrowed, that youâ€™ve observed through comparison to other people or have been told we need to do by other people, be it our parents or our peers.

Iâ€™ll do a complete brain dump of all the things Iâ€™m telling myself onto paper and then label what I need to do versus what is a â€˜shouldâ€™, and where it came from. This inventory of seeing whatâ€™s expired or whatâ€™s borrowed helps us to prioritise. Sometimes, it can feel tricky because we might be letting go of a goal weâ€™ve defined ourselves by. But itâ€™s about determining what we really want to be doing â€“ whether our days are filled more with â€˜shouldsâ€™ or with things we really want to â€“ or have to â€“ be doing.â€Â

Trigger yourself into taking brain resets

Dr Aditi Nerurkar is a Harvard doctor, stress expert and author of The Five Resets.

â€œBrain breaks arenâ€™t just nice luxuries; they have a real impact on your brainâ€™s resilience to stress and burnout. In fact, a recent study with Microsoft took brain scans of two groups; one group had no breaks during the day and the second group took short breaks throughout. They found that at the end of the day, the group that took those short breaks had decreased stress and burnout, and better cognition, attention and memory productivity. Effectively, they taking were brain resets. Studies have shown that even a 10 second break can have a benefit, and tapping into your mind-body connection is the best way to spend this reset time.

â€œI call it â€˜stop, breathe, beâ€™. Stop what youâ€™re doing, take a deep breath and ground your feet to feel centred. The best way to introduce these into your day is to set yourself triggers. For me, as a doctor, itâ€™s just before I knock on the door to introduce myself to a patient. It might be before you click â€˜join Zoomâ€™, or when youâ€™re making your lunch in the morning, or just before you leave to take your kids to school. Anxiety and overwhelm are future-focused emotions, so grounding yourself in the present is one of the most valuable 10 seconds you can give yourself.â€  

Map out your days with time blockingÂ

Sarah Stewart is a time management coach and former project manager.

â€œI encourage all my clients to give time blocking a try. In essence, itâ€™s simply about assigning specific tasks to a block and putting that block in your calendar â€“ planning ahead of time, in other words. This can be as detailed (setting out exactly what tasks youâ€™ll do in the block) or as unstructured (just theming each block) as you like, but it can be so beneficial for helping you feel more on top of things and less busy.

â€œAlthough I now use a digital calendar for mine (checking in weekly to reflect on the week just gone and plan the next), I encourage everyone new to time blocking to start on paper. At the beginning, doing it digitally can be a bit â€˜out of sight, out of mindâ€™ so Iâ€™d recommend putting your plan somewhere visible, like on your fridge. Colour coding different types of tasks (whether this is different facets of your job or coding work v leisure) can help you make sure things are balanced, and as the weeks go on, youâ€™ll feel more able to predict how much time you need for certain things. Remember: your time-blocking plan doesnâ€™t need to be set in stone; itâ€™s more of a guide that helps us feel more prepared for the week. Follow the 80/20 rule: if you can stick to it 80% of the time, thatâ€™ll make a huge difference.â€Â

Try a magic Post-it note

Ali Abdaal is a doctor, one of the worldâ€™s most-followed productivity experts and author of Feel Good Productivity: How To Do More Of What Matters To You.Â

â€œAfter watching Mary Poppins one day back when I was a junior doctor (â€œIn every job that must be done, there is an element of fun. You find the fun and snap! The jobâ€™s a game,â€ says Mary Poppins), I decided to apply the filmâ€™s philosophy to my own life. In a late-night burst of inspiration, I grabbed a Sharpie and a Post-it note and wrote nine simple words: what would this look like if it were fun? I stuck the note to my computer monitor and went to sleep.Â

â€œBy the time I spotted the note on my monitor the following day, Iâ€™d forgotten Iâ€™d put it there. Iâ€™d just got back from work and was making a start on relearning some biochemistry pathways for my medical exam. I sat down with my usual grin-and-bear-it expression. But when I saw the Post-it it got me thinking again. What would this look like if it were fun? The answer came to me immediately: if this were fun, there would be music. I realised that memorising tedious biochemistry pathways magically became a lot more interesting with the Lord Of The Rings soundtrack playing through my headphones.

â€œâ€˜What would this look like if it were fun?â€™ has now become a guiding question in my life. And itâ€™s surprisingly easy to draw upon. Think of a task that you donâ€™t want to do right now and ask what would it look like if it were fun. Could you do it in a different way? Could you add music or a sense of humour or get creative? What if you set out to do the task with friends, or promised yourself a treat at the end of the process? Is there a way to make this draining process a little more enjoyable?â€Â

item.title: Chocolate Overload: 3 Easter baking recipes to make over the long weekend
item.description: Easter is just days away, so we suggest adding these simple seasonal bakes to whatever you have planned to make the long weekend celebrations even better.
item.dc:creator: Annie Simpson
item.content:encoded:
If you work in an office, youâ€™re likely gearing up for four days off over the Easter break. With Christmas feeling like a lifetime ago, the long weekend â€“ our first bank holiday of the year â€“ is an overdue reward at the end of winter and it truly signifies the start of spring.

So, itâ€™s no surprise that weâ€™re planning to make the most of every minute of our time off. We might be losing an hour in bed with the clocks changing on Sunday, but with lighter and longer days on the horizon, itâ€™s set to be worth the wait. And the only thing that can make it any better is a celebratory seasonal bake. Luckily,Â Chocolate Overload!Â by cook and food blogger Jessie Marsden-Urquhart is here to help.Â

We all know that chocolate and Easter go hand in hand (no matter how old you are), so weâ€™re sharing three easy baking recipes that are perfect for the long weekend. From a chocolate egg-filled sharing tray bake to a solo cake for one, even if you do happen to be working over Easter, these sweet treats will make it that bit better.Â

Cracked egg chocolate cupcakes

Jessie says: â€œDecorated with an oozing chocolate egg, these cupcakes have an extra mini egg baked into the sponge and are topped with swirls of silky chocolate buttercream. Pure chocolate overload!â€

Makes 12

Ingredients

For the cupcakes

  • 12 mini filled chocolate eggs (I use Cadbury Mini Creme Eggs)
  • 180g unsalted butter, room temperature
  • 180g caster sugar
  • 2 medium eggs, room temperature
  • 150g self-raising flour
  • 30g cocoa powder

For the buttercream:

200g salted butter, room temperature

  • 350g icing sugar
  • 50g cocoa powder
  • 2 tbsp boiling water

Decoration:

  • 6 filled chocolate eggs (I use Cadbury Creme Eggs)

Method

Place the mini chocolate eggs in the freezer for at least an hour before starting the recipe.

Preheat the oven to 180Â°C/160Â°C fan and line a 12-hole cupcake tin with 12 paper cases.

Cream the butter and caster sugar together in a large bowl until light and fluffy. Beat in the eggs one at a time. Then fold in the flour and cocoa powder to make a smooth chocolate cake mixture. Fill each case with a thin layer of mixture.

Unwrap the frozen mini chocolate eggs and place one upright in the middle of each case. Spoon more mixture on top to conceal the eggs, filling each case three-quarters full.

Bake for 20â€“22 minutes until risen and springy to the touch. Leave to cool on a wire rack.

To make the buttercream, beat the butter in a bowl until soft and pale in colour. Sift in the icing sugar and beat until combined. Beat in the cocoa powder and boiling water to make a smooth and creamy chocolate buttercream.

Spread or pipe tall swirls of buttercream on top of each cupcake. Use a sharp knife to halve the full-sized chocolate eggs so you have 12 halves in total. Top each cupcake with half an egg, letting the filling ooze out onto the buttercream. Enjoy!

Hot cross mug cake

Jessie says: â€œPrep, bake and enjoy this delicious Hot Cross Mug Cake in less than five minutes! Studded with sultanas and filled with mini chocolate orange eggs, itâ€™s perfect for satisfying your sweet cravings over the Easter season.â€

Serves 1

Ingredients

  • 3 tbsp self-raising flourÂ
  • 1 tbsp light brown sugar
  • Â½ tsp ground cinnamon, plus extra for dusting
  • Â½ tsp vanilla extract
  • 1 tbsp sunflower oil
  • 2 tbsp milk
  • 10g raisins
  • 5 chocolate orange eggs (I use Terryâ€™s Chocolate Orange Mini Eggs)

Method

Stir the flour, brown sugar and ground cinnamon together in a medium-sized microwaveable mug. Mix in the vanilla extract, sunflower oil and milk until smooth. Stir in the raisins and chocolate orange eggs.

Microwave on full power for approximately 90 seconds (the cooking time may differ by 10â€“20 seconds, depending on how powerful your microwave is). The mug cake is ready when it has risen and started to pull away from the sides.

To decorate, cut two strips of kitchen paper and lay them on top of the mug cake in a cross. Dust with ground cinnamon, then carefully lift off the strips to reveal the cross. Grab a spoon and get stuck in!

Egg hunt cookie bars

Jessie says: â€œPut all your favourite chocolate mini eggs in one basket â€¦ or in the case of this recipe, a soft and gooey Egg Hunt Cookie Bar! From mixing bowl to first bite in less than an hour, thereâ€™s no excuse not to experiment and find your favourite flavour.â€

Makes 12

Ingredients

  • 150g unsalted butter
  • 100g caster sugar
  • 150g light brown sugar
  • 1 medium egg, room temperature
  • 1 medium egg yolk, room temperature
  • 1 tsp vanilla extract
  • 275g self-raising flour
  • Â½ tsp salt
  • 300g mini chocolate eggs (I use a mix of Cadbury Mini Eggs, Galaxy Golden Eggs, Milkybar Mini Eggs and Smarties Mini Eggs)

Method

Preheat the oven to 200Â°C/180Â°C fan. Then line a 20cm square baking tin with

greaseproof paper.

Place the butter in a large heatproof bowl and melt in the microwave for 30â€“60 seconds until it turns to liquid. Mix in the two sugars, the egg, egg yolk and vanilla extract until combined. Fold in the flour and salt to make a thick cookie dough. Fold 250g of the mini chocolate eggs into the dough, then press out into the baking tin. Use a rolling pin to bash the remaining eggs into pieces and scatter them over the top.

Bake for 18â€“20 minutes. The cookie bars should look golden and set on top, with a slight wobble underneath. Leave to cool in the baking tin for 30 minutes, then slice into 12 bars and serve!

Baking tip:

Cookie bars will continue to cook as they cool down, so itâ€™s best to underbake them. If in doubt, take them out!

Chocolate Overload! by Jessie Marsden-Urquhart (Pop Press, Â£12.99) is out now

Photography: Jessie Marsden-UrquhartÂ

item.title: 9 pairs of comfy low heels that are perfect for wedding season
item.description: Thanks to these low-heeled wonders you wonâ€™t have to diligently layer on the blister plasters before making for the dance floor (or wince as you walk home).
item.dc:creator: Emma Ã“ CuinneagÃ¡in
item.content:encoded:
No matter if youâ€™re warming up for wedding season, getting excited at the prospect of al fresco drinks or simply looking to elevate your everyday office outfits, this is the season to be swapping your winter boots for lighter, airier shoes. And if you want to combine comfort with a more formal fit, low-heeled finds are some of the best styles to choose from.

Luckily, as our love for trusty trainers, jeans and gym kit only seems to be growing, so too do comfortable clothing options. Spring jackets are becoming cosier, tailored trousers have morphed into more weekend-friendly fits andÂ â€“ if the increasing number of both high street and high-end options is anything to go byÂ â€“ high heels are shrinking and shorter, less ankle-harming styles are certainly trending.Â

So thereâ€™s now no need to diligently layer on the blister plasters before you make moves on the dance floor (or wince as you walk home). And to give you even more of a helping hand, weâ€™ve handpicked our nine favourite low-heeled shoe styles below â€“ sandals, pumps and Mary Janes all included.Â

M&S kitten heel slingback

Metallic shades are having quite the moment, so itâ€™s not surprising that these silver slingbacks made it to the top of our wish lists. Vegan-friendly, theyâ€™re made from a faux leather fabric. Plus, an antibacterial padding has been used on the insole, so theyâ€™re not only comfy but should also repel all unwanted smells.Â

item.title: â€œI tried buccal massage for tooth grinding and Iâ€™m now a total convert â€“ hereâ€™s why Iâ€™m recommending it to all my friendsâ€
item.description: Buccal massage may have once been the preserve of aesthetic clinics, but itâ€™s an increasinglyÂ popular way to treat tooth grinding. Stylistâ€™s Miranda Larbi has been down to My Osteo London to see what itâ€™s like to have someone elseâ€™s hands massage the inside of your mouth.Â
item.dc:creator: Miranda Larbi
item.content:encoded:
Imagine the scene: itâ€™s 8.30am on a Wednesday morning and Iâ€™m lying in a bright, lightly scented room as two gloved fingers work in the inside of my left cheek. The past 30 minutes have been spent having my jaw externally rubbed, tapped and knuckled, and now weâ€™ve gone inside. Osteopath Charlotte Mernier has her two index fingers in each corner of my mouth and is lifting what feels like a whole lot of flesh up, so that my top lip is now curled under my nose.Â

Iâ€™m having a buccal massage â€“ a treatment thatâ€™s huge on TikTok (96 million views and counting) but which until recently, Iâ€™d only heard of in relation to anti-ageing trends. These days, itâ€™s become a go-to therapy for tooth grinding â€“ something Iâ€™ve been struggling with in recent years. In fact, my nocturnal bruxism is so bad that last summer, I cracked a tooth and had to have my first crown fitted.

Up to 10% of the population lives with tooth grinding, with people aged 25-44 said to be the worst affected. The cause? Why, stress and anxiety of course.Â Weâ€™re at an age where everyone seems to be juggling careers with the next stages of life, whether thatâ€™s trying to buy a home, fork out for yet another hen do, have kids or simply try to stay afloat amid a torrent of depressing domestic and international news. No wonder weâ€™re chomping through our molars every night.Â

I didnâ€™t know that I ground my teeth until that tooth cracked, but the signs had been there for years. The sides of my mouth are often lined from chewing and I get headaches semi-frequently. More recently, Iâ€™ve been hearing a whooshing sound â€“ like blood rushing around my eardrum â€“ that I often try to down out with the radio.

Aside from flattened tooth edges and cracks, the main symptom dentists often mention is jaw tightness. You might know someone whose jaw clicks when they chew or you might find that your jaw starts to ache when you laugh â€“ those are obvious signs. But it wasnâ€™t until my face was being pummelled by Mernierâ€™s expert fingers that I realised just how ridiculously tight my own jaw is.Â

What happens in a buccal massage?

From TikTok, you might think that the whole session is spent with someoneâ€™s hands in your mouth. In reality, the intraoral part only lasts a few minutes and serves to stretch and massage harder-to-reach areas of the face. The majority of the massage is external.

Mernier starts by pushing down my shoulders, gently rotating my head and giving my neck a deep rub. Then, she moves up to massage my whole face in long sweeping movements before getting to work on the jaw. Thereâ€™s rubbing, kneading, pulling, rocking, tapping â€“ every kind of stroke and touch possible. And after about 20 minutes, she hits a spot just under my right ear on the very top of my jaw which is incredibly sensitive. She stays on it, pressing and rubbing, and after a while, it feels like something moves. Itâ€™s then that I realise the blood rushing I keep hearing is linked to my jaw because, suddenly, my right ear feels a lot clearer.Â

Mernier tells me that tinnitus is a common issue among teeth grinders; those phantom sounds are caused by our bone structures responding to all that grinding and clenching, and the more you clench, the more ringing youâ€™ll hear.

We finish with the internal massage, for which Mernier gloves up. Itâ€™s not uncomfortable at all and, unlike a dental appointment, you can swallow as normal. She doesnâ€™t go far into my mouth (itâ€™s not a whole hand situation) and you donâ€™t have to move at all. In fact, it feels pretty good to have someone move around your lips and cheek flesh.

Does buccal massage work?

After 60 minutes (which passes all too quickly), I get up, start talking and find that my face feels noticeably lighter. It feels like a weight has been lifted from somewhere and itâ€™s easier to open my mouth.

They say that your teeth shouldnâ€™t spend more than 20 minutes a day touching, but many of us simply arenâ€™t aware when weâ€™re clenching. I know Iâ€™m tense when typing on my laptop or cycling, but not conscious enough to do anything about it at the time. Leaving the clinic on Wimpole Street, I notice that my tongue is naturally resting on the roof of my mouth (the correct position) and that my molars are set comfortably apart.

Mernier sends me on my way with a few pieces of advice. One is not to rely on my retainer to break the habit: â€œPeople often still clench wearing their retainer as itâ€™s natural to bite down when thereâ€™s something there,â€ she says. Instead of wearing my retainer when working from home, she recommends trying to be more conscious about when I clench and grind during the day, making an active effort to retract the shoulders, take calming breaths and notice where my teeth and tongue are.

Given how incredible the treatment feels at the time and how instant the results are after, Iâ€™ve got to say that this is one of the best treatments Iâ€™ve ever had. Iâ€™ve already told three fellow retainer-wearers about it and Iâ€™m already looking to see when I might be able to go back for round two.

In the meantime, Iâ€™ve learned a few massage techniques that Iâ€™ll be doing on my jaw a couple of times a week.

Buccal massage at My Osteo LondonÂ costs Â£165 for 60 minutes.

Images: authorâ€™s own

item.title: â€œWhy do my joints ache just before my period?â€ A womenâ€™s health GP explains all
item.description: A womenâ€™s health GP explains the impact monthly hormonal fluctuations can have on our joint health.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Geall
item.content:encoded:
Welcome back to Just Curious, Strong Womenâ€™s weekly series exploring all the random health and fitness questions youâ€™ve always wondered about but never got the answer to.

This week, weâ€™re exploring why so many women seem to experience joint pain in the days leading up to their period.

Navigating the week leading up to your period can be a bit of a rollercoaster. Whether you experience bloating, fatigue, headaches, anxiety or a combination of them all, the pre-menstrual period can leave you looking forward to the moment you start to bleed.

But mood swings, hormonal breakouts and all those other typical PMS symptomsÂ arenâ€™t the only ones that can crop up. Joint pain, while seemingly unrelated, is something many women go through in the week leading up to and during their period â€“ and itâ€™s all to do with the hormonal fluctuations and chemical changes that go on in our bodies during that time.Â

The same can also occur during menopause due to similar hormonal fluctuations. However, the longer-term nature of these changes mean that any potential niggles can become more serious, so understanding where they come from and how to deal with them is important.

With all that in mind, we asked Dr Samantha Wild, a GP and clinical lead for womenâ€™s health at Bupa Health Clinics, to tell us more about the link between hormones and joint pain.Â

How are our joints and sex hormones linked?Â

Both oestrogen and progesterone can impact how our joints feel and function, but itâ€™s oestrogen which experts believe is the prime culprit here.

â€œSex hormones like oestrogen play a large role in regulating and maintaining bone health,â€ Dr Wild explains. â€œOestrogen helps to protect your bones and joints by reducing inflammation and friction between them.â€

There are many ways that oestrogen does this â€“ it can affect your cartilage, also known as the connective tissue in your joints, as well as affect tendon and ligament elasticity. Oestrogen also has an anti-inflammatory effect, so itâ€™s great for reducing pre-existing inflammation in the joints.

Progesterone, which falls towards the very end of the luteal phase (ie the last couple of days before your period) also has a muscle-relaxing effect, so low levels of the hormone can make muscles tight and sore, potentially contributing to joint pain.Â

Why do some people experience joint pain before their period?Â

Levels of oestrogen and progesterone both decrease before our period â€“ and this could explain why some people experience joint soreness at this time.

But the fall in these hormones can also have other effects, Dr Wild explains: â€œStudies shown that low oestrogen can increase your perception of pain.â€

In short, you might be more sensitive to pain in that week before your period, so any small niggles might seem a lot more serious and disruptive.Â Â

Molecular compounds known as prostaglandins â€“ which are what cause the muscle and blood vessels of the uterus to contract to shed its lining â€“ could also play a role, Dr Wild adds: â€œWhen you start your period, prostaglandins are released â€“ and these molecular compounds are believed to be a trigger of joint and muscle pain.â€Â

Why do some people experience joint pain during menopause?Â

The fall in oestrogen which occurs during menopause means many of the joint-related symptoms of PMS are mirrored, but the longer-lasting absence of oestrogen means symptoms can be more severe or lead to bigger issues.

â€œAs oestrogen levels naturally fall in perimenopause, your joints may swell and become painful,â€ Dr Wild says. â€œSore joints are a frequent first symptom for those going through perimenopause.â€

The decrease in oestrogen during menopause has also been linked to an increased risk of osteoarthritis, perhaps due to the impact the hormone can have on cartilage.Â

Can these changes put us at increased risk of injury?Â

As with many womenâ€™s health issues, research into the role hormonal fluctuations play in the risk of injury is limited. But Dr Wild says that there is some evidence that fluctuations throughout the menstrual cycle could influence injury risk.

â€œSome studies indicate that muscle and tendon injuries are almost twice as likely to happen two weeks after your period (around the time of ovulation),â€ she says. â€œInjury has also been linked with the days around the time of your period starting.â€Â

How to reduce hormone-related joint painÂ

Even if youâ€™re experiencing pain on a monthly basis, you can take steps to relieve some of the discomfort.

In the short term, making sure youâ€™re getting enough sleep, taking part in some light exercise â€“ such as yoga or aerobics â€“ and taking over the counter painkillers and anti-inflammatories should take the edge off things.

And in the long run, taking steps to support your bone and joint health can help to dampen the discomfort you experience or get rid of it altogether.

Below are just some of the steps Dr Wild recommends:

1. Keep active

â€œExercise can help to care for both your physical and mental health, along with improving your joint flexibility and offering pain relief,â€ she explains. â€œSwimming, walking, pilates and yoga can offer good options to help keep you strong.â€

Strength training is particularly beneficial for improving the stability of your joints, she adds. â€œAt least twice a week you should make time for strengthening activities. You donâ€™t need to join the gym or start lifting weights if you donâ€™t want to â€“ taking the stairs instead of the lift, carrying shopping and dancing all count as strengthening exercises.â€

Dr Wild continues: â€œControlled stretching can also be a good option if your joints are feeling sore. Just make sure to keep it gentle and build up slowly.â€

2. Seek expert advice

If your joint pain is getting in the way of your ability to function, there are experts who can help. A physiotherapist can target aches and pains and give you exercises to do at home to strengthen your joints, while your GP can provide pain relief and advise on next steps.

This is especially important during menopause, as hormone replacement therapy (HRT) can be prescribed to help relieve joint pain and stiffness.

3. Eat a bone-strengthening diet

Eating a diet thatâ€™s rich in joint-friendly nutrients will ensure your joint health is supported throughout the menstrual cycle.

â€œA diet rich in calcium, vitamin D and omega 3 fatty acids will help to support your bones and joints, along with helping manage other menopause symptoms like hot flushes and low mood,â€ Dr Wild explains.Â

Images: Getty

item.title: Endometriosis is a â€˜nutrient hungryâ€™ condition â€“ hereâ€™s how to make sure youâ€™re getting everything you need
item.description: Food can be a powerful tool in endometriosis managementÂ â€“ hereâ€™s how to maximise the benefits.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Geall
item.content:encoded:
Food has long been used to help treat, prevent and stave off disease, and for good reason. It may not be the magic cure weâ€™d all like it to be, but diet truly can make a difference in the management of all sorts of conditions â€“ even those that have relatively little to do with the digestive system.

Endometriosis is a prime example. While following a specific diet may not take away the pain of lesions and growths, some foods and nutrients have been shown to reduce the impact of the condition on the body and support general wellbeing.

On the other hand, certain foods have been shown to amplify certain symptoms. This means diet can play a role in the severity of flare-ups, including those caused by the conditionâ€™s co-morbidities.

Below, we explore exactly what that means â€“ including the foods and nutrients to seek out when building an endometriosis-friendly diet.Â

Why is diet important for those with endometriosis?Â

â€œEndometriosis is a â€˜nutrient hungryâ€™ condition,â€ explains Lorna Driver-Davies, head of nutrition at the supplement brand Wild Nutrition. â€œThe biological and physiological drain the body is placed under to manage the effect of the lesions means many of those with endometriosis have been shown to have low nutrient status.â€

In particular, research has shown that women with endometriosis tend to have depleted levels of vitamin D, zinc, vitamin A and vitamin B12. Low levels of iron and magnesium are also common â€“ the former due to the excess levels of bleeding the condition can cause, and the latter due to the stress it exerts on the body.

Eating well can also support women with endometriosis to recover better from surgical interventions, and help with both direct and indirect symptoms, such as fatigue, sleep issues and migraines. Conditions such as IBS, rheumatoid arthritis and lupus â€“ all of which women with endometriosis have been shown to be at higher risk of developing â€“ can also be supported, in part, through dietary interventions.Â Â

How to eat well with endometriosisÂ

Targeting specific foods and nutrients is key to building an endometriosis-friendly diet, Driver-Davies explains. Her recommendations include:

1. Get plenty of omega 3 fatty acids

Endometriosis is a condition characterised by inflammation, which means optimising the number of anti-inflammatory nutrients in your diet should be the goal.

Omega 3 is a key one to target, Driver-Davies says. â€œOmega 3 is an anti-inflammatory and research shows a diet rich in omega 3 can reduce the development and progression of endometriosis and help with symptoms,â€ she explains.Â

â€œItâ€™s very common for endometriosis sufferers in the UK to be low in omega 3 because Brits donâ€™t love eating fish as much in comparison to Europeans, but itâ€™s important.â€Â

While omega 3 supplements are widely available, most people should be able to get all the omega 3 you need from your diet alone. Key sources of omega 3 include oily fish (such as mackerel, herring, sardines and salmon) as well as nuts and seeds (such as flaxseed, chia seed and walnuts).Â Â

2. Take inspiration from the Mediterranean diet

The Mediterranean diet is famed for its anti-inflammatory properties, so it can have a positive effect on the inflammation associated with endometriosis.

â€œI am a big fan of the strong science behind this diet,â€ Driver-Davies says. â€œIts benefits for people with endometriosis make sense since its approach is anti-inflammatory, encouraging healthy fat intake, whole foods and plenty of colourful fruit and vegetables. Other research on fruit and vegetable intake has also been found to benefit endometriosis, such as increased antioxidant support.â€

The Mediterranean diet is wide and varied, so itâ€™s easy to keep things interesting. You just want to make sure youâ€™re getting lots of fruit and vegetables as well as whole grains and healthy fats.Â

3. Up your fibre intake

A high-fibre diet isnâ€™t just good for improving your gut health â€“ it can also relieve symptoms of endometriosis, Driver-Davies explains. The two benefits are linked because of the role our gut plays in regulating our oestrogen levels, high levels of which can exacerbate endometriosis symptoms such as cramping and pain.

This is all because of something called the estrobolome â€“ a specific group of bacteria within the gut microbiome responsible for producing the enzyme that helps our body to regulate oestrogen. When the estrobolome is functioning well, this enzyme helps to stop excess levels of oestrogen being absorbed into the bloodstream, instead ensuring it passes through as waste.

Increased fibre intake can positively impact this process by feeding the bacteria, ensuring they stay happy and healthy. But thatâ€™s not all.

â€œFibre helps to keep bowel movements regular, which helps to make sure oestrogen is removed and does not build up,â€ Driver-Davies says. â€œIt also helps to feed the gut microbiome required for a healthy immune system.â€Â

This is important because the immune system has been shown to play a role in the development of endometriosis, so taking steps to support immune health may make a difference to the severity of symptoms. Enhancing the health of the gut microbiome can also help

It is worth noting that one study found that cruciferous vegetables such as brussels sprouts and cabbage could slightly increase someoneâ€™s risk of developing endometriosis, despite these plants being high in fibre and containing a compound which can aid oestrogen metabolism. However, more research is needed to decipher whether this link is of legitimate concern.Â

Images: Getty

item.title: Lunges are an effective lower body exercise â€“ but are they as good as squats?
item.description: Lunges are a great lower body exercise, but are they really as good as squats?Â
item.dc:creator: Chloe Gray
item.content:encoded:
Squats are arguably the OG of leg exercises. Theyâ€™re probably the most commonly performed movements in the gym, and we bet youâ€™d struggle to find a strength training programme that doesnâ€™t have a type of squat in it.

However, on Strong Women, weâ€™ve previously spoken about the fact that squats donâ€™t come naturally to everyone â€“ and not all of us are designed to squat with big barbells thanks to differences in ankle, knee and hip mobility.

If youâ€™re looking for another lower body exercise to sub in for squats, lunges could be the best bet. They donâ€™t get quite the same hype as the squat, but they are a classic compound move. So, are they as effective at working those vital lower body muscles?

The difference between squats and lunges

With so many different ways to perform each of the movements (with kettlebells or barbells, walking lunges or reverse lunges, sumo squat or pause squat), comparing the two can get a little confusing. But if we take a basic squat and a basic lunge, with or without any type of resistance, â€œthey are very similar movements,â€ says Elouise Millard, head coach at F45 Stratford.

Both involve bending your knees to lower your hips down to the ground. In the squat, youâ€™ll have your feet both planted on the ground mirroring each other, but lunges are performed while moving one foot in front of or behind the other, into a â€˜splitâ€™ position. That changes the outcome of the movement.Â

You can squat heavier weights but lunges require more functional fitness

â€œLunges are great for building unilateral strength and core stability and improving your balance,â€ says Millard. These are all functional skills that serve a purpose in every day life beyond the gym.

Unilateral work helps us to be stable and strong on either side of our body. Thatâ€™s especially important given that we donâ€™t often pick things up off the floor with perfectly aligned feet.

The staggered stance of lunges mimics the movement of walking and running, building strength in the pattern we need every day. â€œReverse lunges are particularly good for this,â€ trainer Emma Obayuvana has previously told Strong Women. â€œThe movementâ€¦ mimics the direct body mechanics and muscles as running as you drive that reverse leg back up to standing.â€

Lunges require more balance and stability than squats

â€œLunges are more challenging on the body than the squat due to the increased amount of balance and coordination needed to perform the move,â€ says Millard. â€œFor that reason, beginners might want to start with squats before progressing to the lunge.â€

A 2020 paper published in the Journal of Sport Rehabilitation showed that total muscle activation was higher in a lunge than in a squat â€“ suggesting that the lunge makes more of your muscles work harder. But because of the weight distribution, itâ€™s usually easier and safer to lift heavier when squatting, rather than lunging.

You need both lunges and squats in your routine

Donâ€™t go thinking that the only way to build serious strength is through squatting. In a 2015 study, researchers found that there wasnâ€™t any noteworthy difference between the squat and lunge on their measures of lower body power. â€œOne of the most peculiar findings in the study was that the lunge group actually improved more than the squat group on their 1RM squat (22.6% and 7.2%, respectively) and the squat group improved more than the lunge group on their 1RM lunge (22.1% and 13.6%, respectively),â€ the researchers wrote.

For that reason, â€œboth squats and lunges can have a place in your training programme,â€ says Millard. While opting for the move you prefer or that best suits your goals is important, squats and lunges clearly complement each other and together can work on building well-rounded strength and power. Rather than it being a question of either-or, why not find a place for both? 

Images: Getty

item.title: Hip pain when running? You may need to strengthen your iliacus muscle
item.description: Do your hips seize up every time you go for a jog? Hereâ€™s how strengthening a tiny muscle called the iliacus could make all the difference.
item.dc:creator: Meg Walters
item.content:encoded:
Running certainly isnâ€™t for the faint of heart. While the post-workout endorphins make it worth it, thereâ€™s no denying that it can leave you with throbbing calves and aching hamstrings. One of the most common running complaints, though, is pain and tightness in the hips.

Mild hip soreness is normal after a long run (because youâ€™ve just been using the muscle to power your legs). But if you start to experience frequent pain in the hips and pelvis that makes putting one foot in front of the other feel like an impossible task, you may be dealing with irritation or weakness of the iliacus.

What is the iliacus?

â€œThe iliacus?â€ you might be thinking. â€œNever heard of it.â€Â

You probably have, but maybe not by that name. The iliacus is a key part of the larger and better-known hip flexor (the other main muscle being the psoas). Together, the iliacus and the psoas make up the hip muscle group that connects the spine with the inner hip. Essentially, it is these two muscles that kick into gear when you lift your leg. Â

As PT Lucy Arnold puts it: â€œThe iliacus is a muscle covering the surface of the pelvic bone, ranging through the hip and groin area.â€

â€œSet within the hip region, the iliacus muscle contributes a lot to general function,â€ adds physiotherapist Miriam Daurat from Our Health Hub. â€œItâ€™s involved in walking and supporting posture to working with the psoas major muscle to create powerful hip and trunk flexion. These movements allow us to bend down to tie laces and pick things up â€“ as well as perform exercises like sit-ups and crunches.â€

Can your iliacus cause hip pain while running?Â

According to a 2011 survey, roughly 10% of runners experience hip pain at least once a year. The difficulty is that itâ€™s hard to pinpoint which muscle in the hip area is causing your pain. 

So how do you know if itâ€™s the iliacus that is contributing to poor hip mobility and running pain?

â€œSymptoms of an irritated iliacus can include stiffness while running, decreased mobility and flexibility in hip flexors at the front of the thigh, as well as muscle tenderness,â€ Arnold says.  

Daurat explains that exercise can easily cause irritation in the iliacus. â€œParticularly in running, these small muscles can be overused to the point of injury,â€ she says. â€œThe acceleration and deceleration in running, coupled with the forces travelling through the hips and legs, cause the tendon that attaches the iliopsoas to the femur to become irritated and inflamed.â€

Itâ€™s not just the running that causes pain, either. The ilacus has to contend with a whole day sat down, too. â€œRegular time spent sitting for prolonged periods can cause the muscle to shorten,â€ says Daurat. â€œReduced flexibility and weakness in the iliacus can result in hip stiffness and pain associated with muscle tightness.â€ A shortened iliacus can also result from skipping out on stretching after strength training or, you guessed it, running.

How to strengthen (and lengthen) your iliacus

Itâ€™s important to keep the muscle both strong and supple â€“ especially if youâ€™re working on completing a running goal. Over time, tightness in the iliacus can lead to an â€˜anterior pelvic tiltâ€™,Â Daurat says. Thatâ€™s when the pelvis is tilted forwards, creating an arch in the back. â€œImagine the pelvis as a bucket of water â€“ an anterior pelvic tilt would be as if the bucket was angled to tip water out of the front,â€ she says.Â

If tightness in the iliacus causes this tilt, you may begin to experience back pain in the long term too. Here are some tips to help strengthen and lengthen your iliacus and banish hip tightness for good:

Get up and move

â€œMaking a point to break up episodes of prolonged sitting can go a long way to decrease the likelihood of muscles becoming shortened and irritating during a run,â€ suggests Daurat. â€œAfter 30 minutes of sitting it is important to stand up and move around for a few minutes.â€

Stretch after a run

Stretch, stretch, stretch. Before and after a run, try incorporating stretches like lunges and bridges into your routine. â€œWhile it is important to make sure the iliacus and other muscles are strong, it is vitally important to promote good flexibility to reduce the risk of injury and pain,â€ Daurat says.

â€œMany simple stretches can be done in the comfort of your home, including hanging leg and knee to chest stretches,â€ says Arnold. â€œBut,â€ she adds, â€œalways consult a professional before doing any intensive stretching to prevent further injury.â€

Images: Getty

item.title: A quarter of women have been shamed or pressured to return to work early when taking time off for health issues
item.description: Flexible working still isnâ€™t enough: women are being shamed into returning to work after health issues, according to new research.Â
item.dc:creator: Amy Beecham
item.content:encoded:
It goes without saying: no one should have to choose between their job and their wellbeing. Yet a quarter of women working in UK offices say they have been shamed or pressured to return to work early when taking time off for health issues, new research by the womenâ€™s health startup frendo has found.

Despite the government urging employers to do more to keep workers healthy and the growing prevalence of workplace conversations about staff health, stigma around female health conditions remains,

As a result, over a quarter (28%) of women say their company culture is not open when it comes to discussing health conditions and 27% say their employer is not very willing to make allowances for wellbeing issues.

And the impact isnâ€™t just physical. One in seven women (14%) say they have experienced discrimination in the workplace due to their health, such as being overlooked for promotions or excluded from team activities. Two in five of those who had been discriminated against (42%) did not vocalise their concerns to the staff who were placing them at a disadvantage, and the same proportion did not tell their HR department.Â

Itâ€™s no surprise, then, that Headspaceâ€™s sixth annual Workforce State of Mind report also revealed this week that 77% of workers in the UK say stress has poorly impacted their physical health. Once again, the effects extend far beyond physical health, as 71% claim that work stress caused a personal relationship to end, with Gen X employees more likely (79%) than any other generation to report that work stress has led to a breakup or divorce. This strain is filtering its way into family dynamics too, with over a third of workers (40%) stating that work stress has impacted their childrenâ€™s mental health or their ability to care for their family.

These figures are just the latest in a slew of concerning research into how our jobs are really impacting our wellbeing. Only last month, a worrying report suggested that over a third of young people experience mental illness, adding that 5% are currently signed off work for mental health reasons. Clearly, even with many companies moving towards more flexible working arrangements, still more needs to be done to allow women to prioritise their health â€“ something that should be a given, not an exception.Â

Images: Getty

item.title: Brace yourself: these 2010s hairstyles could be about to become trendy again
item.description: In the hair and beauty world, what goes around very much comes back around â€“ just look at the Y2K and 00s revival weâ€™re currently living through. And what came after the 00s? Thatâ€™s rightÂ â€“ the 2010s.Â Â
item.dc:creator: Aidan Milan
item.content:encoded:
Time really is a flat circle when it comes to trends. And with the trend cycle tending to move in increments of roughly 20 years, we might not be far away from another decade-obsession vibe-shift. After all, much as it might pain us to admit it, 2030 isnâ€™t actually that far away.

TheÂ side parting is already back, lest we forget, and that got us thinking about all the hair trends we used to obsess over in those heady dip dye days.Â

Hairstylist, colourist and curl-and-coil expert Nicola Harrowell tells Stylist: â€œItâ€™s interesting to be around for trends the second time around. I remember my mother telling me, â€˜I used to dress just like you when I was youngerâ€™, and thinking that was absurd!â€

When asked what 2010s hair trends she thinks could be looming in our future, she had this to sayâ€¦

Sidecuts and undercuts

So many cool girls reached for the clippers during the 10s to flirt with a buzz cutÂ â€“ albeit without leaving all their locks on the bathroom floor.

Harrowell, whoâ€™s represented by Premier Hair & Makeup, says: â€œI think the undercut could make a comeback as things get more grungy after this Y2K phase passes. I love an undercut, and hopefully weâ€™ll see some new angles and placements this time.â€

Bold dip-dye

Balayage and ombre highlights never really fell out of style, but the brightly coloured, high-contrast hairdos of the 2010s had a very specific vibe.

Harrowell says: â€œFun colours have come a long way, with brands like Curlsmith doing great wash-off shades. So Iâ€™m hoping, if dip-dye comes back, that it will be done with a lot less damage this time around.â€

The bright bob

Was the bob, a cut weâ€™re already obsessed with in 2024, just a 2010s trend? No, it was not. However, there were some notable crops on the likes of Hayley Williams and Rihanna in the early 10s that made a very specific, colourful statement.

â€œBobs are making a statement ahead of summer,â€ says Harrowell, adding that she suspects theyâ€™ll start to become â€œsuper-sharp and structuredâ€.

Thinking beyond the trendsâ€¦

But Harrowell also points out that, even though we might look to the past for inspiration, what people really want these days are looks that work for their unique hair types and curl patterns.

She explains: â€œI think people are also coming to terms with working out what might be best for them within the trends, instead of solely what is in fashion. The curly people are curly and the straight people are slick and structured, which always looks better to me as it feels natural.â€
