item.title: â€œShut up, Anne Hathawayâ€: How Anne Hathaway outsmarted the Hathahaters and had the last laugh
item.description: As Anne Hathaway once again addresses the extreme public loathing she endured more than a decade ago, Christobel Hastings re-examines the rise and fall of Hathahate â€“ and how one of Hollywoodâ€™s biggest movie stars outsmarted the sexist script.
item.dc:creator: Christobel Hastings
item.content:encoded:
It was February 2013, and at the 85th Academy Awards ceremony, Anne Hathaway had just scooped the Oscar for Best Supporting Actress. The win, by all accounts, was no great surprise: throughout the awards season that year, the actor had racked up trophies at the Golden Globes, SAG Awards and Baftas for her compelling portrayal of the doomed Fantine in the big screen adaptation of Les MisÃ©rables. Standing on stage at the most prestigious film awards in the world, Hathaway was about to experience a moment most actors dream of. Hollywoodâ€™s biggest night belonged to her.

Except when Hathaway took the mic to deliver her acceptance speech, everything unravelled. As she cradled her golden statue and whispered, â€œIt came true!â€, the internet unleashed a tidal wave of vitriol. People mocked the darts on her powder pink Prada gown; her doe eyes and too-perfect mouth; her awed, overeager voice. Then there was the speech itself, which was branded rehearsed, calculated and disingenuous. There was no doubt about it: the Oscar-night darling was now public enemy number one.Â

After the 2013 awards season, the hatred heaped upon the actor became a big topic of conversation. Alongside the everyday cyberbullying, an abundance of think pieces attempted to compile evidence of Hathawayâ€™s most annoying qualities, from her earnest demeanour to her joyful exuberance. â€œSheâ€™s got this theatre kid thing where she adopts the mood of every situation sheâ€™s in [â€¦] but wildly overcompensates every time,â€ said critic Richard Lawson.Â â€œShe always seems like sheâ€™s performing, and her favourite act is this overstated humility and graciousness.â€ In a bizarre scientific analysis, psychology professorÂ Terry Pettijohn argued that Hathawayâ€™s â€œmature faceâ€ was more suited to a challenging climate. â€œWhen times are good we prefer actresses with rounder faces,â€ he explained.Â So zealous was the public loathing that a new wordÂ â€“ HathahateÂ â€“ was created just to describe the movement.

But while the discourse raged with revulsion, it also became clear that few could really pinpoint exactly how and why Hathahate had come to pass. After all, it hadnâ€™t always been this way. When Hathaway burst onto the scene in 2001 with a star-making debut in The Princess Diaries, the fanbase was positively adoring. Then came her graduation with Brokeback Mountain in 2005 and The Devil Wears Prada the following year, which secured her leading lady status. A few years later, Rachel Getting Married was heralded by the critics as her definitive coming-of-age moment, even scoring Hathaway her first Oscar nomination. Loved by the public and the box office alike, it seemed Hathaway could do no wrong.

As the noughties drew to a close, however, the tide was beginning to turn. Interestingly, Hathawayâ€™s first public misstep had nothing to do with her acting ability or movie roles, rather an ill-fated hosting gig at the Oscars in 2011 alongside James Franco. Despite Hathaway singing, dancing and changing outfits eight times that night in a bid to entertain, the critics were scathing. â€œIn what could go down as one of the worst Oscar telecasts in history, a bad and risky idea â€“ letting two actors host â€“ played out in spectacularly unwatchable fashion on the biggest of all nights for the film world,â€ wroteÂ Tim Goodman in The Hollywood Reporter, while LA Weekly branded the gigÂ â€œthe most embarrassing Academy Awards everâ€.

Hathawayâ€™s first public misstep had nothing to do with her acting ability

Hathaway, for her part, tried to take the experience in her stride, admitting that her hosting had been â€œslightly manic and â€˜hyper-cheerleaderyâ€™ onscreenâ€. Franco, meanwhile, made no explanations for his performance, and even added fuel to the fire when he claimed that Hathaway was at least partially responsible for his criticism. â€œAnne Hathaway is so energetic, I think the Tasmanian Devil would look stoned standing next to Anne Hathaway,â€ he told late-night host David Letterman in March 2011. Steadily, derision grew. In a now infamous diatribe against the actor in 2012, Alexis Rhiannon summed up all the hate against Hathaway on Crushable. â€œMy my, what a large beautiful mouth. I donâ€™t like it. Look at those dark beautiful eyes. I donâ€™t like them. Listen to her skinny beautiful words. I donâ€™t like them. Shut up. Shut up, Anne Hathaway.â€ That December, as hype grew around her performance in Les MisÃ©rables, the Hathahatred was about to erupt.

The spark that lit the fuse emerged during the 2013 awards circuit. Come the Golden Globes at the beginning of the year, the Hathahaters found fresh ammunition when the actor accepted the award for Best Supporting Actress for Les MisÃ©rables with the words: â€œThank you for this lovely blunt object that I will forevermore use as a weapon against self-doubt.â€ Like clockwork, she was roundly accused of being too emotional, too saccharine, too contrived, too pretentious. Later that night, she was accused of of putting on â€œThe Anne Showâ€ after taking the microphone when Les MisÃ©rables won Best Musical or Comedy to thank people she forgot to mention in her acceptance speech earlier in the night.

Hathawayâ€™s win at the Screen Actors Guild Awards later that month also fed into the theory that her speeches were unforgivably annoying. While accepting her award for Best Supporting Actress, Hathaway was branded bizarre and inauthentic when she quipped about being thankful for having dental insurance, unlike her destitute character Fantine in Les MisÃ©rables, who resorts to selling her teeth for money. â€œLet me sum up why people hate Anne Hathaway,â€ said radio host Howard Stern after Hathaway won her award. â€œFirst of all she gets a speechwriter to write her speech. Sheâ€™s overly dramatic at these award shows. Sheâ€™s always out of breath. Sheâ€™s even acting when sheâ€™s winning an award.â€

By the time the disastrous Oscars ceremony arrived just a few weeks later, Hathahatred reached its zenith. Despite winning the most prestigious award within the international film industry, Hathaway unleashed a new wave of loathing when she referenced the iconic song I Dreamed A Dream in her acceptance speech. For the first time, her career started to falter. â€œI had directors say to me, â€˜I think youâ€™re great. Youâ€™re perfect for this role, but I donâ€™t know how audiences will accept you because of all this stuff, this baggage,â€™â€ she told Harperâ€™s Bazaar in 2014. There was the emotional impact, too. In that same interview, she described how discovering the intense internet hatred after the Oscars felt like being â€œpunched in the gutâ€.Â

Was Hathaway ever really so unlikeable? Of course not.

Was Hathaway ever really so unlikeable? Of course not. For despite her catalogue of crimes, Hathahate was, ironically, never specifically about Anne Hathaway. Nowadays, as we reflect upon how the pervasive misogyny of the 2000s wronged so many of our female pop culture icons, itâ€™s clear that Hathaway was simply the victim of a long-held tradition; one in which a talented, beautiful, famous woman is used as a punching bag. Indeed, a Buzzfeed article titled â€˜Why Do People Hate Anne Hathaway?â€™ appeared to unwittingly hit upon this when it highlighted, among many other scathing insights, that â€œmore often than not, thereâ€™s no real reasonâ€ for hating Anne Hathaway. The sentiment was echoed in a New York Times piece titled â€˜Do We Really Hate Anne Hathaway?â€™. â€œItâ€™s not really Anne Hathaway I â€˜hateâ€™,â€ said writer Sarah Nicole Prickett, who is quoted in the piece. â€œItâ€™s all the lesser, real-life Anne Hathaways I have known â€“ princessy, theatre-schooled girls who have no game and no sex appeal and eat raisins for dessert.â€

But our story is far from over. In the wake of the Oscars furore, Hathaway disappeared from the spotlight. One might assume that she was too bruised to withstand any more mockery, but it seems that her retreat was a deliberate strategy to allow the pile-on to lose momentum and pivot elsewhere. We know this because Hathaway herself hinted that she was purposefully staying out of the public eye. When asked the reason for her absence in 2013 by the Huffington Post at the Sundance Film Festival, she joked, rather brilliantly: â€œMy impression is that people needed a break from me.â€ In other words, she was playing the game and waiting for public approval to come full circle.Â

As much as staying under the radar was a smart move, Hathawayâ€™s re-emergence was genius. After taking a year out, she resurfaced in 2014 with a humdinger of a movie by way of Christopher Nolanâ€™s Interstellar, swiftly followed by earnest musical romance Song One, two roles which showed once more that she had serious range. She styled out talk show interviews with humour and honesty, joking about how her Oscars dress made her nipples look â€œerectâ€ on The Tonight Show and rapping about the Hathahaters during her next appearance. And she proved that she was bigger than the cyberbullies. â€œThis whole thing has made me a way more compassionate and loving person,â€ she told Harperâ€™s Bazaar in a triumphant interview. â€œAnd I donâ€™t feel sorry for myself.â€

By 2017, a flurry of think pieces about Hathaway returned to the media. But this time around, the pendulum had swung back in her favour. â€˜You Are Wrong And Also Dumb If You Hate Anne Hathaway,â€™ read one headline from Observer. â€˜Itâ€™s Not Cool To Hate Anne Hathaway Anymore,â€™ declared Vulture. When 2018 rolled around, Hathawayâ€™s star turn as Hollywood It girl Daphne Kluger in Oceanâ€™s 8 was hailed a resounding success. â€œFor a few years there, Hathawayâ€™s presence in Hollywood was attached to the narrative that she was trying too hard to be likeable, that she was embarrassing herself by showing her work,â€ wrote Jia Tolentino in The New Yorker. â€œThis performance is a statement â€“ Hathaway understands the game sheâ€™s playing â€“ and a heist in itself. She runs away with the show.â€

More than a decade on from the age of peak Hathahate, the era when Hathaway was defined by public loathing now seems like a distant footnote. And yet, her story feels eerily relatable. A woman destined for the greatest heights of success, who instead found herself picked apart for her appearance, personality and talent: every woman is familiar with the narrative.

Ultimately, Hathawayâ€™s plan to wait out the hatred rather than attempt to win over the public worked, and these days sheâ€™s back at the top of her game and in the online graces. From chilling 1960s thriller Motherâ€™s Instinct to a BookTok-approved adaptation ofÂ Â The Idea Of You, things have come full circle.Â

Speaking to Vanity Fair as the magazineâ€™s April cover star, she reflected on the period of virulent derision: â€œA lot of people wouldnâ€™t give me roles because they were so concerned about how toxic my identity had become online.â€

â€œI had an angel in Christopher Nolan, who did not care about that and gave me one of the most beautiful roles Iâ€™ve had in one of the best films that Iâ€™ve been a part of,â€ she said. As a result of the two-time Academy Award-winning director hiring her, Hathaway added that â€œmy career did not lose momentum the way it could have if he hadnâ€™t backed meâ€.

One can only speculate, of course, whether Hathaway draws inspiration from her personal adversity for her professional roles. But the time for speculation is over. What we do know is that Hathaway is a supremely gifted actor, and that she deserves every good thing coming to her. Itâ€™s fortunate for us, too, that Hathaway knew the day would come when she would once again have her time in the sun. â€œYou have to remember in life that thereâ€™s a positive to every negative and a negative to every positive,â€ she told US Weekly in the wake of the Oscars backlash in 2013. â€œThings tip in the scale of the positive. So that is what I focus on.â€

Images: Getty

item.title: Ambivalent relationships: why we need to watch out for our frenemies even more than our enemies
item.description: We should be more concerned about â€˜fake friendsâ€™ than our real enemies, according to psychologist Adam Grant.
item.dc:creator: Amy Beecham
item.content:encoded:
We all have someone in our lives that weâ€™re not really sure about. It could be a colleague that is friendly towards you one day but gives you the cold shoulder the next. It might be an oldÂ friend who seems to be growing more and more irritated by your presence. Whoever they are, itâ€™s often hard to know how to act around them. Do you kill the person with kindness in the hope they change their behaviour? Or simply leave them to it and spend less time in their company?

These so-called ambivalent relationshipsÂ may feel like theyâ€™re just part of adult life, but according to psychologist Adam Grant, theyâ€™re something we should be incredibly wary of, even more so than flat-out negative relationships.

â€œThe most intuitive reason is that ambivalent relationships are unpredictable,â€ Grant writes for The New York Times. â€œWith a clear enemy, you put up a shield when you cross paths. With a frenemy, you never know whether Dr Jekyll or Mr Hyde is going to show up.â€

â€œI had assumed that with a neighbour or a colleague, having some positive interactions was better than all negative interactions,â€ he continues. â€œBut being cheered on by the same person who cuts you down doesnâ€™t buffer the bad feelings; it amplifies them.â€

Indeed, studies have shown that a frenemy can cause you more distress than a straightforward enemy because these relationships are often so confusing that you never quite know what youâ€™re going to get. However, research from earlier this year concluded that most of us maintain frenemyships because the benefits, such as saving face, maintaining social networks and sustaining important connections, outweigh the negative ramifications of dealing with the relationship or terminating it.

So if you are going to stay in contact with a frenemy, how should you go about it?

Studies have shown that a frenemy can cause you more distress than a straightforward enemyÂ

Other than giving them a wide berth, if you must make contact with a frenemy, the key is setting clear and firm boundaries. While you may not feel comfortable confronting someoneâ€™s passive aggression or snide comments, having good emotional boundaries can look like not taking on other peopleâ€™s emotional burdens (aka trauma dumping) and not engaging in triggering topics.

When it comes to communication, being clear on what you deem acceptable is the best route to take. So if youâ€™re not ready to talk about something, dislike the tone youâ€™re being spoken to in or feel demeaned by name-calling or being dismissed, be explicit about your barriers.

While you canâ€™t guarantee they will react in kind, youâ€™ll know that youâ€™ve done everything you can to protect your wellbeing.

item.title: Beauty Pie: What is it, how do you sign up and is it actually worth joining?
item.description: Founded by serial entrepreneur Marcia Kilgore, Beauty Pie is a â€˜members onlyâ€™ club selling luxury beauty at affordable prices â€“ without a catch. Hereâ€™s the low-down.
item.dc:creator: Lucy Partington
item.content:encoded:
Between differentiating the strobe creams from dewy balms and the toners from the liquid exfoliators,Â beauty can be an overwhelming topic at times. There are so many brands out there, itâ€™s tricky to know where to start. But Beauty Pie is a great place to begin your journey.Â

The brand isnâ€™t a new concept. It launched back in 2017 and, along with the likes of Deciem, was part of a new wave of brands set to disrupt the beauty industry. Itâ€™s a service that gives members access to luxury cosmetics at factory prices â€“ and itâ€™s not too good to be true.

Beauty Pie is the brain child of entrepreneur Marcia Kilgore, whoâ€™s also the powerhouse behind iconic brands like Soap & Glory, Bliss Spa and FitFlop. Sheâ€™s worked in the industry for decades, and along the way she has learnt a lot about how both business and the beauty industry work.

Tired of the mark-up and overpriced products, Kilgoreâ€™s aim is to create more transparency when it comes to knowing what youâ€™re actually paying for, and she wants her customers to be able to buy luxury goods at cost price.Â

For example, a moisturiser from a well-known, high-end brand could have a retail cost of Â£100. But with Beauty Pie, a similar product will cost just Â£12.04 â€“ and the breakdown of that price is made clear on the website. Usually it will cover important things like product packaging, safety testing and warehousing. Itâ€™s also worth noting that Beauty Pie make absolutely no profit from any of the cosmetics they sell â€“ so what youâ€™re paying for is the price the factory has charged for it. All their profit comes from the cost of membership.

Granted, thereâ€™s no unnecessary extra money spent on packaging, so the products are very no-frills (but Kilgore still demands everything should be made from recycled plastic where possible), and thereâ€™ll never be a celebrity face associated with the brand. But full transparency and an extensive,Â constantly expanding range of hard-working, reliable products counts for much more, as does the precedent Beauty Pie is setting.

If youâ€™re slightly dubious of where these cosmetics are actually made and where they come from, donâ€™t be. Having worked in the industry for as long as she has, Kilgore has travelled the globe and knows exactly which factories in which countries are best for certain products. Plus, itâ€™s no secret that the majority of cosmetics tend to be made in the same places â€“ the very same places that Beauty Pie make their products.

There is a spending limit in place that relates to the retail value of products, and the amount you can buy every month depends on which membership tier you sign up for.Â

But with so many items to choose from â€“ including Japanese-inspired skincare, colour cosmetics, fragrances, candles, retinol creams and serums, lipstick and nail polishÂ â€“ itâ€™s hard to know what to buy first. So weâ€™ve rounded up an edit of our favourite bits, to give you a helping handâ€¦

item.title: â€œThe speculation surrounding the Princess of Wales says something sinister about what itâ€™s like to be a woman in the public eyeâ€
item.description: Stylist investigates how the frenzied rumour mill and forced outing of Princess Catherineâ€™s private cancer diagnosis reveal online acts of micro-misogyny.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Bourne
item.content:encoded:
Before we begin, this isnâ€™t an article about the Princess of Wales, nor is this article about her private medical information.

Instead, this is a call to arms. Because, honestly, we need to unpick what has been going on with everyone but Princess Catherine over the last 10 weeks.

On Friday (22 March) the Princess of Wales released a video statement revealing she has received a cancer diagnosis. This came after weeks of frenzied speculation by social media users and media outlets on the reason for her leave of absence from public duty. She described the diagnosis as a â€œhuge shockâ€, and said that her family have experienced â€œan incredibly tough couple of monthsâ€.

Following what quickly became a lesson in how we dehumanise those in the public eye (and how we find it all too easy to take our speculation to the faceless abyss of social media), an outpouring of shock and support flooded the online discourse. Commenters even began to retract their previous statements now her private matters no longer appeared gag-worthy material.

In one high-profile retraction, Blake Lively apologised on her Instagram Stories for previously making light of the Prince and Princess of Walesâ€™ doctored Motherâ€™s Day image, saying that a now-deleted post on her Betty Buzz business account â€œaround the â€˜Photoshop fails frenzyâ€™â€ has left her â€œmortifiedâ€ upon her learning of Princess Catherineâ€™s cancer diagnosis. Blake Lively wrote â€œIâ€™m sorryâ€, before adding â€œSending love and well wishes to all, alwaysâ€.

Having ranged from AI-generated images and body double allegations to â€˜blink twice if you need helpâ€™ â€˜jokesâ€™ and Kate-gate memes that spawned by the second, the rumour mill has now abruptly halted.

But before the news cycle moves on and those responsible write off their speculation as â€˜jokesâ€™ that just got out of hand, letâ€™s reflectÂ â€“ because this is a reminder that as a woman in 2024, the world (online and offline) is still a sinister place to exist.Â

The cosmetic procedure allegation

When it was first announced in a statement that Kate would be stepping back from public duty for an unspecified period of time following a planned abdominal surgery in January, social media users commented in their droves to â€˜jokeâ€™ that the Princess may have been recuperating following cosmetic surgery.

From a â€˜BBLâ€™ to a â€˜tummy tuckâ€™, the procedures stacked up. Would this discourse have played out had it been the Prince on an absence of leave? The answer is no.

Such commentary is inherently misogynistic, with a pervading derogatory assumption that women reach a societally-prescribed milestone where cosmetic surgery must be on the table.Â

The â€˜damsel in distressâ€™ narrative

Other allegations that surfaced online included that the Princess of Wales must have been â€˜kidnappedâ€™, or that she was in a medically-induced coma. Both play into the harmfulÂ â€˜damsel in distressâ€™ narrative trope, which has historically stripped women of power and control.

This kind of allegation also served to pressure a woman into giving up the last element of control she hadÂ â€“ the ability to choose when to tell the public of her cancer diagnosis. As Sarah Weinman writes in her essay for The Cut, â€œCancer is a wily beast, ready to strike on its own schedule, shattering the illusion of recovery and control. Is it any wonder, then, that Catherine wanted to hold on to it?â€.Â

The mental health crisis

After Piers Morgan speculated on whether Princess Catherine could have had a â€˜nervous breakdownâ€™ during TMZâ€™s controversial Where is Kate Middleton?Â documentary earlier this month, the rumour mill swirled with social media allegations that the Princess could be suffering a mental health crisis.

Morgan said, â€œI think the pressure on Kate has been utterly unbearable for a long time. It wouldnâ€™t shock me if she has had some kind of breakdown. Theyâ€™ve now had a major health crisis and sheâ€™s trying to bring up three young kids in a goldfish bowl of the Royal family. You put all that togetherÂ â€“ thatâ€™s a lot for any young woman to deal with.â€

Here, we see the inherently misogynistic trope of the â€˜hysterical womanâ€™Â â€“ an attempt to invalidate a womanâ€™s personal experiences, thoughts and feelings. In Morganâ€™s eyes, Princess Catherine would be the â€˜supporting roleâ€™ to Williamâ€™s â€˜Kingâ€™, and speculating that she may not be able to â€˜copeâ€™ with the idea of becoming Queen positions her as secondary to her husband.Â

The body double speculation

When Princess Catherine was spotted on a trip out to a local farm shop in Windsor on 16 March, weeks after the speculation surrounding her health began, a fresh wave of allegations surfaced online that a â€˜body doubleâ€™ must have been used.

This examination over grainy footage uncovers something a whole lot more sinister and is very reminiscent of a feeling any woman will understand: how society polices, politicises and scrutinises womenâ€™s bodies as we navigate the world. Such speculation can feel suffocating.

There have been, and continue to be, waves of commentary on how the media scrutinised Princess Diana, with harmful narratives and invasive paparazzo techniques. But back then, in the 90s, public speculation was confined to private conversation around the dinner table.

Now, we exist in an age where the noise of social media entirely eclipses that of the media, stripping a woman of her autonomy and privacy, so she feels she has to tell the world about an intensely private and personal medical diagnosis, perhaps before she is ready to.

Allegation by allegation, these individual moments of speculationÂ â€“ whether intended with humour or maliceÂ â€“ are moments of micro-misogyny that paint a vile portrait of how society continues to attack womanhood.

As Princess Catherine addressed the faceless camera to reveal her cancer diagnosis and put an end to the frenzied speculation of the last few weeks, she sat alone. She powerfully and bravely reclaimed her narrative after weeks of being hounded by misogyny. Letâ€™s hope she now gets the privacy she deserves to healÂ â€“ and that, as a society, we realise that words matter.Â

item.title: 7 retro desserts to try across London that take you back to your school dinner days
item.description: Dust off your gingham dress and grab your book bag: school dinner desserts are back in a big way across the capital.
item.dc:creator: Amy Beecham
item.content:encoded:
Remember when you were young and carefree and every dinner was followed by a Choc Ice, a bowl of Vienetta or a pot of rice pudding? Well, your days may no longer be spent doing handstands or picking daisies, but the good news is that school dinner desserts are back â€“ in a big way.

Youâ€™ve probably already heard about joyous jam roly-poly at Rochelle Kitchen, elevated banana splits at The Delaunay or tried CafÃ© Ceciliaâ€™s famous deep-fried bread and butter pudding, but even more spots across London are all leaning into the nostalgia and serving up retro desserts. Ready to take your tastebuds back in time? Here are seven of the best to try now.Â

The Duke of Greenwich sherry trifle

This boozy miniature sherry trifle is the perfect end to an epic Sunday roast.

Address:Â 91 Colomb St, London SE10 9EZ

book now

Manziâ€™s arctic roll

item.title: Why women want men to peel their oranges: the rise of acts of service as the prominent love language
item.description: How did asking your partner to peel an orange for you become a barometer of affection, you ask? Social media, of course. Women filming themselves applying â€œorange peel theoryâ€ on their unsuspecting other halves speaks to a generational love language, argues executive editor Jazmin Kopotsha. Here, she speaks to the author and originator of The 5 Love Languages to uncover why women are crying out for acts of service (and what those actions look like in real life).
item.dc:creator: Jazmin Kopotsha
item.content:encoded:
My boyfriend has peeled an orange for me. We were ranking our favourite fruit (thrilling, I know) and I declared that oranges were overrated. They require too much work to get in to. Those awful white stringy veins? Gag material. And you can never really tell how ripe theyâ€™re going to be until youâ€™re covered in pulp and itâ€™s all too late.

A few days later, he presented me with a pre-peeled segment of orange to eat. Iâ€™m convinced this was an expression of disbelief at my aversion to oranges more than anything, but I was touched by the gesture all the same.

This Very Important Milestone in our relationship happened ages ago. But when â€œorange peel theoryâ€ swept TikTok recently â€“ videos of women asking their partners to peel an orange for them to see if they would take on the task as confirmation of their love â€“ I couldnâ€™t help but tune in. I told myself this was out of ironic fascination, of course. And that I, a serious grown-up in a secure and loving relationship, was above benchmarking whether my partner was worth keeping against this arbitrary social media trend. Insert knowing raised eyebrow emoji here.Â

My hubris didnâ€™t last long. I was quickly shot down when I told a friend about my relationship already meeting this cool-girl criteria. Contrary to the women testing their partnerâ€™s affection with a request to skin some citrus on camera, my boyfriend did it for me ages ago. Talk about true love. She told me it didnâ€™t count because I neither wanted nor asked for the peeled orange so it was never really for my benefit. Humbled by a rollercoaster of smugness and insecurity, I forced myself to sit with the scenario for a while. Yes, online trends like these often have an unsavoury habit of over-simplifying things that are nuanced and complex â€“ especially in the wellbeing space â€“ but at the heart of this relatively harmless game of â€œwhat would your partner do for youâ€, there seemed to be a shift in mindset, too.

A wave of women had overwhelmed social media with a refreshed framework for a â€˜goodâ€™ partner. Gone were the #RelationshipGoals that plagued the 2010s with images of women surrounded by lavish presents, flash-mob proposals and perfectly framed photos taken by their patient Instagram boyfriends. Consider this the era in which the â€˜receiving giftsâ€™ love language thrived in public.Â

Take it back a few years and you might remember that the climax of most romcoms of the 90s and 00s was when a man finally articulated his feelings to the flummoxed yet doting female lead. Think, Heath Ledgerâ€™s character serenading Julia Styles with Canâ€™t Take My Eyes Off You in 10 Things I Hate About You. Tom Cruiseâ€™s â€œI love you; you complete meâ€ in Jerry McGuire. Any mention of that painful trope that includes â€œthose three little words sheâ€™s always wanted to hearâ€.Â Consider this the glory years for the â€˜words of affirmationâ€™ love language, as demonstrated by all those films in which the guyâ€™s wrongdoings are undone by shouting (or singing) his feelings.

No doubt â€˜quality timeâ€™ and â€˜physical touchâ€™ have peaked and troughed in our lifetimes, too. The former perhaps in the post-war period of being reunited with a loved one or even after the internet fundamentally altered the way we communicate with each other. And we need not look too far to find womenâ€™s yearning for physical touch, magnified for all of us by the Covid lockdown years. I canâ€™t be the only one who read far too much into an accidental brush of the hand at the supermarket after being starved of skin-to-skin contact.Â Â

Acts of service is 2024â€™s love language of choice

Looking at our behaviour right now, though, it seems that acts of service is the love language of choice for women in 2024. We want partners who are willing to do the quieter things that make our lives that little bit easier. Millennial women in particular are frazzled, tired and overstimulated. Surely the last thing any of us want to do isâ€¦ well, anything. The Great Resignation that saw swarms of us quitting our jobs (without necessarily having something else to go to), the decline of Girl Boss hustle culture and the seductive appeal of living a #SoftLife have been hinting as such over the last couple of years.Â

For me, I crave my boyfriendâ€™s interjection in day-to-day decision-making. Plan the date night. Decide what TV show weâ€™re watching. Do a load of laundry so that my go-to jumpsuit is clean for the meeting I told you Iâ€™m going to. And message my friends to cancel on my behalf because Iâ€™m too tired/canâ€™t be bothered/could do with some time to myself.Â

Is it too much to ask? I donâ€™t think so. Though bearing the brunt of the emotional labour has long been the plight of womenkind, I wonder if weâ€™ve reached our limit and so attach new value to a partner willing to carry some of that load out of love rather than obligation. One of my friends told me how it melted her heart to find that her husband had got up early to make breakfast, fill up the car with petrol and lay out her bag ahead of her first day in a new job. On the flip side, the most common complaint from another close friend is along the lines of: â€œWhy do I have to ask him to do everything? Why canâ€™t he see what needs doing and just do it for me?â€

I wouldnâ€™t go so far as to eliminate the role other love languages play in modern womenâ€™s desires: sex is great, gifts are cute and, of course, Iâ€™d like to spend some time with you. But I donâ€™t think thereâ€™s anything more attractive than a man who can sense your needs, expect nothing in return and utters those three magic words: â€œIâ€™ll handle it.â€Â

The man whoâ€™s dedicated his lifeâ€™s work to understanding how people truly want to be loved is Dr Gary Chapman. In his early years as a marriage counsellor, he noticed that couples would often voice similar complaints in their sessions. To unpick what people really meant when they said they didnâ€™t feel loved, he scoured through over a decadeâ€™s worth of notes for the answer.

â€œRemarkably, I found their answers fell into five categories,â€ Dr Chapman tells Stylist. â€œThe premise is simple: different people with different personalities express love in different ways. These ways of expressing and receiving love are called â€˜love languagesâ€™ and every individual has one they prefer above the others. I refer to it as their primary love language.â€Â

Itâ€™s now been more than 30 years since Dr Chapmanâ€™s book The 5 Love Languages: The Secret To Love That Lasts, hit bestseller lists across the world and the prevalence of his concept in how we understand relationship behaviours is showing no sign of slowing down. Since the book was released, the five methods of loving â€“ receiving gifts, quality time, words of affirmation, physical touch and acts of service â€“ have given relationship counsellors and psychologists a blueprint to use as they guide clients through a whole manner of things.Â

Acts of service help to alleviate womenâ€™s stress

Dr Gary Chapman, author of The 5 Love Languages

When I asked Dr Chapman about my hunch that women are more vocally seeking acts of service in a romantic partner, he suggested that it could be related to longstanding cultural and societal pressures that have slowly started to shift over generations. â€œI believe women today feel freer to express their need for help. In the past, they were expected to do it all and do it well,â€ he explains. â€œI think women are speaking up and asking for the help they need to create a healthy work/life balance, and offering acts of service is a way to help alleviate their stress.â€

Dr Chapman caveats this thought with the fact that he hasnâ€™t noticed that one love language resonates more than the other four. â€œThe love languages are rather evenly distributed from 23% to 18% in each category,â€ he says. One is not necessarily more common among males and another among females. But BACP registered psychotherapist and anxiety expert Kamalyn Kaur offers a similar observation on women being more vocal â€“ at least on the internet â€“ about wanting acts of service from their partners.

â€œHistorically and traditionally, women have often been responsible for managing households, taking care of the family and child-rearing responsibilities,â€ Kaur explains. â€œAlthough this is changing, I think the expectations can still be there, putting a lot of pressure on women, particularly those who are also managing careers. In some cultures, women are still expected to take on the role of â€˜running the houseâ€™ without the men being involved at all.Â

â€œGiven these circumstances, it is no surprise that an act of service will be more appreciated and valuable than someone buying you a bunch of flowers or giving you words of affirmation. An act of service will take the load off you, alleviate some pressure and will also make you feel both seen and supported.â€

Being able to ease the burden of responsibilities weighing on an acts of service person will speak volumes, Dr Chapman explains. â€œLaziness, broken commitments and making more work for them tell speakers of this language their feelings donâ€™t matter. When someone serves out of love (and not obligation), an acts of service person feels truly valued and loved.â€

Itâ€™d be remiss not to acknowledge that to feel catered to as someone whose love language is acts of service relies on knowing what that looks like for you. Granted, I didnâ€™t ask for the slice of orange my boyfriend presented me after I told him I didnâ€™t like the effort of eating oranges. But facilitating something for me â€“ even if it is eating a piece of fruit that I donâ€™t really want â€“ is a demonstratable type of love that I value very highly.

â€œThe love languages are an intuitive and simple way to teach couples how to tune into each otherâ€™s ways of expressing love,â€ Dr Chapman says. What might that look like in practice? We asked 13 women to tell us.Â Â

Speaking in Love Languages: the acts of service that make women in relationships feel lovedÂ

â€œI recognise itâ€™s not sexy or cool, but thatâ€™s the reality of love as an adultâ€

Ellen, 31, lives with her boyfriend. Theyâ€™ve been together for seven years.

â€œI have many expectations around general admin and house upkeep, and I find that when those expectations arenâ€™t met I can feel my love meter draining. One is that I have a special container for our toothbrushes, and I expect that my partner will put their toothbrush in this container rather than leaving it on the side of the sink, where itâ€™ll create a little toothpaste ring. We take turns to cook for the week, and on a Sunday evening, I expect him to clean the kitchen and clear the fridge so I can start my cooking week with ease. When he doesnâ€™t do these things, Iâ€™m resentful and grumpy. When he does, I feel such immense love for him â€“ itâ€™s wild.

â€œSimilarly, he recently took care of the admin of researching Airbnbs and booking flights for an upcoming wedding. I loved that. It was like he recognised that I was busy and stressed out, and knew that the mental load of having to do that would be weighing on me. Each time he collects my antidepressant prescription from Boots so I donâ€™t have to, or arranges condiments in the fridge, thatâ€™s better than any bouquet of flowers. My love language is 100% â€˜making my life easierâ€™, which I recognise is not remotely sexy or cool, but thatâ€™s the reality of love as an adult.â€

â€œI like being carried up to bed if I fall asleep on the sofaâ€

Chloe, 28

Chloe, 28, living with a boyfriend for two years.

â€œAs soon as we put a film on, Iâ€™m guilty of falling asleep straight away, even when I say Iâ€™m not tired. This happened a few times when we started living together, and my boyfriend would always be frustrated and confused by me avoiding getting up and putting myself to bed â€“ sometimes you just canâ€™t be bothered. So now, heâ€™ll let me fall asleep and carry me up to bed at the end of the film.â€Â

â€œHeâ€™ll always pick up the dog pooâ€

Annie, 32, lives with her boyfriend. Theyâ€™ve been together for 10 years.

â€œI donâ€™t necessarily expect it (and I have never asked), but for some reason, if weâ€™re walking the dog together, he will always pick up the dogâ€™s poo. I can be holding her lead and heâ€™ll hold out his hand for the bags. Or if heâ€™s got her, heâ€™ll pass her over to me so that he can pick it up. I donâ€™t know when it started but it always makes me laugh, and now itâ€™s just imbedded in the routine that itâ€™s something I donâ€™t do. And just to clarify: if itâ€™s just me walking her, I do still pick it up!â€

â€œHe bought me some nice treats after a date. I would have preferred him to offer to walk me homeâ€

Sue, 26, is single and dating.

â€œI was dating a really nice guy for a while, but something just wasnâ€™t clicking. I could tell he liked me a lot (he told me so enough) but it just wasnâ€™t hitting right. I remember talking to my mum about how I felt bad for breaking up with him when he spent so much money on gifts. She said the only thing I would consistently complain about would be the fact that he never offered to help me get home after a date â€“ whether waiting for a taxi or walking me home. In hindsight, that says a lot about both of us.â€Â Â

â€œIf he goes to the shop, I expect a little treatâ€

Jess, 30

Jess, 30, has been with her partner for six years.

â€œMy feet are always cold, so every night when I get into bed he lets me put mine on his to warm them up. If I go out in the evening, he walks me to the station. He also always cleans the catâ€™s litter tray because he knows that makes me gag. Expectation-wise: if he ever goes to the shop I expect him to pick me up a little treat. Non-negotiable, in my opinion.â€

â€œMy husband rubs my belly and sings a songâ€

Miranda, 33, is married.

â€œWhen Iâ€™m on my period, my husband rubs my belly and sings a song called Bleedy Magooâ€¦ and now, I donâ€™t think I could get through the week without that ritual. Also, he always does the washing up and changes our bed sheets every Friday â€“ and changing bed sheets is lowkey the worst chore.â€

â€œI expect to be escorted home or for him to at least find and track my journeyâ€

Jazmin, 31, lives with a partner of four years.

â€œThe last thing I want to do when Iâ€™m stressed is have to think about little matters of convenience. For example, if thereâ€™s a train strike and my boyfriend knows Iâ€™m in the office, then I want him to check that Iâ€™ll be able to get home OK, have a look at my options and come to meet me if Iâ€™m going to arrive late at night.Â

â€œIf Iâ€™m out late and getting a train home, I expect to be escorted from the train station. Also, weâ€™ve both learned that I will not engage in conversation in the morning until Iâ€™ve been brought a cup of tea in bed. Separate from these sorts of things, Iâ€™ve definitely noticed that the markers of a â€˜grown-upâ€™ relationship are not just traditional affection. Itâ€™s making the other person feel heard and respected, which for me requires taking things off my plate to help me focus on other things.â€

Heâ€™s been known to wash my hair for me

Louise, 33

Louise, 33, has been with her partner for seven years.

â€œThere have been a few times in recent years when my boyfriend has been known to wash my hair for me. It started almost as a joke because I was moaning about how long my washday routine takes. He half-assed offered to do it for me, and I donâ€™t think he expected me to say yes. But every couple of months, particularly if Iâ€™ve been having a rough time, heâ€™ll run me a bath and offer to wash and condition my hair while I soak.â€Â

â€œMy husband heats the car before I get inâ€

Vicky, 30, is married and theyâ€™ve been together for five years.

â€œWhen itâ€™s cold out, my husband puts the heating on in our car remotely so when I get in itâ€™s already warm. We have a ritual every Sunday: my husband gets up first and makes us both a coffee and then gets back into bed, where we listen to the radio and do a crossword (weâ€™re horribly old for our age).

â€œWhen we go to nice restaurants, my husband always picks the wine, and for me, this is an act of service. He is really into wine (and very knowledgeable) and he always picks something he knows Iâ€™ll love, that goes with what Iâ€™m eating, how Iâ€™m feeling that day and what the weatherâ€™s like. It sounds ridiculous, but I find it very romantic.â€

â€œI donâ€™t have to worry about where Iâ€™ve put my keysâ€

Alexis, 37, has been dating her boyfriend for two years.

â€œOne of the things that puts the biggest smile on my face recently is when Iâ€™m rushing to get out of the door in the morning and looking around for my keys, Iâ€™ll eventually find them on the shelf by the door. I always forget to put them there (in my own house!) and often throw them on a table or leave them tucked down the side of a sofa. But heâ€™s noticed that I tend to struggle with mornings and beat myself up when I slow myself down/forget things. Now heâ€™s taken to putting my keys by the door whenever he stumbles across them.â€

A song and dance has to be made about my birthday

Amy, 26, is engaged.Â

â€œI like my fiance to always walk on the outside of the pavement so I can walk on the inside (lower risk of a passing car driving through a puddle and splashing me, running me over, etc). Iâ€™m also very big on birthdays â€“ I couldnâ€™t care less if we donâ€™t celebrate Valentineâ€™s Day or anniversaries, but a partner has to make a song and dance about my birthday. (Iâ€™m such an only child.)â€Â

â€œHe looks at the map so I donâ€™t have toâ€

Rebecca, 32, has been with her partner for just over a year.

â€œMy partner drives me and my daughter on the school run twice a week. Plus, when we go anywhere he looks at the map and gets the route in his head first so I can just follow him and not have to look at my phone. This is love.â€

â€œHe has to sleep on the side of the bed closest to the doorâ€

Sophie, 30, lives with her boyfriend. Theyâ€™ve been together for nine years.

â€œWhen Iâ€™m really busy, working late or generally feeling like my to-do list is never-ending, my partner is so great at knowing when to ramp up all the little acts of service that make my day better and less stressful. He will stroke my arm for ages to calm me down (weird but nice), heâ€™ll make my favourite dinner (usually loads of carbs) and run to the shop and get me my favourite Yorkie raisin and biscuit chocolate and bring it to me with a cup of tea. Heâ€™ll also watch reality TV with me, includingÂ Married At First Sight: Australia even though he hates it because I like having someone to talk to about it.

â€œAlso, I donâ€™t like sleeping near the door. I always sleep next to the window and he always sleeps closest to the door. So, whenever we go away anywhere he will automatically choose the side closest to the door (so he gets murdered first, obviously, while I have time to escape out the window).â€

item.content:encoded:
If you had just won gold at an international indoors athletic competition or taken home a silver medal for your country at a swimming event, youâ€™d expect to be paid handsomely, right? But that isnâ€™t the case for many of our best sportswomen. In fact, the majority are barely scraping a living â€“ despite being at the very top of their field.

Thatâ€™s according to the results of the BBCâ€™s 2024 Elite British Sportswomenâ€™s Study, which saw 615 elite sportswomen across 28 different sports asked to fill in a survey about their experiences. Of the 143 women who responded, only 93 were full-time athletes and 13 received absolutely zero income for being at the top of their field.

And although some athletes in high-profile sports like football and tennis may receive lucrative sponsorship opportunities, this study shows thatâ€™s not the case across the board. In fact, more than three-quarters of the respondents said they earned less than Â£30,000 a year from their sport, while four in 10 said they earned less than Â£10,000 a year (including grants, funding, prize money, salaries or sponsorship).Â

And that lack of money is clearly taking its toll: more than a third of respondents said theyâ€™d considered giving up their sport due to the recent cost of living crisis and the majority answered â€˜noâ€™ when asked whether sportswomen were paid enough and received enough financial reward compared to their male counterparts.

Sponsorship opportunities were a big issue among respondents, who said the current economic climate made it hard to get sponsorship, even though men seemed to get more. Indeed, one respondent added: â€œAs much as the profile of womenâ€™s sport is on the rise, in the smaller sports, sponsorship is decreasing and making it harder to survive, even with world-class results and world top-10 rankings.â€

The study also found that more than a third of respondents had been trolled on social media, while almost three-quarters of respondents had experienced sexism in their sport. One in three respondents said they did not feel supported by their club or governing body to have a baby and continue to compete at their current level.Â

Four in 10 said they earned less than Â£10,000 a year

Thatâ€™s even more shocking when you consider that, according to research the Womenâ€™s Sports Trust, more people than ever before turned up to watch womenâ€™s sport live in the UK last year. The same can be said for viewership figures, with a record-breaking 46.7 million people tuning in to watch womenâ€™s sport on linear TV in 2023.

Womenâ€™s sport does feel more visible than ever â€“ and itâ€™s inspiring more and more young girls to take part. But clearly, the fight for equality is far from over.

While itâ€™s amazing to see so much progress being made when it comes to crowd sizes and viewership figures, this survey is a poignant reminder of the battles sportswomen are fighting behind the scenes just to compete on the world stage.

In 2024, itâ€™s not good enough that women with so much talent are being forced to consider giving up their sport simply because they canâ€™t make ends meet. The excitement surrounding last yearâ€™s Womenâ€™s Fifa World Cup was a prime example of just how powerful and exciting womenâ€™s sport can be. We just need more brands to get on board and give more sportswomen the opportunities and financial security they deserve so they can turn their full attention towards the sports they love.Â

item.title: Trying to conceive? Hereâ€™s how pilates can help you to prepare for pregnancy (and the 5 best moves to practice)
item.description: If youâ€™re trying to conceive, regular low-impact strengthening exercises can help strengthen the pelvic floor and core ahead of pregnancyâ€¦
item.dc:creator: Miranda Larbi
item.content:encoded:
When youâ€™re trying to conceive, the advice tends to centre around what you eat, how often you have sex and keeping stress to a minimum. But regular movement is also a key lifestyle factor that can influence how you feel â€“ physically, emotionally and mentally â€“ on your pregnancy journey. The ideal activity is one that strengthens the core and pelvic floor (youâ€™ll need that later down the line!), improves posture (crucial if your centre of gravity starts to shift as a bump grows) and calms the mind. And thatâ€™s where pilates comes in.

We know that pilates offers a host of benefits for everyone, regardless of age, gender or reproductive intentions. But the mat (or reformer)-based activity is especially useful for pregnant women and those thinking of starting a family. Itâ€™s not that the exercise will help you to get pregnant (thatâ€™s stretching the powers of pilates a little too far), but itâ€™s about prepping the body to cope with the physical (and mental) changes that happen quite quickly once you are pregnant. 

Think of it a little like a pre-season; if you were looking at a nine-month football stretch, youâ€™d spend a few months before doing lots of strength and conditioning and mobility workouts to prepare ahead of all those games. That pre-season might not win you the trophy, but itâ€™ll put you in a great position from that first match.  

Hollie Grant is an award winning reformer and mat pilates instructor, and founder of Pilates PT. In her new book, The Bump Plan, she explains that the trying to conceive (TTC) stage is often sugar-coated as being an exciting time full of â€œfun and lots of shaggingâ€, but thatâ€™s not always that way for many women. â€œFor me, this was the time where I really â€˜neededâ€™ exercise,â€ she explains. â€œI leaned heavily on it to support my mental health and mood while navigating TTC and found it to be an anchor.â€

During her first pregnancy, she struggled with urinary stress incontinence (ie leaking when you jump or cough), and as such, Grant writes that when TTC with her second baby, she wanted to meet the physical demands of pregnancy from the off. â€œI wanted to enter my next pregnancy feeling strong, capable and with a seriously functional pelvic floor,â€ she says. 

Think of this period like a pre-season

Why is exercise like pilates important when TTC?Â

The NHS recommends that the average, non-pregnant adult do 150 minutes of moderate-intensity or 75 minutes of vigorous exercise a week, but there are no guidelines for women TTC. There are umpteen reasons for that, says Grant, including the fact that some people donâ€™t know theyâ€™re pregnant for some time and the fact that the TTC community isnâ€™t seen as a distinct group of people (at least within these mainstream bodies). That means youâ€™ve got to decide how to see yourself â€“ as part of the general adult population or the pregnant population.

Grant explains that the only real difference between the two is the recommended intensity of cardio exercise. Moderate intensity is recommended during pregnancy, while the general population can work at moderate, vigorous or very vigorous intensity. If youâ€™re actively trying for a baby, you may want to lean more towards that 150 minute-moderate intensity goal â€“ which also includes two strength workouts a week.

The key thing to remember about pregnancy is that babies grow in the abdominal cavity, so having a strong, functional core is important for protecting the spine and pelvic floor. Grant explains that TTC is the perfect time to do as much ab work as possible â€“ especially as core work becomes more challenging once a bump comes into play. Cardio is also important as your blood volume doubles during pregnancy, and all that extra liquid needs to be pumped around the body by the cardiovascular system. So nowâ€™s the perfect time to set up a swimming routine or do couch to 5K, while committing to regular pilates sessions thatâ€™ll strengthen those key areas.Â

With that in mind, here are the 5 pilates moves that Grant recommends practicing if youâ€™re TTC.Â Â

5 pilates moves for people trying to conceiveÂ

Arm reach

â€œThis is a great exercise for teaching spine stability,â€ says Grant. â€œDuring pregnancy, our growing uterus can pull the pelvis forward at the front and cause us to lean backwards.â€ Thatâ€™s more pronounced if the abs stretch and struggle to support the spine. Arm reaches are all about promoting core activation, which then stabilises the spin and reduces the temptation to lean back.

  1. Breathe in, arms by your side
  2. As you exhale, reach your arms up over your head and hold them there for a moment
  3. Stay in a neutral position (donâ€™t lean back)*, then inhale and lower the arms back down
  4. Repeat

*that neutral position is key for making the abs at the front work harder.

Hip hinges 

â€œIâ€™d prescribe these exercises to every human being if I could. Hip hinges activate the hamstrings and glutes which, given our modern-day sedentary lifestyles, can become weak and lazy,â€ she explains. â€œDuring pregnancy, itâ€™s these muscles that give the pelvis support as the uterus grows.â€ This movement pattern is known as the good morning stretch in strength training and is the same pattern as a deadlift (were you to add weights).

  1. Find your neutral standing position and then bring your arms to prayer at your chest
  2. Make sure your knees are soft and then when youâ€™re ready, imagine that you are bowing
  3. Push your bum back and hinge at the hips until you can feel the backs of your legs stretch but canâ€™t go any further without bending your knees or back
  4. Hold
  5. As you exhale, bring yourself back up to standing and repeat  

Hip lift

Grant says: â€œToo much sitting down in our modern lifestyles can leave our hip flexors feeling tight and weak. Thatâ€™s a problem because, in pregnancy, we need strong and flexible hip flexors that can support our pelvis. This exercise targets the concentric (shortening) phase and eccentric (lengthening) phase of muscle activation and helps improve the function of the hip flexor.â€

  1. Stand in a natural position
  2. Shift your weight to your right leg (knees soft) and bring your hands to prayer
  3. Exhale to bend your left knee and lift it so that your left thigh is parallel to your hip (think: standing tabletop)
  4. Hold, balancing on the right leg
  5. Inhale as you lower the left foot to tap the floor and exhale to bring it back up to that tabletop position
  6. Repeat, making sure that the pelvis remains fixed in place â€“ it should only be the left leg moving in the hip socket. Nothing else should move
  7. Change legs and repeat on the other side

Quad stretch

â€œThis is a great exercise for learning how to stabilise the pelvis, and it also works the glutes and abdominals. Pelvic stability is really helpful as the bump grows, so strengthening the pelvic stabilisers (our pelvic floor and transverse abdominis) will make a huge difference ahead of pregnancy.â€

  1. Come into a standing kneel (only your legs should be on the floor â€“ not your bum too)
  2. Engage the core and bring your arms up to shoulder height, relaxing the shoulders away from your ears
  3. Imagine a line going from the crown of your head to your knees
  4. As you inhale, slowly start to hinge backwards â€“ maintaining that imaginary line
  5. As we exhale, bring yourself back to the start position
  6. You should feel the effort in the core and, if youâ€™re squeezing, the glutes

Side kneeling leg lift

Grant calls this exercise â€˜spicyâ€™, so you can be sure of a good hip abductor burn. â€œLift the leg as high as you can without making the rest of the body move.â€

  1. Come to a standing kneel and find that neutral position, arms out to the side
  2. Lean towards your left side so that you can put your left hand on the floor
  3. As you come down, extend the right leg along the mat, making sure the hips are facing forward
  4. Bring your right arm towards the ceiling, exhale and slowly lift your right leg up towards the ceiling â€“ toes pointed
  5. Inhale and, with control, bring that right leg back down
  6. Repeat a few times before switching sidesÂ

Images: Getty

item.title: Your April 2024 horoscope is here: get ready for the month ahead with your star signâ€™s forecast
item.description: What does April 2024 have in store for your star sign? Let astrology lead the way with your horoscope for the month ahead.
item.dc:creator: Astrodim
item.content:encoded:
April is upon us and so is Mercury retrograde, which starts on the 1st of April and doesnâ€™t budge until the 24th. That spells troubleâ€¦ but what else can your star sign expect this month? And how can you best navigate Mercury retrogradeâ€™s classic problems with communication, travel and technology? Your horoscope is here to help.Â

Youâ€™ll find your star signâ€™s specific forecast ahead, but first letâ€™s run through whatâ€™s happening in the world of astrology for the month. First, as mentioned, itâ€™s Mercury retrograde. Then, on the 5th, weâ€™re hit with two major transits: the sun conjoining with the North Node in Aries, which will up our motivation, and Venus entering Aries, which will nudge us to turn our dreams into plans.Â

On 8 April we have another double dose of intense transits, probably the most intense of 2024. Not only will we have a total solar eclipse in Aries, but the only aspect it will be making is an exact conjunction to Chiron. Talk about intense, in-your-face healing. Solar eclipses are all about huge new beginnings that can totally turn us upside down. This one in particular will bring us new beginnings by challenging our motivationsÂ â€“ are we doing what we want to do and following our passions? Take it easy this week, these are tough questions. The Mercury cazimi in Aries on the 11th will bring some clarity, thankfully.

The sun enters Taurus on 19 April, which will push us to focus on practical stability and security. Change will be all around, so doing what you can to stay steady will be key. Keep that energy for another transit on the 21st: Jupiter conjoining Uranus. After that, things should settle down.Â

On the 23rd, the full moon in Scorpio will prompt us to dig into our emotions and then, finally, Mercury will station direct. Phew. On the 29th, Venus enters Taurus, which will make us assess our deep desiresÂ â€“ and prompt us to let go of any weâ€™ve outgrown. Finally, Mars enters its home in Aries on 30 April. This is a great moment to hit the ground running, using all the plans youâ€™ve been working away on. Everything you learn this month is going to come in handy.Â

Ready to dig in to the specifics for your star sign? Read on for your horoscope for April.Â

Aries

21 March to 19 April

You have a lot going on in April, Aries, and you have an opportunity to transform and rise like the phoenix. This wonâ€™t come easy, but who else can do it other than the warrior of the zodiac? Especially during your solar returnÂ â€“ happy birthday, April Aries! Watch out for Mercury Retrograde, which will cause trouble with communication and your day-to-day routine. Youâ€™ll feel an urge to kick up a fuss, but itâ€™s important to reframe: issues might not be your fault, but what can you do to make them better? If you lean into this way of thinking, youâ€™ll see success this month.Â

On 8 April there will be a solar eclipse in your sign, which signals big changes in your life for the next year. On the day, take it easy. This eclipse will be heavy, energy-wise, so this is a time to reflect, let go and rest. Afterwards, prepare for a season of unexpected shifts and opportunitiesÂ â€“ donâ€™t let them pass you by.Â

Taurus

20 April to 20 May

Throughout April, youâ€™ll feel a pull to read between the lines and understand the unspoken words. Youâ€™re an investigative mood, and thatâ€™s fine, but make sure you donâ€™t become too watchful. Sometimes itâ€™s worth trusting your intuition and just going for it, rather than digging into every minor interaction.Â

On the 19th, Taurus season beginsÂ â€“ happy birthday, Taurus! You might experience some uncomfortable adjustments in the realm of work this month. Although frustrating, this will bring growth. Face the changes head-on and make tweaks where necessary.Â

Towards the end of the month, youâ€™ll be looking more deeply into your relationships. Somethingâ€™s not working and youâ€™re ready to let it go. Turn towards self-love at this time.Â

Gemini

21 May to 20 June

Misunderstandings abound this month and youâ€™ll be dealing with the emotional hangover. Consider how you might have played a part in some of these miscommunicationsâ€¦ have you unintentionally said something hurtful? Focus on this and consider the other personâ€™s feelings when you move towards patching things up.Â

April will also be a good month to resolve any internal roadblocks for your long-term goals. Is there a reason you arenâ€™t going after your dreams? Are you scared of failure? Or even success? Make it a priority to reflect on your aspirations and whatâ€™s been holding you back in the coming weeks. Once you have that clarity, youâ€™ll find moving forward so much easier.Â

Be warned that Taurus season might leave you feeling a tad overwhelmed. Know that itâ€™s OK to take some time to yourself to get introspective. And donâ€™t hold on to anything thatâ€™s no longer serving youÂ â€“ now is a good time to let go of patterns that have overstayed their welcome.Â

Cancer

21 June to 22 July

The spotlight is on you this month â€“ all eyes are on Cancer. The timing can be a bit annoying as you feel that youâ€™re not on your A-game. It is very important that you dot every i and cross every t, especially in the workplace. Take your time in everything that you do and allow yourself to be a great example.Â

The reason youâ€™re being so closely watched? Thereâ€™s an opportunity for growth. Those eyes are sticking around to make sure youâ€™re the right fit. Situations will be thrown at you and youâ€™ll be judged by how you respond. Stay calm and stay true to yourself. Nowâ€™s the time to hone your skills in showing your best self during tough times.Â

Towards the end of the month, youâ€™ll feel an itch to step out of your norm and experience new things. What entertained and energised you previously isnâ€™t clicking the way it was before. That might feel uncomfortable at first, but embrace the chance to do things differently. You might discover something wonderful.

Leo

23 July to 22 August

Ooh, Leo. This month is going to be a real journey of self-discovery. Youâ€™ve relied on your cheerful disposition to keep trucking along, but your energy is running out. Now you want to reflect. Lean into that desireÂ â€“ going deep can be frustrating at first, but so beneficial long-term.Â

The powerful solar eclipse will ramp this up, unearthing some wounds that havenâ€™t yet fully healed. Youâ€™ve been telling yourself these issues have already been addressed and resolved, but thatâ€™s not the case. Thereâ€™s still some work to be done. Be gentle with yourself.Â

At the end of April, youâ€™ll be ready to let go of some baggage. As a result, youâ€™ll enter May with renewed hope and optimism.Â

Virgo

23 August to 22 September

Youâ€™ve got a lot on your mind this month, Virgo, and you donâ€™t feel ready to talk about it. With Mercury, your planet, in retrograde, youâ€™d rather keep it hush-hush than make any mistakes. Youâ€™ve been feeling the transformative energy around you rerouting you to the direction youâ€™re supposed to be in. You respect it, but it doesnâ€™t make this uncomfortable moment better. However, you are VirgoÂ â€“ there is nothing that revised routines and healthier habits canâ€™t fix. Youâ€™re just getting yourself ready for the task.

However, there are times in which we have to dig deeper to get to the root of the problem. This eclipse will show how you tend to hold your cards close to your chest when it comes to your motivations, passions and excitement, as if you were to get too excited then something would go wrong. Come on, Virgo: you know thatâ€™s not the right approach. Let yourself believe that good things can happen.Â

As the sun enters Taurus, youâ€™ll feel a push to believe in yourself more. Make this a month of empowerment, of honing your routines to feel like your best possible self. Itâ€™s a good time to shake things up a little; seeing a new perspective can be uncomfortable but will prove immensely helpful in your journey.Â

Libra

23 September to 22 October

Brace for irritation, Libra â€“ the people closest to you are getting on your nerves this month. Mercury retrograde means misunderstandings are at an all-time high, and while youâ€™re trying to keep the peace, your patience is running thin. The way through this? Keep an open mind and do your best to clear up any confusion.Â

That irritation might start to morph into an itch to break free, but try not to make any rash decisions. Take a moment to think things through and have a conversation with the person at the heart of the issues to see how you can move forward. And have a ponder on whatâ€™s going on internally that makes you want to run for the hills. Fear of emotional intimacy, is that you? As the month goes on, youâ€™ll find it easier to open up.Â

Scorpio

23 October to 21 November

Usually your vibe is all about being cool, calm and collected. Thatâ€™s not the case this month. Youâ€™re flustered, accident-prone and aggravated. The best way to deal with this is to slow down. What can you do to restore your inner balance? How can you adjust your routine to better handle the ups and downs? Make tranquillity your focus word for April.

Towards mid-month, there will be a focus on the important relationships in your life. Whether romantic or platonic, you will notice that there may be a disconnect between you and the people you care about. Your mind is on some issues at home, with your family or some personal emotional frustration. Scorpio, you canâ€™t avoid dealing with this situation. If youâ€™re having a hard time working through this, ask for some help.Â

Sagittarius

22 November to 21 December

Youâ€™re in the mood to explore and have fun this month. Go for it! Try new things, follow your interests and do what brings you joy. But try to be considerate of other people in your life at the same time; donâ€™t bulldoze, no matter how tempting that might be. Compromise and collaboration are key. Remember, Sagittarius: it doesnâ€™t always have to be your way or bust.Â

The full moon towards the end of the month will bring situations that have been under your nose to your attention. Donâ€™t be alarmed: tune back into the routines and rituals that keep you steady and remember the end goal. Itâ€™ll all be worth it when you get what youâ€™ve been hoping for.Â

Capricorn

22 December to 19 January

Your home life is chaotic right now. Breaking glassware, plumbing issues, annoying housematesâ€¦ you name it, youâ€™re experiencing it. A lot of this is coming from clumsiness and bad communication, but it feels like a rain cloud is perpetually over your home space. You probably feel this way because you know itâ€™s more than just bad communication and absent-mindedness causing this chaos. Thereâ€™s an emotional blockage. We know getting vulnerable isnâ€™t your thing, Capricorn, but sometimes itâ€™s necessary.Â

The solar eclipse will push you on that need to dig deeper emotionally. Ever heard of the quote â€œas above, so belowâ€? Often when the exterior world feels hectic, itâ€™s a reflection of inner turmoil. We get so distracted emotionally that we cause mayhem in our lives by being snappy, clumsy, forgetful. Whatâ€™s really eating you up inside? Get to the root of your feelings and youâ€™ll notice all the other stuff starts to smooth outÂ â€“ plus, youâ€™ll be better equipped to deal with all the ups and downs.Â

As Taurus season arrives, youâ€™ll be ready to let your hair down. Go for it, Capricorn. Fun is important, especially when youâ€™re holding on to stress. A touch of spontaneity at the end of the month can bring some luck and opportunity your way.Â

Aquarius

20 January to 18 February

Be warned, Aquarius: miscommunication is going to be a big theme for you this month. Your words and actions are being misinterpreted; your power is being read as intimidating; people are taking offence where none was intended. Work as hard as you can on communicating clearly, but try to give other people the opportunity to do the same. Youâ€™ll need to listen this month. As in, actually listen. Drop the defensiveness and hear what others are trying to tell you.Â

This mess will encourage you to ask where that tendency to put a wall up comes from. Youâ€™ll ask how you can start to take the wall down, brick by brick. Be patient with yourself and lean into this energy of self-realisation.Â

As you heal your inner self, youâ€™ll want to heal your home life and closest relationships, too. Thereâ€™s been a disconnect there, right? Taurus season is a great time to work on that. This wonâ€™t be an easy process, but itâ€™s well worth it.Â Â

Pisces

19 February to 20 March

Pisces, youâ€™re usually so great at going with the flow. So why are you so rigidly holding on to certain ideas and beliefs that youâ€™ve now outgrown? Doing this could be holding you back from exciting opportunities. Itâ€™s time for you to accept that people grow and changeÂ â€“ including you.Â

Do you doubt that youâ€™re ready for big things? Do you worry youâ€™re not worthy? April will be a moment for you to realise you are equipped for it all. Once that realisation hits, security can settle in. Let yourself believe in your ability and good things will happen. The 11th is looking like an especially great day for big ideasÂ â€“ keep a notepad handy to write any down.Â

Once youâ€™ve done that deep emotional work, itâ€™s time to live it. Think about ways to integrate this new mindset into everyday life. Communicate with others about your ideas and do it comfortably. Connecting with like-minded people will make this process super enjoyable.Â
