item.title: The Sweet East: a fantastical spin on the coming of age tale for a modern world
item.description: New England becomes a wacky, weird, wonderful fantasmagoria in the new Talia Ryder film.
item.dc:creator: Meg Walters
item.content:encoded:
Part coming-of-age indie, part sweeping fantasy, The Sweet East is a dizzyingly fantastical trip down a very modern rabbit hole into the curiouser and curiouser world of contemporary America. Weird and wonderful, artful and ugly, this debut feature from cinematographer Sean Price Williams offers a damning verdict on a splintered America, as seen through the eyes of a girl who never really seems to know quite what sheâ€™s looking at.

The Sweet East, which stars Talia Ryder (Do Revenge), Ayo Edebiri (The Bear, Bottoms) and Jacob Elordi (Saltburn, Priscilla) is a deft play on the classic literary trope known as the Heroâ€™s Journey. The film adheres to the recognisable structure: a daring protagonist (usually a knight of some description) embarks on a quest, leaving behind all that is familiar in favour of lands unknown, meeting an array of larger-than-life characters who help or hinder them along the way. Itâ€™s a framework that has been updated, tweaked and feminised before: Alice In Wonderland, The Wizard of Oz, even David Bowieâ€™s cult classic Labyrinth.Â

The Sweet East follows in this tradition. We follow our heroine, Lillian, a listless, quiet high school senior from North Carolina, as she sets off on a journey across the northeastern coast of America, meeting an array of increasingly strange oddballs from niche subcultures along the way. During a school trip to Washington, she falls into the company of a punk Marxist group, before meeting a creepy neo-Nazia academic, a couple of pretentious indie filmmakers and a lonely Vermont farmer. Like any good coming-of-age drama, The Sweet East lets Lillian try on new personas, learning from and mimicking the people she encounters. She assumes the role of violent leftist vigilante with ease; she morphs into a ribbon-bedecked Lolita, playacting naive sexuality with the frustrated neo-Nazi, Lawrence; she transforms next into a budding starlet who parties the night away, flirts with her famous co-star and giddily graces the covers of tabloids; she willingly assumes the role of beautiful prisoner in the Vermont farmhouse.

The Sweet East is a dizzyingly fantastical trip

As the ever-transformational Lillian, Ryder presents us with a girl who is listless and uninformed. Her opinions about what she sees and hears are kept quiet â€“ that is, if she has any opinions at all. Her rare contributions consist of mocking and sardonic smiles. Ryderâ€™s performance is subtly, quietly drawn, although the character herself is frustratingly blurred at the edges.

The characters she meets along the way are all superbly, precisely crafted caricatures. Edebiri brings her signature wit and humour to the role of Molly, an affected film director. The perfectly cast Elordi oozes charm and charisma as Ian, â€œthe nationâ€™s crushâ€ and a rather dim actor. Rish Shah (who previously appeared alongside Ryder in Do Revenge) gives an affecting, unsettling turn as the soulful, proprietary Mohammad.

In a classic Heroâ€™s Journey tale, the hero always succeeds: against all odds, they vanquish their enemies, they achieve their goal, they reach their destination. But in the fractured, straining modern America of The Sweet East, this tidy conclusion doesnâ€™t quite work â€“ instead, our heroine has, it seems, no clear goal, no set destination. And so, she floats into an ever weirder and wackier world that eventually loses its grip on reality altogether â€“ Vermont is transformed into a landscape painting; Lillian sees a cartoon image through the barrel of a gun; she winds up at a fantastical monkâ€™s castle on a windswept cliff.

Â She floats into an ever weirder and wackier world

Lillian is a modern-day Alice. But instead of rising above the madness and clamouring back out of the rabbit hole, you get the sense that the madness she has seen has seeped into her very core. The Sweet East is a beautiful trip of a film that captures the sheer oddness of growing up as a woman today in a world of bizarre political leanings and inexplicable obsessions â€“ a world where people are increasingly cocooned in their own little worlds. In Williamsâ€™ portrait of America, it is a society on the verge of mental breakdown â€“ and it seems that, having grown up in this chaos, his heroine can only dive in headfirst.

The Sweet East comes to cinemas on 29 March 2024.

Images courtesy of Utopia

item.title: The â€˜kitty cutâ€™ is set to be this yearâ€™s biggest hair trend â€“ hereâ€™s how to get the look
item.description: In the market for a hair refresh? The â€˜kitty cutâ€™ has been hailed the hair trend of 2024, thanks to its choppy finish and low-maintenance styling.
item.dc:creator: Hanna Ibraheem
item.content:encoded:
The demand for bob haircuts is showing no sign of abating, with blunt, baroque, Italian and collarbone bobs all dominating hair trends at the moment. And it doesnâ€™t stop there. The mixie cut is already up there with 2024â€™s edgiest trends, while long bangs are set to rise in popularity.

But the haircut set to dominate the year? Meet the â€˜kitty cutâ€™. Great for those in that awkward growing-out-my-bob phase, itâ€™s a mid-length haircut that involves tons of layers. Even better, your kitty cut is tailored to your hair texture, meaning it requires minimal styling for a low-maintenance approach.

Intrigued? We asked two experts â€“ Lucy Jones, hairstylist at Larry King, andÂ Louis Byrne, editorial artist at Lâ€™OrÃ©al Professionnel ParisÂ â€“ to break down everything about the trend. From how to style it to what to ask for in the salon chair, hereâ€™s all you need to know to nail the look.

What is the kitty cut?

â€œThe kitty cut is a version of the undone textured lob,â€ says Jones. â€œItâ€™s a great style if you are growing out a bob and adds subtle shape and extra volume. Creating longer layers and a chunky face frame can accentuate the cheekbones giving a feline effect to the eyes, hence the name.â€

How do you wear the kitty cut?

â€œThis cut is very versatile; it can be worn straight or curly,â€ says Byrne. â€œIt looks great with added volume and will give you the ultimate swish.â€

What is the best way to style the kitty cut?

â€œUndone and easy,â€ says Jones. â€œUse Larry Kingâ€™s My Nannaâ€™s Mousse, Â£22, to add plumpness and shine, using just your fingers to tease out natural texture under the hairdryer and finish with a mix of finishing cream and texture spray.â€

Byrne says: â€œIf you would like to wear this style straight I recommend blow-drying your hair using a round brush or a diffuser. I also like to use rollers and Lâ€™OrÃ©al Professionnel Tecni.Art Super Dust Powder, Â£18.55, for extra volume and bounce.

â€œIf you wish to wear this cut curly, simply apply oil to the ends of your hair before going in with the Lâ€™OrÃ©al Professionnel Steampod, Â£235, for a smooth finish. Ultimately your hair texture will bring out the best of this cut.â€

What should you ask for in the salon to achieve the kitty cut?

â€œThere are quite a few versions of the kitty cut, so any picture references would be recommended when going into the salon,â€ advises Jones.

Byrne adds:Â â€œEnsure you and your hairdresser are using the same language. Pick your top three images and use these as a guide for your stylist and let them advise you on how your hair texture will work best with the length and style.â€

This is where we come in. Hereâ€™s our round-up of kitty hair inspiration for your next appointmentâ€¦

item.title: Spending time in nature makes you a more authentic person â€“ a new study shows how
item.description: A new study shows how going outside can make you more authentic â€” both with others and with yourself.
item.dc:creator: Meg Walters
item.content:encoded:
If you spend a lot of time online, you might have seen the phrase â€œtouch grassâ€ cropping up in lengthy comment sections. Itâ€™s often used as a (not super-friendly) reminder to take a break from the toxic abyss of the internet and to get outside into the real worldÂ â€“ the implication being that, in spending too much time online, the individual has lost touch with the world outside their laptop screen.

While telling someone to â€œtouch grassâ€ may be a veiled insult, there is actually a bit of truth to itÂ â€“ as, according to a new study, getting outside into nature is one of the best ways to boost your authenticity and, yes, reconnect with the reality of being a human being.Â

If you work on a computer all day, you might find that you spend most of your time inside staring at a screen. At the end of a long day filled with blue light, email notifications and keyboard tapping, you might find yourself feeling strangely disconnectedÂ â€“ not only from the real people around you, but also with your own self. According to this study,Â we might all need to go touch grass, asÂ spending a little more time outside can help us get back in touch with our authentic selves. In turn, it can lead to a more authentic inner dialogue with ourselves and more authentic relationships with others.

We spoke toÂ Elle Mace, a Positive Psychology Coach, about the strong link between nature and authenticityÂ â€“ and why it matters.

What is authenticity, anyway?

Before getting into the study, letâ€™s talk about what psychologists mean when they talk about authenticity. When we think about someone who is â€œauthenticâ€, we tend to imagine someone who is good at simply being themselves â€“ someone who avoids putting on airs or acting out a role.

However, authenticity in psychology is a little more complex. It relates not only to expressing oneâ€™s true self, but also whether we are able to grasp and comprehend our own feelings, beliefs and desires. Further, it involves acting based on our values and needs despite societal pressures, and being open and honest in our relationships.

According to Mace, this kind of authenticity is vital to our personal happiness and to the health of our relationships.

â€œCultivating authenticity is important for personal well-being and fulfilment because it allows individuals to live in alignment with their true selves, fostering genuine connections, self-acceptance, and psychological resilience,â€ she says.

About the study

The study, published in the Journal of Personality and Social PsychologyÂ in January 2024, aimed to understand why nature and authenticity go hand in hand. They worked with the hypothesis that â€œnature fosters authenticityâ€ and that â€œauthenticity mediates the positive influence of nature on longer term psychological well-being (higher life satisfaction and meaning in life, lower depression, anxiety and stress)â€.

Researchers examined these four points by surveying 10,000 participants, evaluating their connection to nature, and compared the results to their personal sense of authenticity. They found thatÂ there was a clear link between nature connectedness, engagement in nature-related activities and authenticity.

Nature fosters authenticity

In a second study, the researchers compared people who lived in natural environments with those in urban environments. Once again, they found that natural habitats increased authenticity. A third study explored how spending time in nature could improve an individualâ€™s sense of inner authenticity, thus increasing personal satisfaction.Â

Why nature is linked to building authenticity

Ok, so the study shows that getting outside and, yes, touching grass can make us more authentic, both in our relationship with ourselves and with others â€“ but why?

Well, as you might have guessed, it gives us an opportunity to get back to the basics of our own humanity. With a break from the chaos of modern life, we get the chance to reconnect with who we are at our core. After all, you canâ€™t be honest with others if you canâ€™t be honest with yourself â€“ and getting outside helps you do just that.

â€œBeing in nature can facilitate the development of authenticity because it often provides a space for reflection, introspection and connection with oneâ€™s innermost thoughts and feelings,â€ Mace says. â€œAway from the distractions and pressures of daily life, nature encourages individuals to be present and tune into their authentic selves.â€

How can we all add some nature (and authenticity) into our lives?

Getting outside is one of the best ways to boost your own sense of authenticity â€“ but itâ€™s no secret that finding the time and space to get out into nature isnâ€™t always easy.

Mace suggests you make nature a priority in your schedule.Â

â€œPlan outdoor activities such as walks, hikes, picnics or simply spending time in a nearby park,â€ she says. Even if itâ€™s just ten minutes in a local park during your lunch break, it might help you reconnect with your inner, authentic self.

Itâ€™s also important to be mindful about how you engage with nature once youâ€™re out and about. â€œIncorporate mindfulness practices into everyday life,â€ she says. â€œMindful walkingÂ or taking a few moments to appreciate natureâ€™s beauty can help individuals connect with their authentic selves amid busy schedules and being around other peopleâ€™s noise.â€

Images: Getty

item.title: Women are falling into the â€˜exhaustion gapâ€™ at work â€“ here are 5 tips to tackle it
item.description: Women are more likely to experience burnout and overwhelming stress than men, in a phenomenon called the exhaustion gap. Charlotte Davies shares tips on how to break free.Â
item.dc:creator: Ellen Scott
item.content:encoded:
Ask a woman how she is and after the initial, cursory â€˜All great, thanks!â€™, youâ€™re likely to hear the word â€™tiredâ€™. Most of usÂ â€“ apart from those annoying people you know who are somehow always glowing and free of dark circlesÂ â€“ are bloody exhausted. Weâ€™re so busy rushing around and getting stuff done that weâ€™re in desperate need of proper rest, and when you chuck in all the issues we can face when it comes to sleep, the wiped-out cycle continues.Â

This, inevitably, affects our work. And work affects our exhaustion. Thereâ€™s another fun cycle for you.Â

Women, in particular, are hit hard by this. The exhaustion gap is a term that refers to the overwhelming impact of work (both in the office world and at home) exhaustion on women, pointing to stats that show women are more likely to experience burnout and stress as they juggle the demands of their careers with household and caregiving responsibilities. Weâ€™re struggling to find any semblance of work/life balance, with long, busy hours leaving us with little time or energy to do even the basics of self-care, let alone pursue our other goals.Â

â€œItâ€™s evident that women in the workplace experience higher levels of burnout and exhaustion than men,â€ LinkedIn career expert Charlotte Davies tells Stylist. â€œWeâ€™ve all felt the additional strain from the last few years, and while flexible working arrangements have been designed to help, our research still shows that one in five women believe that itâ€™s harder to achieve a work-life balance now compared to 20 years ago.

â€œWithout the right balance, burnout can occur, and if we donâ€™t spot the signs and tackle them early on, then our health can really suffer. Itâ€™s important to have open and transparent conversations about the help and support we need when things are getting too much, and know where to find the tools that will help better manage these particularly challenging periods in our lives.â€

How do we start to navigate the imbalance and tackle our tiredness? Davies shares five tips ahead.Â

Be open and honest when youâ€™re struggling

â€œItâ€™s much more beneficial to you and your employer to acknowledge when youâ€™re struggling and feeling overwhelmed, rather than suffering in silence,â€ Davies says. â€œHaving an open, honest conversation with your boss and coming up with a plan together can help to manage your workload and avoid the exhaustion gap.â€

Get comfortable saying â€˜noâ€™

Hereâ€™s a tough fact to swallow: you canâ€™t do everything. You canâ€™t just keep â€˜pushing throughâ€™ when your workload is too much to bear and you canâ€™t keep taking more and more on because youâ€™re a people-pleaser and perfectionist who just wants to be great at their job. Sometimes, you do have to say â€˜noâ€™ and â€˜Iâ€™ve got too much onâ€™. Sorry!

Davies notes: â€œNearly half (47%) of women who think itâ€™s more difficult to maintain a positive work-life balance now say that a â€˜grind cultureâ€™ is one of the key contributors to this, according to recent research commissioned by LinkedIn. Itâ€™s important to be able to set boundaries in both our work and personal lives to ensure we have time to rest and recover.â€

Find techniques to help you feel in control

â€œFinding the right tools can be instrumental in helping you keep calm and feel in control in tricky situations and also means youâ€™re more likely to be able to switch off after a stressful working day,â€ Davies suggests. â€œLinkedIn Learning courses such as Building Resilience, or Embracing Unexpected Change can set you off on the right foot.â€

You might also like to try mindful meditationÂ or block off time in your calendar just for strategising or repeating affirmations. Play around to find what works for you to help you feel less overwhelmed by your day-to-day tasks at work.Â

Make self-care a priority

Another fact that can be tricky to accept: you canâ€™t do your best work if youâ€™re not your best self. And in order to be your best, you need to look after yourself. That means getting enough sleep, taking time off, eating nourishing food, getting outdoors and consciously taking steps to manage your stress levels.Â

Davies recommends: â€œTry to commit to doing the things that make you feel that little bit less stressedÂ â€“ it can be something as small as a lunchtime walk around the block. The more you put into yourself, the more youâ€™ll be able to give to both your work and personal commitments.â€

Find the right place for you

â€œOften, managing your work-life balance, no matter the skills and techniques you put in place, can still be difficult if your workplace doesnâ€™t support it,â€ Davies tells us. â€œIf youâ€™ve tried some of the above and youâ€™re not satisfied with where you are, it could be time to start looking elsewhere. Using LinkedInâ€™s Job Search Filter can help you find companies that prioritise the work-life balance of their employees.â€

Want more advice on how to work better? Sign up to the How To Work email below.

item.title: â€œA 10-minute stretch routine cured my chronic back pain in just 4 weeks â€“ this is what it involvedâ€
item.description: Millions of us live with chronic backpain from rubbish work set-ups, but there are ways to ease the niggles that donâ€™t involve forking out for a chiropractor or dosing up on ibuprofen. Mollie Quirk found a free, quick and simple solution to her lower back issues in the form of a daily YouTube yoga practice.
item.dc:creator: Mollie Quirk
item.content:encoded:
These days, itâ€™s more unusual to say that you donâ€™tÂ have backache than you do. During the pandemic, we went from ergonomic office desks to working from our kitchen tablesÂ and sofasâ€¦ and four years on, many of us still donâ€™t have great at-home set ups for our hybrid routines. The result? Crunchy necks, screaming hips and sore lower backs.

My own backache began mid-lockdown. Iâ€™d been working between the sofa and a low vintage bureau and by summer 2020, my breakfasts were laced with paracetamol or ibuprofen. That continued for years, and while I was still functional, I became aware that I was relying on painkillers to simply function. Clearly, something needed to changeÂ â€“ and that something had to be my posture.

Itâ€™s not a unique story; back in 2020,Â BupaÂ found that 11 million people were suffering with new aches and pains due to working from home. Fast forward four years, and almost a million people in UK are now too sick to work because of back or neck issues, with the welfare bill for dealing with back suffers costing Â£1.4bn a yearÂ â€“ up 25% compared with before the pandemic.Â

Back pain isnâ€™t just an inconvenienceÂ â€“ itâ€™s life disrupting. It stops you from working well, exercising properly, socialising regularly. And we still donâ€™t treat it seriously.

Back pain isnâ€™t an inconvenience â€“ itâ€™s life disrupting

The most obvious first step, if your work station is to blame, is to sort out your working environment. So, I began by investing in a new desk and office chair. Out went my lovely cow print number and in came a pink mesh orthopaedic chair and and table that allowed me to work more efficiently. Weirdly, however, the pain didnâ€™t subside â€“despite my posture naturally improving.

So, I decided that something more drastic needed to happen: a 30-day fitness challenge focusing on posture and back strengthening.

To get a steer on the sorts of things I should be trying, I chatted to Adam Byrne, a physiotherapist at Bupa Health Clinics. He explained that poor posture can lead to muscle imbalance which results in pain throughout the back. If you sit with one leg under the other, you inevitably end up lop-sidedâ€¦ which might put more pressure on one glute, one side of the spine, one shoulder etc.

After being prescribed a handful of exercises, I scoured the internet for more posture-correcting exercises and stretches to try. After being bombarded with an array of results, I decided to focus on two different techniques from two different experts.Â

Emi Wong was the first YouTuber I stumbled across. With almost 5 million subscribers and thousands of comments boasting success from her tips and tricks, how could I not give her advice a go? But then I then found AskDoctorJoâ€™s YouTube channel and was instantly drawn in by the array of videos she had posted on back pain. With almost 2 million subs, she was a definite contender.

I decided to alternate between Emi and Jo for the first two days to see which technique and sets of exercises suited me best and what worked efficiently and quickly.

On day one, I tried Joâ€™s routine but it just didnâ€™t work for me â€“ I found the videos long-winded and tricky to understand, especially as a fitness novice. I jumped straight into Emiâ€™s video after watching five minutes of Jo, and was instantly drawn in with the way she taught the exercises. I was able to understand with ease and found that I could do the exercises alongside her.

So, what is Emi Wongâ€™s Fix Your Posture in 10 MinutesÂ all about? There are 10 different exercises that last for 50 seconds each, with a 10-second rest between each exercise. Itâ€™s so easy to follow that by the end of week one, I no longer needed to watch the video during my workoutÂ â€“ I could just listen as I moved.Â

The first time I completed the full workout, I was absolutely exhausted. But by the time week one had come to a close, I was in the swing of things and felt rejuvenated and refreshed. The movements soon became second nature, and each day, my back felt a little better.

By the end of the entire month of following Emiâ€™s routine, I was shocked at how far I had come. After work every day, I would stop for a break before heading to my room to practise this routine after four weeks, was almost pain-free. I still do the routine every day and will probably continue to do so for the foreseeable future because it actually works.Â

Even taking a one-minute break from my desk in the middle of the day to do one of these exercises for 50 seconds has proved to be a game changer. So, what are you waiting for?

Â After four weeks, I was almost pain-free

The 10-minute posture-fixing workout

Chest opener

  1. Sit on the floor cross-legged
  2. Bring your hands behind your head, elbows out openÂ
  3. Now close your elbows so they end up pointing ahead of you â€“ squeezing your shoulder blades together
  4. Repeat for 50 seconds

My arms did feel a little heavy at first but after about day four, my arms felt stronger and more supple, which made the exercise easier.

Wall slideÂ

  1. Sit cross-legged with your back flat against the wall
  2. Raise your arms above your head with them also flat on the wall
  3. You then slide your arms down the wall, bending your elbows
  4. Repeat for 50 seconds

Glute bridge

  1. Lying on the floor, bend your knees and place your feet about an inch from your bum
  2. Keeping your head and shoulders fixed, raise your bum and core so that your pelvis is in the air
  3. Either keep your arms flat on the ground next to you, or lace your fingers under your back
  4. Stay in position for 30 seconds, then bring your butt back down

All four twist

  1. Go into table top (on hands and knees)
  2. Keeping one hand on the ground, twist the opposite side and raise the other arm as you do so
  3. Look up to the sky, pause for 25 seconds then switch sides
  4. If you want to make this more tricky, alternate between left to right every few seconds

Ab stretch

As a big fan of yoga, I was already familiar with the ab stretch because itâ€™s almost exactly the same as the classic cobra pose.Â

  1. Lie on your front with your forearms resting on the ground
  2. Extend to raise your chest and core, stretching your stomach and back as you look up to the ceiling

Down dog twist

Much like the downward facing dog, this twist exercise really pulls on your back â€“ which is such a great feeling after being hunched over a laptop all day.Â

  1. Start off standing
  2. Bending the knees, lean forwards to bring your hands to the floor and walk them forward until youâ€™re in a kind of triangle with your bum in the air, your arms straight and your knees softly bent
  3. Take your right hand off the floor and stretch to touch your left toes (keeping your other hand firmly on the ground)
  4. Hold for 25 seconds
  5. Now go back to downward dog and repeat on the other side for 25 seconds

Back squeeze pulse

  1. Lie on your stomach with your chest and core slightly raised.Â
  2. Move your arms out in front of you then bring them back and squeeze your shoulder blades together in a pulsating movement for three repetitions
  3. Moving your arms back and forth, continuing the process for 50 seconds.Â

Swimmers

Back swimming takes a lot of stamina and can feel exhausting, but itâ€™s such a good exercise for your back and core.Â

  1. Lying on your belly, start with your legs and arms outstretched
  2. Slowly start to mimic breast stroke, by making circles with your arms and legs
  3. Repeat for 50 seconds

With this move you can really feel your shoulders rotating and your back squeezing in the middle.Â

Cat cow

Lastly, the cat cow is a really great move to end on. This exercise releases almost all the tension built up throughout the workout.

  1. In table top position, round your back and bend the neck so that youâ€™re looking towards your belly button
  2. Breath deeply before retracting the shoulders and looking up to the ceiling
  3. Repeat five times

Images: Getty

item.title: Is it better to increase reps or weight when strength training? We asked the experts
item.description: Not sure what the next step in your strength training journey should look like? We asked two personal trainers whether itâ€™s better to increase your reps or weights, and how to tell when itâ€™s time to make that jump.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Geall
item.content:encoded:
The world of strength training can get pretty complex, especially when it comes to deciding how you structure your workouts. Like most sports, there are multiple ways to approach your training depending on your goals and personal preference â€“ and that includes whether youâ€™re going to prioritise weight or reps.

While it can be tempting to try to lift as heavy as possible, struggling to complete one rep probably isnâ€™t going to help you build strength in the long run. The same is true on the opposite end of the spectrum: while opting for a weight you can overhead press for hours might make you feel accomplished, itâ€™s probably not going to do much.

Ultimately, you want to find a sweet spot between the two. But does that mean prioritising one over the other, at least to begin with? And if so, how can you tell when itâ€™s time to increase both your weights and your reps?Â

What are the benefits of increasing reps when strength training?Â

While strength training is all about priming your muscles to support heavier loads, there are benefits to increasing the number of reps you do in a session â€“ including when it comes to endurance and overall fitness.

â€œWorking in a higher rep range helps to improve the ability of your muscles to perform over an extended period,â€ explains Ali Malik, a personal trainer and founder of Fit Labs Kensington. â€œPerforming more reps with shorter rest intervals can also elevate your heart rate and enhance cardiovascular conditioning.â€

Because increasing your reps typically requires you to drop the amount of weight youâ€™re dealing with, this style of strength training can also provide benefits for joint and ligament health, explains Amanda Place, a personal trainer and founder of Sculptrition.

â€œIt also helps you to build resilience, not only in your workouts but in various aspects of life, as you have to push through fatigue,â€ she adds. â€œIntegrating a range of rep schemes into your training can help you to achieve a well-rounded and effective weight training regimen.â€

And thatâ€™s not forgetting that high-rep routines can also help to reduce the risk of injury that comes with lifting heavier weights, because youâ€™ll be more in control of your movements.Â Â

What are the benefits of increasing weight when strength training?Â

Thereâ€™s something particularly satisfying about being able to up the dumbbell size you use in your workouts, and being ambitious with the weights you use can offer plenty of benefits. That is, if you do it gradually.

â€œIncreasing the weight you are lifting is known in training terms as progressive overload,â€ Malik explains. â€œThis is a fundamental principle in strength training and exercise science that involves gradually increasing the demands placed on your muscles, typically by lifting heavier weights or increasing resistance overtime.â€

The benefits associate with this progressive increase in weights are numerous, including increased strength, and muscular hypertrophy, or growth.Â

Itâ€™ll also help you develop power and explosiveness â€“ something youâ€™ll want for sports that require sudden movements â€“ and can even stimulate the development of stronger bones. This is why strength training is such a good form of exercise for women both pre- and post-menopause, who are at greater risk of osteoporosis due to their changing hormones.

â€œProgressive overload also requires increased joint stability and muscle activation, which can help to protect against joint injuries and enhance overall joint health,â€ Malik adds.Â

Is it better to increase reps or weight?Â

The right decision for you will largely depend on the goal youâ€™re trying to achieve, as well as the stage youâ€™re at in your training.Â

Place explains: â€œIf you aim to maximise muscle size and strength, lifting heavier weights with lower repetitions is the preferred approach, as it promotes hypertrophy and significant muscle growth. On the other hand, increasing the number of reps with lighter weights is more effective for improving muscular endurance.â€

In most cases, both experts say itâ€™s usually beneficial to incorporate a mix of both approaches into your training. This is a process known as periodisation, where you go through cycles in your training â€“ in this case, it would be training with lower weights and higher reps (known as a hypertrophy or volume phase) and training with heavier weights and lower reps (known as a strength phase).

A balanced approach can also prevent you from reaching a plateau in your training, which can take a toll on your motivation levels. Ultimately, you just want to make sure youâ€™re always being challenged.Â

How to tell when you should increase your reps and weightÂ

Want to switch up your strength training, but not sure whether youâ€™re ready to up your reps or weight? Malik recommends considering the following three things:

  • Are you breezing through your reps?

â€œIf you are making the deadlifts with ease, you may not be challenging yourself enough,â€ Malik says. â€œEvery strength training program has specific goals that determine the weight, reps and sets to undertake for each exercise. Hitting the top of your rep range during your sets with proper form can be a sign to go up in weight.â€

  • Are you seeing results?

â€œThe goals set for your strength training class should dictate how heavy you can lift and the way to achieve it,â€ he says. â€œThere are different ways to achieve your fitness goals other than increasing your weight, such as increasing the number of reps. However, if you have been hitting the gym without much progress, it may be time to consider increasing weight to align with your fitness goals.â€

  • Is your form flawless?

â€œAll the weight increase hype may be futile if the body isnâ€™t ready to handle the extra kilos,â€ Malik explains. â€œYou may need to ensure that your form is perfect, allowing you to perform the specific exercise safely. The effects of increasing weight without proper form may result in serious injuries, especially for strength-building exercises that may put a strain on your spine.

â€œHaving great form allows you to record consistent progress over time. You may choose to record yourself as you do the sets to identify areas you may be doing wrong. Stagnating at the same weight over several weeks can slow down your fitness journey. Knowing when to add weight to your exercises is a critical part of your strength training programme.â€Â

Images: Getty

item.title: This 10-minute workout is designed to boost your energy levels with just 3 simple moves
item.description: Feeling exhausted or lethargic? Strength training gets your blood flowing, increases your heart rate and releases endorphins â€“ all of which can help you to feel more energised.
item.dc:creator: Chloe Gray
item.content:encoded:
A high-octane workout might be the last thing on your mind when feeling more lethargic than a sloth. But did you know that the endorphin rush that comes from smashing out a sweaty session actually boosts energy levels too?Â

In the short term, it gets the blood and oxygen circulating around the body to make you feel more alert. But regular exercise has also been shown to increase energy by 20% while decreasing fatigue by as much as 65%, according to a study from the journal Psychotherapy and Psychosomatics.Â

This full-body circuit works you from head to toe, including the heart â€“ which means you might just be able to make it through the day without a nap.

Dumbbell Renegade Row

  1. Get into a plank position, with arms directly under shoulders and body in a straight line (donâ€™t let the hips sit too high or sink too low).Â
  2. Hold a dumbbell in each hand.Â
  3. Bend your left arm, bringing the weight up to your chest, so that your elbow is at a 90-degree angle.Â
  4. Squeeze the shoulder blades together at the top of the move, before slowly lowering the weight back down. Repeat on the opposite arm, while keeping the hips complete still (try not to rock them).

Do 20 reps

Dumbbell Thruster

  1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and rest the dumbbells on top of your shoulders (arms bent).Â
  2. Bend your knees to come into a squat â€“ making sure that your weight is in the heels and not the toes.
  3. Â Check to make sure that your knees also arenâ€™t going past the front of your toes.Â
  4. Drive back up to standing position and as you extend upward, straighten your arms above your head.Â
  5. Return the dumbbells to your shoulders as you squat back down.

Do 10 reps

Russian Kettlebell Swing

  1. Stand with feet hip-width apart and grip theÂ kettlebell handle with both hands â€“ placing it in between your legs with your arms hanging straight.Â
  2. To swing the kettlebell, squat slightly and swinging the kettlebell through the legs slightly, then thrusting the hips forward.Â
  3. The momentum from your hip thrust will carry the kettlebell upward, until it reaches straight out in front of you at eye level (arms become parallel to your chest at the height of this move). If you can swing the weight higher than eye level, you need to use a heavier kettlebell.Â
  4. The kettlebell will naturally swing back downward (while arms remain straight) and will fall back in between your legs as you return to starting position (slight squat).Â

Do 10 reps.

Rest for 60 seconds. Complete 3 rounds of entire set.

Images: Stylist

item.title: Sleep versus exercise: should you work out or take a nap if youâ€™re feeling sluggish and tired?
item.description: Hereâ€™s how to tell whether youâ€™d benefit from more sleep or a dose of exercise.
item.dc:creator: Kat Storr
item.content:encoded:
To nap or not to nap? That is the question I ask myself pretty much every day when my brain and body feel sluggish in the middle of the afternoon.

Itâ€™s natural for our circadian rhythm (the 24-hour process that regulates your sleep-wake cycle) to dip after lunch, and thatâ€™s what leads to low energy. But there are also other reasons why you might feel the need to lie down and close your eyes, like broken sleep or eating dinner late at night.

In a bid to combat this tiredness, it can become second nature to make yet another cup of coffee or reach for a sugary snack. But those solutions, at best, act as sticking plasters. At worst, they can exacerbate fatigue by keeping you up at nightÂ â€“ leaving you feeling tired again the next afternoon.Â

Iâ€™m lucky enough to work for myself from home and have childcare sorted until 5pm most days, which means if Iâ€™m hit by fatigue, I can close my eyes for a short time. Iâ€™ve become well-known among family and friends for my love of a good â€˜Kat napâ€™.

Years of working shifts and early mornings means I can drop off at pretty much any time of day and, as long as itâ€™s not for too long, I usually wake up feeling refreshed. But, is a nap the right choice for coping with afternoon sluggishness? Or should I be using this time to get my blood flowing and muscles working instead?Â

Benefits of exercise for energy and focus

Thereâ€™s no right or wrong way to tackle tiredness and naps certainly donâ€™t work for everyone. But thereâ€™s plenty of science to suggest that movement can help us to feel more invigorated. 

Jeff Kahn, CEO and co-founder of sleep and energy-tracking app Rise Science, tells Strong Women that he believes exercising outdoors might hold the key to beating the 3pm slump: â€œTaking a walk and getting outside is great for getting light during the day, which is an often overlooked part of sleep and circadian health. It will also help with blood flow in your body and â€˜wake upâ€™ your muscles and brain.â€

The benefits of exercising for both mind and body are undeniable. â€œEver since I started working out regularly, I havenâ€™t felt tired at all,â€ says formerly tired travel writer Helen Iatrou. â€œQuite the opposite: it gives me a huge surge of energy.â€

In fact, a few of the women I chat to anecdotally cite naps as something that make them feel even more tired â€“ and workouts leave them feeling more alert. Iâ€™m the same: after choosing a workout over a nap, the endorphins released give me the energy I need to get through bath and bedtime with the kids. All that physical exertion also definitely helps me to sleep better. 

Since I started working out regularly, I havenâ€™t felt tired

Helen Iatrou

But finding the motivation to exercise after work or when youâ€™re tired can be really hard, especially during the winter months when itâ€™s cold and dark at 4pm. This is something mother-of-two Vicky says she struggles with: â€œI (usually) choose to nap, but often regret it. Iâ€™m not sure that Iâ€™ve ever regretted a workout. But my god, itâ€™s hard to feel motivated to move when the alternative is a good nap.â€Â

Benefits of napping for an energy reboot

There are times when your body may really need to rest and recuperate, especially if youâ€™re struggling with ongoing sleep deprivation or illness. This is when a daytime nap, even just for 20 minutes, could really help.

Sophie Elletson, lead nutritionist at Future Woman, believes a nap can be more beneficial for women than exercise. She explains that if your cortisol levels spike too much, it can destabilise the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis (the communication pathway between the brain and the pituitary and adrenal glands), which can then down-regulate your reproductive hormones.Â

â€œThis is why women who over-exercise can lose their periods,â€ she says. â€œSo, we always encourage clients to focus on gentler forms of exercise like walking, yoga or pilates when theyâ€™re feeling stressed and overwhelmed. A gentle walk outside is ideal for that afternoon slump.â€Â

But Elletson maintains that sleep is the best way to stabilise your HPA axis. Napping is a great way of calming the system, while aiming for a minimum of seven hours sleep a night.Â

Kahn agrees: â€œSleeping during the day can help you boost your energy levels and reduce your sleep debt without having to go to bed early. However, naps that are too long can lead to sleep inertia. In contrast, short power naps of 10-20 minutes can help you feel energised when you wake up.â€

Which is better for energy â€“ exercise or sleep?

Napping and exercising both have clear benefits for our mental and physical wellbeing. And being able to do either in the afternoon is a massive luxury that many of us just donâ€™t have. But perhaps for those of us who do WFH a few days a week, maybe 2024 should be the year that we prioritise downing tools in the afternoon for a brief energy-booster â€“ whether weâ€™re running, jumping or napping.

Images: Getty

item.title: â€œNot being able to swim was my dirty secret â€“ hereâ€™s how I conquered my fear before turning 40â€
item.description: Millions of UK adults canâ€™t swim, but it turns out a fear of water can be tackled in as little as 13 hours, writes Lauren Potts.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Potts
item.content:encoded:
When was the last time you felt a real sense of achievement? That lightning bolt rush of adrenaline, joy and disbelief that comes with conquering something that, at one point, seemed insurmountable? Mine was last month when, at the age of 39, I swam 25 metres for the first time in my life.

Some people conquer marathons or mountains, but my Everest has always been the swimming pool. When I was a child, a teacher let go of me in the water and I panicked and sank. I can still picture how annoyed he was when I re-emerged, spluttering and crying. Without encouragement or support, I remained in the shallow end, clinging to the side, while my friends progressed to the deep end and dived for bricks. To complete my embarrassment, my mum had won a fancy Slazenger swimsuit, making me the best-dressed learner who couldnâ€™t even doggy-paddle a width.Â

That fear may have taken root in a pool in Cumbria sometime in the early 90s, but instead of tackling it, I simply avoided swimming for 30 years and being a non-swimmer became my dirty secret. I missed out on birthday parties and school trips, lazing in hotel pools and drifting in the sea on holiday. I told myself that I â€œcouldnâ€™t floatâ€ â€“ something Iâ€™d heard my parents say â€“ and adopted the reason myself, adding to the family myth that we were scientific anomalies that defied the laws of physics.

It wasnâ€™t until I was on my honeymoon in 2022, when I looked at the Caribbean sea from the safety of my sun lounger, that I thought maybe I was missing out by not frolicking in the turquoise waters. I began to question the narrative Iâ€™d been pedalling for three decades: could I really not float and learn to swim? Or had I simply never faced my fear?Â Â

I decided I didnâ€™t want to hit 40 having never learned a skill that most people master as children â€“ which is how, six months later, I found myself back in the shallow end. Only this time, I was a 38-year-old in armbands convinced I was going to drown in knee-high water.

I may have felt ridiculous to be learning to swim as an adult, but Iâ€™m certainly not alone in trying to do so. According to Swim England, one in three people over 16 in England canâ€™t swim 25m unaided, and about 50,000 adults are learning. Thatâ€™s an amazing stat, given that â€“ according to counsellor Georgina Sturmer â€“ adults tend to avoid activities that scare us.

â€œAs children we are often given the opportunity â€“ or are required â€“ to try new things, to face our fears, to push ourselves out of our comfort zone. Yet as adults, we usually have the power to say no, to sit back on the sidelines if we are feeling frightened, to stay stuck in our existing patterns of behaviour and relationships,â€ Sturmer tells Strong Women. â€œThis might feel comforting, but it can also represent a missed opportunity to learn and grow, and to build new neural pathways that can help us to think differently.â€

It took some time before I began to feel positively about voluntarily putting myself in a position of possible death on a weekly basis. At first, I was useless. I had to google how to put a swimming cap on and my goggles kept filling with water. I snorted what felt like a pail of chlorine. One week, it took me 45 minutes to lean back on a foam noodle. At one point, my teacher declared I was â€œin discord with the waterâ€, to which I tersely replied: â€œYes, since about 1991.â€Â Â

It took me 45 minutes to lean back on a foam noodle

My progress felt agonisingly slow and I wondered how I would ever go from clutching a float to being free of one. Then in week 17, the decision was made for me when my teacher physically prised it from my hands and told me I was ready. I didnâ€™t wholly believe her, but I also realised the only way I was ever going to do it was by telling myself I could. In a literal sink-or-swim moment, I pushed off the side and, for the first time, I swam unaided. I was practically euphoric.

Mindset psychologist Dr Rebekah Wanic says my breakthrough came from realising that I needed to think differently about the situation.Â Â

â€œOur beliefs about what we can and canâ€™t accomplish influence what we will and will not do. A big part of working towards a meaningful goal is believing there are things you can do to get yourself closer to it,â€ she says. â€œWhen you realise your mindset is either facilitating you in achieving your goals in life or holding you back, and you learn to have control over it, you are so powerful.â€

Once I realised that I could swim, that I could float, that I wasnâ€™t necessarily going to drown, my attitude shifted. As someone motivated by goals, I began to set myself targets to swim 5m, then 10m, 15m and 25m. Within weeks, I had not only achieved them all but bought the rainbow-coloured badges meant for children to prove it. Each achievement left me punching the air, sometimes even eliciting a clap from the lifeguard or a â€œwell doneâ€ from a fellow swimmer.

But as proud as I am of my progress, I regret not tackling it sooner. I regret that I waited until I was almost 40 to fix something that, all told, was conquered in about 13 hours. Milestone birthdays often trigger a sense of reflection, says Sturmer, which is no bad thing. In fact, it can be the opposite.Â

â€œIt can add a sense of urgency, and spur us on to create a goal that we really want to achieve by a certain age,â€ she explains. â€œThis can be a powerful and helpful motivational tool.â€

Sturmer reassures me that my three decades of dithering are a pretty normal response to fear â€“ a defence mechanism to protect myself because of the fear I experienced as a child. Better yet, all the excuses Iâ€™ve made have been necessary steps on the path to change, adds Wanic, because without them, I wouldnâ€™t have needed to confront them and set the goal in the first place.

â€œSometimes we think: If I had dealt with this earlier, I wouldnâ€™t have missed out. Everybody has experiences where theyâ€™ve wasted time or not confronted things; thatâ€™s a natural part of life,â€ says Wanic. â€œBut once you recognise that, you can let that define you or you can use it as motivation. Let the twinge of regret show up â€“ but donâ€™t let it just sit there, because all itâ€™s going to do is prevent you from moving forward.â€

As for my next goal, thereâ€™s a 50m badge with my name on it. And yes, to those wondering, I might even sew it onto my swimsuit.Â Â

Images: Getty; courtesy of the author

item.title: â€œMy stress and anxiety regularly leave me drained â€“ what changes can I make to have more energy?â€
item.description: In this weekâ€™s Sleep Diaries, a 26-year-old journalist finds out how reimagining her morning routine could help her to cope with heightened stress and anxiety.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Geall
item.content:encoded:
Welcome back to Stylistâ€™s Sleep Diaries, where we take a deep dive into one of the most important (and elusive) factors in our day-to-day lives: sleep. To help us understand more about it, we invite women to share their habits with our sleep expert Dr Nerina Ramlakhan for analysis.Â Â

About me

Age:Â 26

Occupation: Journalist

How much water do you drink on average per day?Â 6-8 glasses

How much caffeine do you drink on average per day?Â 2 cups of coffee

What time do you go to bed at night? Around midnight.

What time do you wake up in the morning? Between 6am and 8am.Â

How often do you exercise?Â I do lots of walking every day but only go to the gym around once a week at the moment to do some cardio as Iâ€™m pretty busy.

Do you eat breakfast within 60 minutes of rising? Yes.

My story

â€œMy levels of stress and anxiety are heightened at the moment and itâ€™s taking itâ€™s toll on my sleep and energy levels. For the last year Iâ€™ve found I either fall into a deep sleep and wake up feeling tired or sleep lightly and have lots of vivid dreams. These dreams arenâ€™t recurring but often involve tense situations where things are going wrong, so I feel anxious when I wake up.Â

â€œItâ€™s made a huge difference to my energy levels. Iâ€™d rate mine about a three out of 10 at the moment just because of how lethargic I feel: coffee has become an essential part of my day, because without caffeine I find it hard to muster the energy I need to do my job.

â€œWork is definitely a factor here: the amount of work I have on my plate can be challenging, and I take work home or do overtime in the office most weeks. That has a knock-on effect on my whole schedule, so I end up eating dinner late (between 8-9pm) and skipping the gym. In all honestly, some of my commitment to working overtime does come from a wish to quieten my stress and anxiety, because when Iâ€™ve got something to focus on its less present.

â€œAt the end of the day Iâ€™d love to feel more energised and rely less on caffeine â€“ Iâ€™m just not sure how to get to that point with my stress and anxiety draining me. Can you help?â€Â

So, what does it all mean? Sleep expert Dr Nerina Ramlakhan shares her thoughtsâ€¦

â€œIâ€™m glad youâ€™re taking time to eat breakfast as morning anxiety levels can worsen if you donâ€™t because your body starts to run on cortisol (and caffeine),â€ says sleep expert and physiologist Dr Ramlakhan. â€œAlong those lines, I hope youâ€™re eating before you have your cup of coffee â€“ if not, thatâ€™s a change Iâ€™d recommend.

â€œYou could really benefit from trying some simple stress management techniques and the one I would recommend is to start your morning with a simple breathing practice. You should try to do this before you dive into your day â€“ even before you look at your phone.

â€œTo get started, place your left hand on your belly just below your navel and the other hand over your heart. Simply notice the rise and fall of your breathing. Ideally, follow five inhales and five exhales while breathing through your nose. Gently experiment with making the exhales a little longer, sending them out through your lower body. This will help you to anchor yourself before you start your day.â€Â

She continues: â€œFor an even greater boost to energy and mood, add a simple minute journaling practice focusing on gratitude to this morning routine. What are you looking forward to today? What are you grateful for?

â€œScientific research shows that people who have a good morning routine tend to be more productive, have lower stress levels and are generally happier and more optimistic, so find what works for you and stick to it.â€Â

Images:Â Ami Oâ€™Callaghan; Dr Nerina Ramlakhan

item.title: 7 science-backed ways to relieve pain naturally, as recommended by GPs
item.description: Try these expert-recommended natural remedies and techniques instead of reaching for the painkillers.
item.dc:creator: Kerry Law
item.content:encoded:
Living with pain can be, wellâ€¦ a real pain. The throbbing agony of a headache, twisted ankle or period cramps can leave us doubled-up on the sofa, too distracted to do anything and feeling miserable. Sure, you can reach for some over-the-counter painkillers for a quick fix, but what if youâ€™ve already maxed out on your dose for the day or youâ€™d rather avoid drugs altogether?

Can you really find temporary relief from searing pain without reaching for the ibuprofen or paracetamol?

â€œMedication does have a role in helping people deal with pain signals, particularly when the pain is acute and can help with inflammation,â€ says pain expert Dr Amber Johnston, clinical psychologist and neuropsychologist at Healthy Mind Psychology. â€œBut many medications out there merely mask the pain, and if the pain is chronic or without a clear healing process, this medication can become addictive or ineffective.â€

Dr Johnston explains that pain is an important messaging system alerting the brain to a problem (eg â€˜remove hand from boiling waterâ€™). But inflammation also plays a role in ongoing or chronic pain: â€œCortisol is released whenever we need additional energy to deal with stress, and that includes when experiencing pain. We also understand that too much cortisol release can cause increased inflammation in our bodies, which can also send chemical alerts to our brain in the form of pain experiences.

â€œNatural ways to reduce inflammation â€“ everything from eating well, attempting to get enough sleep, moving our body and managing cortisol â€“ can all play a part, without reaching [straight] for the pills,â€ she adds.Â

7 drug-free ways to relieve pain, according to the expertsÂ

It goes without saying that relieving pain is only part of the solution. If pain persists or youâ€™ve picked up a longer-term injury, you should always consult a medical professional for a personalised treatment plan. For milder issues or immediate relief, however, here are seven pain-relieving remedies, as recommended by medical experts.

Freeze pain with the RICE method for sports injuries

Ice is your friend here. Cold therapy has been used in pain management for decades due to its ability to reduce inflammation by decreasing blood flow. But you donâ€™t have to head to your nearest (and often expensive) cyrotherapy chamber to reap the injury-soothing benefits. Dr Vishal Aggarwal, of Healthium Clinics, recommends using the RICE method (rest, ice, compression, elevation) to relieve pain from sprains and strains.

He says: â€œRest the area, applying an ice pack for 15-20 minutes every two hours during the first 48 hours to reduce swelling, while using a barrier to prevent direct contact with skin. Compression with a bandage helps control inflammation, but not so tight that blood flow is restricted. Elevation of the injured limb reduces swelling and promotes blood flow.â€Â

Soothe pain with heat

Thereâ€™s science behind hugging a hot water bottle when youâ€™re suffering from PMT. Applying heat to an affected area can help reduce pain by promoting blood flow and relaxing the muscles, in turn reducing painful muscle spasms.

If using the RICE method on a swollen injury, Dr Aggarwal recommends applying a heat pack approximately 72 hours afterwards.Â

Stimulate pain-relieving acupressure points

This arm of traditional Chinese medicine, based on the concept of â€˜qiâ€™ (or energy flow), has been used in pain management for centuries. But if you canâ€™t access an acupuncturist, you can stimulate acupressure points at home with no need for needles.

Acupuncturist Saffron PrettyÂ explains: â€œAn acupuncture point is a bundle of fibres, one of which is usually a nerve. You should press these points firmly with your thumb until they hurt, so you get a response from the nerve and, therefore, the brain.â€

She recommends you consult an acupuncturist for the most effective treatment as â€œpoints are not just specific to the condition but also the personâ€. However, as a generic pain reliever, Pretty suggests stimulating what are known as the four gates. â€œThis is an ancient combination of two points â€“ large intestine 4 (LI4 â€“ a point on the hand) and liver 3 (Liv3 â€“on the foot). Theyâ€™re often used to manage pain in childbirth and some dentists learn LI4 as itâ€™s also good for toothache.Â

â€œFind LI4 on the top of the hand, on the fleshy mound between the thumb and forefinger, close to the forefinger bone. Liv3 is on the top of the foot, between the tendons of the big toe and second toe.â€Â

Pretty recommends searching online for a visual guide to pinpoint the exact location.

Rinse with saltwater for mouth-related aches

Ulcers, swollen gums and toothache can often lead to off-the-chart levels of pain. Before you head to the dentist to investigate, temporary pain relief is possible via a basic store cupboard ingredient.

Dr Julia Coelho, dentist at The Door W4, explains: â€œA saltwater rinse can be extremely effective in treating inflammation, helping to ease pain and reducing the bacteria in the mouth and gums that causes the pain. Rinse with saltwater two to three times a day, especially after meals.â€Â

You can make a salt mouthwash by dissolving half a teaspoon of salt in a cup of warm water.

Reduce period pain with anti-inflammatory foods

Hannah Alderson, nutritionist, hormone specialist and founder of The Positive Method, says: â€œHerbs, foods and supplements with anti-inflammatory properties are the way to go.â€

However, Alderson adds that managing pain associated with periods and conditions such as endometriosis and PCOS requires a holistic approach involving diet, exercise and stress management: â€œShifting your body into a less inflamed state doesnâ€™t happen overnight. A bout of period pain is unlikely to be tamed quickly with one turmeric latte. Patience is key.â€ 

Becoming less inflamed doesnâ€™t happen overnight

Hannah Alderson

Aldersonâ€™s recommended foods to prioritise:

  • Turmeric: â€œTop of the list due its curcumin content â€“ a molecule famed for its ability to ease swelling and reduce inflammation, as well as support the reduction of free radical damage. Boost its effectiveness by consuming it alongside black pepper.â€
  • Green tea: â€œEpigallocatechin-3-gallate (EGCG), one of the major phytochemical components in green tea, is effective in the management of pain through suppression of inflammation and oxidative stress.â€
  • Clove: â€œContains eugenol, which is a natural pain reliever.â€ Several scientific studies have concluded that clove oil can kill bacteria, reduce inflammation relieve pain. 

Breathwork and meditation can reduce pain

Donâ€™t underestimate the power of relaxation. Researchers at the Pain Rehabilitation Center found that 10 minutes of diaphragmatic breathing three times a day reduced pain when done consistently for at least two weeks.

Dr Johnston believes initiating a relaxation response is a primary way to reduce levels of cortisol in the system, and therefore pain. She says: â€œMindfulness practice and deep, regular breathing gives the body the message that it is OK and not under threat, even when the pain signals are continuing.â€Â

Try these simple breathing exercises to dial down the stress and reduce pain.Â

Use distraction techniques to boost endorphins

â€œPain signals are naturally trying to alert your attention, but [sometimes these alerts can be] too loud and unnecessary for the situation,â€ says Dr Johnson. â€œUse your thoughts to tell your body and brain that youâ€™re overriding these messages, and aim to focus your attention on anything that may bring some interest or pleasure instead.â€

Movement, socialising and pleasure-seeking arenâ€™t just about taking your mind off the pain: they can also boost endorphins, the bodyâ€™s natural painkilling hormone. The word â€˜endorphinâ€™ actually derives from the term â€˜endogenous morphineâ€™, as it is supposed to mimic the opioid.

Dr Johnston appreciates that it is tempting to stay home alone when in pain but is clear that â€œit helps to engage with others. Get out and go somewhere that has good memories or brings a feeling of connection.â€

Images: Getty

item.title: â€œConstant headaches made me think I had a brain tumourâ€¦ but I was experiencing the physical symptoms of depressionâ€
item.description: In a piece for Processing, a Stylist Frame Of Mind series, writer ChloÃ« James shares how she discovered that depression can lead to unexpected physical symptoms.Â
item.dc:creator: ChloÃ« James
item.content:encoded:
The first time I thought I had a brain tumour, Iâ€™d had a headache for two days and gone on a WebMD spiral. Iâ€™ve never been a headache person, but I am a serial worrier, which means that the symptom checker has a permanent seat on my list of most visited websites. Most of the time, I stop feeling stressed because my symptoms disappear before I even realise theyâ€™re gone. But this was different.

Over the next few weeks, my headaches ebbed and flowed but never totally stopped. What scared me more was that half of my face felt numbÂ â€“ kind of like a dentist had injected me with local anaesthetic and it was slowly starting to wear off.

I ran my symptoms through as many checkers as I could find and started cross-referencing the most common results. Some kind of neurological condition seemed inevitable.

The thing is, for someone who stresses out so much about their health, Iâ€™d always had an aversion to doctors, hospitals, or anything that may confirm I am in fact unwell. But as weeks became months, I found myself withdrawing. I couldnâ€™t focus. I started making stupid mistakes with my work. Iâ€™d have fun, then sober myself with the reminder that I was probably going to die. My friends or my boyfriend would make future plans, and in my head, Iâ€™d respond, â€œI probably wonâ€™t be here, though.â€

Eventually, I reached breaking point. My headaches started in February and by May I was probably crying more often than not. I was self-aware enough to recognise Iâ€™d become a nightmare to live with, talk to, or even remotely know. Begrudgingly, I made an appointment to see a doctor. My appointment took a grand total of two minutes as he listened to my symptoms, found the nearest neurologist, and told me to get an MRI asap.

By this point, I was so stressed that I didnâ€™t really know how to feel anything else. In some ways, Iâ€™d transcended stress and just accepted my fate. I wonder if Iâ€™ll be able to get the money back for my flights this summer, I thought as I changed into the gown for my scan. It sucks that I probably wonâ€™t be allowed to fly once I start my treatment.

I hadnâ€™t had an emotion other than nothingness

As I live in Dubai, all healthcare is private. In this case, it was a major perk as I received my MRI results in a matter of hours. I waited for them in the hospital until I was called back to my neurologistâ€™s office, where she smiled and said, â€œCongratulations, you have a beautiful, healthy brain.â€

I went home elatedÂ â€“ but the feeling didnâ€™t last long. If my head was healthy, then why was this happening? The neurologist had suggested that my numbness may be the aura of a migraine, the sensory disturbances that kick in before or during an episode, but I knew the location and nature of my headache wasnâ€™t typical of a migraine.

Two months later, I made a different appointment. My symptoms hadnâ€™t changed, but I had. I was snappy and uninterested in everything. I went to Disneyland â€“ literally the happiest place on earth â€“ and wondered why, even while riding Space Mountain, I always felt like I was a few steps away from actually enjoying myself. It was only when a friend mentioned seeing her psychiatrist that I decided maybe I should, too.

My psychiatrist was approachable but thorough. I cried in the first 10 minutes because I didnâ€™t know what to say other than the fact I felt nothing. I realised I meant that in every sense of the word. My face wasnâ€™t the only thing feeling numb; I hadnâ€™t had a genuine emotion other than stress or nothingness in a long time. In passing, I mentioned the physical symptoms Iâ€™d experienced over the past few months. He nodded and carried on.

At the end of my session, he told me I was depressed. I shouldnâ€™t have been surprised. Iâ€™d had depression before, but that was years ago and it hadnâ€™t felt like nothing. I felt too much of everything, and â€˜everythingâ€™ was always negative. When I explained this, convinced heâ€™d got it wrong, he nodded again and prescribed me antidepressants.

I had taken antidepressants before. Last time, Iâ€™d taken SertralineÂ â€“ an SSRI (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor) that increases the production of serotonin, a hormone that regulates your mood. Now, my psychiatrist thought Iâ€™d respond better to Bupropion, which restores the balance of dopamine and norepinephrine (the chemicals responsible for pleasure and motivation) in your brain.

Sertraline had dulled the sadness that ravaged me through my late teens. This time, it was like Bupropion was slowly waking me up, but I didnâ€™t notice until my next check-up. My psychiatrist was delighted with my progress and asked about my headaches and numbness. Shocked, I realised theyâ€™d improved, too. How had something I obsessed over for months disappeared so quietly?

My psychiatrist noticed my surprise and explained that the physical effects of depression are, like the condition itself, unpredictable. â€œSome people get headaches,â€ he said. â€œSome people donâ€™t.â€ When I asked why nobody had suggested depression as the cause before, he shrugged and said, â€œGeneral practitioners donâ€™t think about this stuff.â€

While I donâ€™t like to think about the months I wasted mourning my life while it went on without me, I also make a concerted effort not to feel too guilty. Depression is so prevalent is because itâ€™s sneaky. It can manifest in ways you donâ€™t even imagine, with the NHS listing everything from aches and pains to constipation and low sex drive as symptoms.

If anything good came out of this experience, itâ€™s that Iâ€™ve witnessed firsthand just how complex and powerful my brain can be. Itâ€™s technically me, but itâ€™s not always on my side; it can spot cracks in my defences before I even know they exist, and has no qualms in taking me to the darkest places imaginable. Considering my past experiences, I thought I had a pretty good understanding of depression. Now I know that there is no one way to experience mental illness â€“ and that in itself feels like a start.

Frame Of Mind is Stylistâ€™s home for all things mental health and the mind. From expert advice on the small changes you can make to improve your wellbeing to first-person essays and features on topics ranging from autism to antidepressants, weâ€™ll be exploring mental health in all its forms. You can check out the series home page to get started.

If you or someone you know is struggling with their mental health, you can find support and resources on the mental health charity Mindâ€™s website and NHS Every Mind Matters or access the NHSâ€™ list of mental health helplines and services.

If you are struggling with your mental health, you can also ask your GP for a referral to NHS Talking Therapies, or you can self-refer.

For confidential support, you can also call the SamaritansÂ in the UK on 116 123 or email jo@samaritans.org. In a crisis, call 999.

Images: courtesy ofÂ ChloÃ« James

item.title: The â€˜motherhood penaltyâ€™ is responsible for a large part of the gender pay gap â€“ hereâ€™s what you need to know
item.description: New analysis of ONS data uncovers the stark income disparity between working mothers and fathers. Itâ€™s called the motherhood penalty, and itâ€™s a driving cause of the gender pay gap. Hereâ€™s what you need to know about it.
item.dc:creator: Alyssa Jaffer
item.content:encoded:
With another International Womenâ€™s Day behind us, itâ€™s a good time to ask if anything is really changing for women. Closing the gender pay gap has stalled, major companies are cutting their DEI investments and the World Bank recently discovered that the global gender gap is far larger than previously thought.

So what will it take for women to be truly equal at work?

New data analysis from charity Pregnant Then Screwed revealed that mothers make Â£4.44 less per hour in weekly earnings than fathers. Worse still, mothers earned 43% less than fathers based on median weekly earnings, according to ONS data from January to March 2023.

This is the motherhood penalty. It covers the earnings gap between parents of different genders, as well as the opportunity costs for women who become mothers and either leave the workforce due to high childcare costs or miss out on career opportunities during key growth years â€“ and in many cases, their careers never recover.

What is the motherhood penalty?

â€œThe motherhood penalty is the systemic disadvantage that mothers experience in the workplace in terms of pay, perceived competence and benefits compared to their childless counterparts,â€ said Joeli Brearley, CEO and founder of Pregnant Then Screwed.

â€œItâ€™s a financial penalty that isnâ€™t just an inconvenience â€“ itâ€™s catastrophic for their quality of life. Itâ€™s why we have a gender pension gap, itâ€™s why women have lower rates of mental wellbeing and it reduces access to good quality housing,â€ she said.

Ultimately the reason the motherhood penalty exists is rooted in maternity and gender discrimination, Brearley explained. The Equality and Human Rights Commission estimated that as many as 54,000 new mothers each year lose their jobs due to maternity discrimination, despite pregnancy being a legally protected characteristic â€“ and that number is growing.

Decades ago, a single income could comfortably support the whole family. Dad went to work while Mum tended to the house and raised three kids. Over time, women have taken their place at work and living costs have risen faster than wages have, but our social systems and support from employers havenâ€™t kept the same pace of change.

â€œIt tends to be the mother who sacrifices their career because we have a childcare system that doesnâ€™t work,â€ said Brearley. â€Our antiquated parental leave system tells fathers to go to work and mothers to stay at home and care for their child.â€

The reality of the motherhood penalty

For women who want to become mothers, the choice is fraught with sacrifice and uncertainty in their careers. Freya Leete, a PR consultant in Tunbridge Wells, joined a London startup during an exciting growth phase of her career â€“ but not long after disclosing her surprise pregnancy to her employer (which she cannot name due to being bound by an NDA), she found herself without a job.

â€œI walked into what I thought was going to be my six-month review meeting, but instead I was made redundant,â€ she said. â€œI was five months pregnant and couldnâ€™t believe what was happening. I left feeling so angry that they were doing this to me and stressed about how to afford the baby, as I knew the likelihood of another company hiring me at this stage was hugely unlikely,â€ she said.

Freya initially pursued legal advice but eventually negotiated a settlement to prioritise her financial and emotional wellbeing and move forward.

For so many like Freya, the motherhood penalty derails women from their career track â€“ and the consequences can impact the entire trajectory of their professional success. The Child Penalty Atlas, a research project studying the impact of parenthood on men and womenâ€™s careers globally, found that â€œshortly after the babyâ€™s arrival, womenâ€™s employment plummets sharply, while menâ€™s continues on a relatively smooth upwards trajectory. After a few years, both men and women stabilise â€“ but womenâ€™s employment never returns to pre-child levels.â€

And when a corporate structure doesnâ€™t support mothers the way they need, theyâ€™re pushed out of the workforce completely. Following her redundancy and as a new mother, Freya struggled to find work that suited her. When her second child was eight months old, she decided to go back to work, but she still hasnâ€™t found the career security she had before having children.

â€œMy professional confidence had been left in tatters, so I took a job that I was overqualified for. I still struggle with my confidence and think I always will. I found it really hard to navigate motherhood and my career, always feeling guilty about one or the other. This intensified once my eldest started school, as school and work hours simply donâ€™t make sense. Iâ€™ve now made the decision to go freelance so I can navigate a better work-life balance that aligns with the needs of my family,â€ she said.

Why fixing the motherhood penalty matters

Abolishing the motherhood penalty would be a large stride towards closing the gender pay gap and enabling true gender equality at work. In the UK, 88% of the gender gap is explained by the child penalty.

And itâ€™s not only mothers or even women who are adversely affected by the motherhood penalty â€“ we all stand to benefit by correcting it.

â€œEveryone should care about the motherhood penalty because it has a massively negative impact on the economy,â€ said Brearley. â€œIf we can create a system where everyone has equal and fair access to the labour market so they are working the hours that they want to, then the benefits to the economy will be enormous.â€

How workplaces can reduce the motherhood penalty

Truly flexible working, bolstered parental leave policies and funding support for childcare can all help to reduce the motherhood penalty. And itâ€™s also crucial to confront bias around pregnancy, maternity and paternity.

Pregnant Then Screwed is calling for six weeks of paternity leave paid at 90%, all parental leave to be paid at the national living wage and childcare to cost 10% or less of household income.

Whether youâ€™re a mother, a future mother, childfree or an ally, itâ€™s going to take all of us to eliminate the motherhood penalty for good.Â

Images: Getty

item.title: Borecore is officially in: 100 utterly mundane things that bring us joy
item.description: The evidence is stacking up: weâ€™ve all become boring. But thatâ€™s nothing to yawn at now that borecore is firmly â€˜inâ€™. How did dullness become so desired? Ellen Scott explores, and shares a mega list of 100 things that are undeniably boring but deliver true joy.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Scott
item.content:encoded:
There comes a time in everyoneâ€™s life when you realise, with a cold, creeping shock, that you have become boring. My time struck, paradoxically, in a moment of great excitement. Searching to confirm the bin collection post-Christmas, I discovered that â€“ finally! â€“ a major source of grumbling had been resolved. The council where I live would now take the recycling weekly, rather than every two weeks. Upon learning this, I rushed to message my partner, my family, all my friends. I posted a story on Instagram with multiple exclamation points. I felt adrenaline coursing through my veins as images of a clutter-free kitchen and flattened delivery boxes flashed through my mind. It was a true high, followed by the swift comedown of realising who I now was: someone for whom joy comes not from a big night out or illicit substances, butâ€¦ bins.

I have spent a lot of time and effort trying to prevent this from happening. I thought that having lilac hair, multiple tattoos and an exciting job might prevent me from ever being a bore. At parties, I told stories about drinking with fraternities in Massachusetts and that time I went to a nudist swingersâ€™ retreat in Jamaica. But gradually the dullness snuck its way in. I got an air fryer and found myself talking about it at length. I rejoiced each time a plan was cancelled and I could refuse to move from the sofa for the entire weekend. For Christmas, I asked for a restock of my favourite grey socks from M&S.

We can appreciate whatâ€™s unremarkable but still beautiful

The thing is, while my teenage self would cringe for all eternity if she discovered she would become someone enthralled by clear storage bins and a cup of tea, I have no shame about my boring transformation. I love being a bore, and this is in large part because it seems like everyone now is. Look at all the home organising influencers, notice just how much chat there is about air fryers, turn on the TV to catch yet another reality show about pottery or buying a home. Everywhere you look, the evidence is there: boring is now cool. The era of borecore is upon us.

But where has it come from? â€œBorecore can probably be traced back to the explosion of TikTok during the pandemic, when enforced isolation and idleness for many (but not for everyone) turned the mundanity of the everyday into our social currency online, as well as our entertainment,â€ Annie Corser, senior trends editor at Stylus, tells Stylist. â€œThe content creation habits formed during that strange time persist today in much of what weâ€™d consider borecore: detailing our takeaways, organising fridges and filming how we do laundry.â€

Perhaps, then, borecoreâ€™s ascension is down to the chaos of those pandemic years (and the political turmoil before and after), and as a society weâ€™ve leaned into the soothing qualities of dull pleasures. You can see it in the world of fashion, where â€˜quiet luxuryâ€™ (read: expensive but not particularly exciting white shirts, black dresses and beige cashmere jumpers) reigned supreme for months last year, while stilettos have been swapped for comfy trainers or business-appropriate chunky loafers ever since the WFH days of the pandemic.

In the past few months, borecore appears to have ramped up even more. Shades of grey (undeniably the dullest colour imaginable) appeared on the autumn/winter catwalks at Prada, Fendi and Bottega Veneta. And the trend thatâ€™s trickled down to the high street, worn by every fashion editor and influencer? A grey knit. Again, dull as dishwater. While once a grey cardigan would be an uninspired option, now, as Stylistâ€™s fashion director Lucy Reber puts it: â€œA grey button-down knit is a byword for chic thanks to Miu Miuâ€™s glorious take on this unassuming piece.â€
