Once youâ€™ve noticed that borecore has taken hold, youâ€™ll see it everywhere. In our growing fondness for the mundane in our social media feeds, where a video of a woman restocking her guest bathroom has 2.5 million likes. In our spending: â€œThe purchase of air fryers in the UK increased nearly seven percentage points from 2020 to 2022, marking one of the largest jumps for appliances in the market,â€ says Ryan Hui of market research company Mintel. And in the way we pass our time:Â data suggests young people are spending far less time socialising outside of the house than the same demographic was 20 years ago. The coolness of sex, drugs and rock and roll has faded; people are having less sex, going on fewer dates and less likely to drink to excess. Rather than going off the rails, young people are casting off â€“ the stereotypically grannyish activity of knitting is on the rise.Â

Itâ€™s true that the cost of living crisis likely plays a role in the great bore-ification. Air fryers have become such a hot topic of conversation partly because they cost less to run than using an oven. And when budgets are tight, nights out are one of the first things we cut:Â one YouGov survey from FareShare found that 42% of 18 to 24-year-olds in the UK are reducing socialising with friends due to rising costs.

But bland isnâ€™t all bad. Weâ€™re not choosing blah solely because we canâ€™t afford anything else; weâ€™re turning towards borecore because despite being dull, it also makes us happy. â€œSimple is not simplistic and the little basic details of life can be pleasant and consoling when so much is difficult,â€ notes psychotherapist Charlotte Fox Weber. â€œThere is constant uncertaintyÂ and indecision about big life issues and we can enjoy enriching our personal lives in whatever small way possible. It might be a piece of fruit, the scent of fresh rosemary or wrapping a gift in a certain way, but everyday chores and activities can be comforting, reliable and self-expressive without demanding that we uproot our lives and do something drastic.

â€œRitualising and noticing ordinary details can go a long way for enhancing experiences. Without spending wildly or making tough decisions, we can appreciate whatâ€™s unremarkable but still beautiful in life. I once heard someone describe the musicality of a washing machine as something they loved listening to; I love this and hadnâ€™t ever bothered to pay attention to the sounds of washing unless it was about a problem. Listening and looking at daily life can be meaningful and utterly worthwhile.â€

There are certain little delights that, if you were to bring them up at a party, would lead you to being labelled the ultimate dullard. But we at Stylist believe these things to be deserving of discussion and, more importantly, celebration. â€œEmbracing ordinary life â€“ allowing yourself to appreciate the everyday â€“ can be life-enhancing and real,â€ Weber agrees. â€œI think a lot of us have resisted being boring for so long or made an apology for boring chat, so Iâ€™m fascinated by what it might do if we were to just say screw it, I like boring things and thatâ€™s fine.â€

With this in mind, we share with you a list of 100 wonderful but undeniably boring joys. These are not things that would traditionally win you cool points if you were to discuss them. They are not something to write home about. And yet we adore them all the same.Â

100 boring things we truly adore

1. Low-stakes cosy crime. A small town rocked by a mysterious outsider smashing up garden gnomes? Sign us up.

2. The bins being taken just before they started overflowing. Satisfying!

3. Discovering you can cook an entire meal in the air fryer. And telling everyone about it. Itâ€™s now April and Iâ€™m still regaling colleagues with exactly how I cooked an entire Christmas dinner in the air fryer. The roast potatoes were the best Iâ€™ve ever had.

4. A cup of bog standard tea with milk and sugar.Â

5. â€œDoes Old Street roundaboutâ€™s cycling lane count?â€ asks Strong Women editor Miranda Larbi. â€œAnd the Elephant & Castle crossing. Both exceptional town planning.â€ Miranda, it absolutely counts.

6. The two-hour window of greatness every Thursday when Dragonsâ€™ Den is followed by The Apprentice.

7. A good pair of socks. I know many sock aficionados have strong preferences for ribbing and thickness, and I respect that. But for me, itâ€™s all about getting a five-pack of â€˜sumptuously softâ€™ ones from M&S in â€˜grey marlâ€™. The smugness of having only grey socks, and thus being able to pair them up with ease, is a huge bonus. Odd socks arenâ€™t an issue when all your socks match.

8. Buying a new fleece and looking forward to it finally being cold so you can fully appreciate its cosiness.

9. Trying a new brand of milk. Proceed with caution, as sometimes this can be too much excitement. Sainsburyâ€™s swapping your order of Oatly Barista Edition for Califia Farms, fine. Going from almond milk to hemp? Whoa there.

10. Hearing about every single step of someone elseâ€™s skincare routine, despite it fundamentally being the same as everyone elseâ€™s and holding no bearing on your life.

11. Figuring out how to use the grill setting on your oven.

12. A sizeable jar to put household staples in.

13. A label maker. I got one for Christmas a few years back and I continue to find any excuse to make a custom label.

14. Your very own tea station with labelled jars for sugar and teabags, rather than just using the bag each one comes in.

15. Limescale removal. A squeaky clean kettle? The dream.

16. Finding just the right sitting position that delivers both comfort and the ideal light for reading a book.

17. The immense life upgrade of getting a garlic press rather than having to deal with the faff of peeling and chopping.

18. Running a debobbler over a jumper, a sofa arm, a bra strap, everything.

19. Doing the crossword every day.

20. And still doing Wordle (bonus boring points if you have strong opinions about American spellings or words that only those in the US would know)

21. And getting really into Connections.

22. An early night.

23. When you have absolutely zero plans for the evening.

25. Tuning in to watch the weather.

26. Thermals as an entire concept.

27. How much money youâ€™re saving by running a space heater rather than putting the heating on.

28. Pickling anything.

29. Making your own jam.

30. Having a slightly different breakfast than normal. For example, features writer Holly Bullock swapped her usual porridge for a sausage sandwich last Saturday and â€œrode the high all dayâ€. I swapped honey for salted caramel spread on my yoghurt last week and Iâ€™m still thinking about it.

31. Buying the fancy apple juice thatâ€™s cloudy and tastes like actual apples.

32. Nailing your technique for bundling a pair of socks into a little ball.

33. Cheese on toast. Forget making your own pasta or fiddling about with bao buns. Sometimes, some cheddar on sliced white is all the buzz you need.

34. Being asked what you want for Christmas/your birthday and responding by listing off â€˜things for the houseâ€™. Iâ€™d love some new plates.

35. You know whatâ€™s really good? A glass of cold water. Not too cold, mind you. My teeth are sensitive.

36. Discussing how you slept the night before.

37. Buying new bath towels.

38. The lofty dream of having a laundry room, perhaps with one of those drying racks that comes down from the ceiling.

39. A mug with a good weight to it.

40. â€œTidying the edge of my lawn with a lawn edging tool,â€ says Stylistâ€™s digital content director Felicity. If I say â€˜edgingâ€™ and you think of lawns, congratulations, you have become boring. Welcome.

41. Fancying someone because they just seem â€˜quite niceâ€™.

42. Other peopleâ€™s office grumbles. â€œSorry for going on and on,â€ they say. No, please do continue to tell me about how Tracy keeps repeating your points in meetings as though sheâ€™s just come up with them. I live for this.

43. Slicing a cross into a jacket potato and watching the steam rise out.

44. â€˜Making good timeâ€™, such as your usual walk to the shop taking seven minutes rather than the allotted 10.

45. Hot water bottles.

46. Growing your own basil because itâ€™s far more cost effective than buying a new pack every time you want to make pesto.

47. Making your own pesto.

48. When it rains and you get the opportunity to try out your new rain cape/umbrella/little detached hood thing.

49. A pleasant light temperature. Iâ€™d like my bulbs to be about 20% warmer, personally.

50. When you press the button at a pedestrian crossing and the lights turn the moment you do. â€œThe feeling of power and tax well spent,â€ says Miranda.

51. The Archers omnibus.

52. When youâ€™re wrapping a present and cut exactly the right amount of paper. Also, when your scissors glide through the paper. Better than hard drugs, some might say.

53. Knowing that youâ€™ve seasoned some fresh tomatoes to perfection. A good quality tomato in general, really.

54. â€œHaving a card drawer so Iâ€™m never caught short,â€ says my most grownup friend, Rebecca.

55. A sharp set of kitchen knives. â€œThereâ€™s a shop down the road from me that sharpens mine a couple of times a year,â€ says Stylistâ€™s subeditor, Steven. â€œIâ€™m rarely happier than when slicing a tomato afterwards.â€

56. A nap on a Sunday afternoon.

57. When you discover that the dinner you made yesterday microwaves well the next day for lunch.

58. Matches in an aesthetically pleasing box.

59. Or making your own match holder out of an old candle jar by putting it in the freezer, chipping out the wax, and sticking some striking paper on the bottom.

60. Taking the plunge and buying a mini greenhouse.

61. Waking up just before your alarm goes off.

62. A shower, but with enough time for dilly-dallying and general faffing about.

63. Slathering your face in the heaviest cream and the richest oil so you can go to sleep glistening like a chicken about to be roasted.

64. A proper roast chicken, on that note.

65. Batch cooking. Itâ€™s wild how many influencers there are now whose entire schtick is making 10 servings of chilli and popping portions in the freezer.

66. Making a vegetable soup. With odds and ends of veg you didnâ€™t use up!

67. Aiming for 30 plants a week. I started doing this on the guidance of wellbeing queen Miranda Larbi, and now bore everyone by getting out my Notes app and reading out all the plants Iâ€™ve eaten in the past few days. Even herbs count, you know.

68. Neighbour drama. I heard number 37 doesnâ€™t like how many packages theyâ€™re having to take in for number 39. Itâ€™s a lot of packages, to be fair. Why do they keep ordering stuff for next-day delivery if they know theyâ€™re not going to be in? And donâ€™t get me started on how 39 doesnâ€™t put their green bins back in their gardens in a sufficiently prompt manner.

69. Having a system for your bookshelf organisation. Iâ€™m partial to colour coding, but I recognise this is controversial.

70. The high of watching your total drop thanks to your Nectar card/Tesco clubcard.

71. A cuddle with absolutely zero chance of progression to sex.

72. The moment you successfully excavate an ingrown hair.

73. Coasters. Having a respect for wood: in. Being laissez-faire about water rings: very much out.

74. Any sort of drawer freshening item that makes your underwear smell like lavender.

75. A sensible jumper. A grey crewneck really does go with everything.

76. A spreadsheet that looks good and does a good job at communicating data.

77. A pear at the right point of crispness.

78. Gentle stretches. Not yoga. More like touching your toes or leaning over to one side with your arms above your head.

79. Forget a dramatic will-they-wonâ€™t-they love story or a passionate affair. These days a comforting relationship with someone who makes you laugh and shows they care is the height of hot. Just look at all the swooning over â€˜orange peel theoryâ€™.

80. Leaving a party early enough to stick to your usual bedtime.

81. Iâ€™m considering buying a laser level. No firm decisions have been made yet.

82. Getting stocked up on your preferred pen (Muji 0.38, if youâ€™re wondering).

83. A water flosser.

84. Upgrading to a fancy toothbrush. Mine connects to an app on my phone and tells me when Iâ€™m brushing certain sections of my mouth too hard.

85. A weekend spent reading the newspaper and lying on the sofa.

86. Getting to the end of a pot of a beauty product and getting every last drop left.

87. In fact, the very concept of â€˜getting your moneyâ€™s worthâ€™. Sussing out cost per use, being responsible with your spending and buying things that are made to lastâ€¦ all very boring, all very chic.

88. Putting on a load of laundry or starting a dishwasher cycle.

89. â€œWhen the load of washing Iâ€™ve done is the perfect amount to all fit on the clothes horse,â€ says head of email Annie Simpson, â€œso I donâ€™t have random socks and T-shirts hanging off drawers and cupboards.â€

90. Managing the delicate art of poaching an egg for a runny yolk but sufficiently firm whites.

91. Receiving a present, unwrapping it and saving the paper for future use.

92. Stylistâ€™s social media editor Sophie Boyden says her heated clothes dryer is â€œlife-changingâ€. I am deeply envious.

93. Did you know that rice pudding sales jumped by 45% last year? And that a rice pudding bar, named Rizz Rice (yes, that does make us all uncomfortable, but letâ€™s move on), opened up in London in February? Rice pudding, the dullest of desserts, is having its time in the sun.

94. Ordering a big food shop and discovering the expiry date on a perishable item is later than you had predicted. A thrill!

95. Landing the coveted front seat on the upper deck of the bus so you can feel like youâ€™re driving.

96. A simple sandwich. Look, I have all the time in the world for a hyped-up XXL sandwich filled with fancy pickles and exciting textures, but alsoâ€¦ an egg mayo is quite good, isnâ€™t it?

97. Successfully unclogging a big wad of hair from the plughole.

98. A crisp spring day. Does this offer the excitement of a snow day or the sex appeal of sweltering summer climes? Absolutely not. But the crispness of the air is plain magical.

99. Having an hour to do a deep extracting session in front of a magnifying mirror.

100. An uneventful day/week/month where nothing really happens. Things are always happening. Thereâ€™s always something. Wouldnâ€™t a brief respite from that be absolutely delicious?

Images: Getty; Adobe Stock

item.title: Endometriosis flare-ups: 5 women on how they cope, from using heat pads to practising self-compassion
item.description: From deep breathing to heat pads and natural remedies, these are the coping techniques five women with endometriosis use when theyâ€™re going through a flare-up.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Geall
item.content:encoded:
One in 10 women in the UK live with endometriosis, but youâ€™d be forgiven for assuming the true number was much smaller with the lack of knowledge, awareness and respect the condition receives.

From waiting almost a decade to get a diagnosis to being told getting pregnant is the best option for managing symptoms, living with endometriosis often feels like dealing with one blow after another. And thatâ€™s on top of the toll that the condition itself can take. In a recent survey from Active Iron, 96% of women with endometriosis said their symptoms had led to a decline in their quality of life.

But while progress is slow on the societal front, the endo community remains home to a wealth of advice for dealing with painful symptoms, GP appointments and everything in between.

So, to mark Endometriosis Awareness Month this March, we asked five women who are living with endometriosis to share their advice for dealing with painful flare-ups. From using meditation to regulate stress to keeping an eye on posture, hereâ€™s what they said.Â Â

â€œStress makes my symptoms worse, so I practise meditationâ€

â€œFlares are one of the worst parts of having endo, but Iâ€™ve found a few things that help to manage them at home. The most important one is reducing my stress through meditating â€“ the more I stress, the worse the flare-up gets.

â€œAfter that, I like to combine fresh ginger and lemon to make an anti-inflammatory tea and reduce all processed foods in my diet for the next few days to help my body settle down. Tens machines are also a great way to reduce the pain without taking medication.â€

Sophie, 27Â

â€œI try not to sit at my desk for too longâ€

â€œSince I noticed sitting at my desk for too long could trigger a flare-up and worsen my pain, Iâ€™ve started looking at home to improve my posture and desk set-up as well as building in time to walk around and move. Having in-person meetings and moving around more during the day seems to lead to fewer flare-ups and less pain â€“ itâ€™s hard to know the cause here but it has worked for me.

â€œI also use a variety of methods to help keep my pain under control. Heat can be a very effective form of pain relief so I have a lavender wheat bag I can pop in the microwave as well as heat pads that go directly on my skin. I also have cooling pads for when the pain feels hot and angry.

â€œIâ€™ve recently started to use breathwork as a way to â€˜breathe outâ€™ the pain. Iâ€™m no specialist, but because the pain can cause my body to tense up, Iâ€™ve found using my breathing to try to relax and visualise the pain leaving my body to be really effective alongside other things.

â€œLearning techniques from a pelvic floor physio has also helped me to manage flare-ups and manage my condition in general. I also use teas and fresh ingredients to help calm and soothe any gut-related symptoms I have during a flare-up.â€

Rebekah, 33Â

â€œNothing takes the pain away, so I take the weight off my feetâ€

â€œIâ€™ve suffered with endometriosis since I was a teenager, and every time the pain flares up again I feel so frustrated and disappointed with my body. Really? This again? I say to myself as I feel it shooting through my pelvis, in my lower back and the tops of my legs.

â€œI feel like after so many years, I should have found a better way to manage it, but nothing Iâ€™ve tried can fully take the pain away. I usually have a hot bath or hot water bottle to just about take the edge off and take the weight off my feet until I can ride it out.â€

Martha, 40Â

â€œNatural alternatives have been really helpfulâ€

â€œI was diagnosed with endometriosis at 18 and underwent a medically induced and reversed menopause to treat the condition (after a major operation), so I was keen to try natural alternatives where possible after all the medical interventions.

â€œI went to the health food shop where the lady gave me all sorts of weird and wonderful ingredients to mix into a tea, and I found it really helped. I later retrained as a tea sommelier and began making my own teas, which I still use to support my body and symptoms.

â€œI also sell these teas to other women looking for natural support through my small business. The teas contain ingredients Iâ€™ve found to be personally beneficial â€“ my energise blend, for example, contains ashwagandha, an adaptogen plant that helps the body to adapt to stress, as well as ginger, which Iâ€™ve found helps with period cramps.â€

Candice, 41

â€œSelf-compassion helps me to navigate the guilt of cancelling plansâ€

â€œI do lots of practical things to deal with my pain â€“ taking painkillers, using hot water bottles. But one of the most important things Iâ€™ve learned is to be kind to myself.

â€œThere is so much emotional pain that goes along with being an endo sufferer â€“ not only is it rarely acknowledged by doctors, but that feeling when you know that your body is having a flare-up and youâ€™ll have to cancel plans can leave you feeling guilty and a bit rubbish. We need to remember that itâ€™s out of our control and that endometriosis is such a debilitating condition. People will understand â€“ we need to try and offer the same sympathy to ourselves.

â€œTalking to other people about what youâ€™re going through also helps. Youâ€™ll be surprised by how many women will identify with your pain, and it may even be the catalyst that someone needs to get their own diagnosis.â€

Michelle, 38Â

Images: Getty

item.title: One Good Thing: use â€˜soft fascinationâ€™ to make your daily walk better for your mental health
item.description: Welcome back to One Good Thing, Stylistâ€™s Sunday series, as part of Frame Of Mind, that asks experts in mental health for the one good thing we can all do to boost our wellbeing.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Scott
item.content:encoded:
This week weâ€™re hearing from Julia Sands, an accredited practitioner of the Institute for Outdoor Learning and founder of Ipse Wilderness.Â

Hey, Julia! If you could recommend One Good Thing everyone can do to improve their mental health, what would it be?

A daily 15-minute walk in green (or blue) space, ie in a park, woodland or any kind of space with views of nature and/or water.

Why is this your One Good Thing?

Multiple studies have found a causal link between exercise in nature and a reduced risk of mental health problems, improved mood, lower stress, increased life satisfaction and eudaimonic wellbeing.

How can we use a daily walk for our mental health?

Go outside, move your body, look around and take notice. Even if you canâ€™t walk far, spending time in nature is restful and restorative because it provides â€˜soft fascinationâ€™: pleasant things to notice that donâ€™t require our effort. Studies have proved that walking in woodland and noticing three good things in nature each day (eg hearing birdsong or watching leaves sway in the wind) has a significantly positive impact on mental wellbeing after just five days, including for those with a specific mental health diagnosis such as depression or anxiety.

Avoid taking your phone or listening to music. Just be.

What benefits could we see from a walk that includes that soft fascination?

A reduction in depression and anxiety. An improvement in psychological wellbeing, enhanced mood, increased self-esteem and reduced tension. The physical health benefits include reduced blood pressure, cardiovascular fitness and reduced inflammation. Facilitation of social networking and connectivity. And you can learn more about your neighbourhood and find new places to walk.

Are there any common mistakes people make when heading out for their walk? How can we avoid them?

Sometimes itâ€™s tempting to use a walk as a way to ruminate, worry or plan. Try to avoid taking your phone or listening to music. Just be. Look around and label to yourself what you can notice about nature around you. It can help to walk with someone else and point out the nice things you notice to them.

How do you personally do your One Good Thing?

I got a dog five years ago specifically to force myself to go for a walk every day. I am easily distracted so I list the things I notice out loud to myself as I walk. I also try to take a moment to really appreciate something on each walk, whether itâ€™s the crunch of the frost underfoot or the shape of the clouds.

And how has doing this changed your life for the better?

I am definitely fitter and emotionally more calm. Plus, I became a qualified Lowland Leader so I now lead other people on wellbeing walks in nature with Ipse Wilderness.

Frame Of Mind is Stylistâ€™s home for all things mental health and the mind. From expert advice on the small changes you can make to improve your wellbeing to first-person essays and features on topics ranging from autism to antidepressants, weâ€™ll be exploring mental health in all its forms. You can check out the series home page to get started.

Image: Getty

item.title: Picture This: Bridgertonâ€™s Simone Ashley is set to lead Prime Videoâ€™s new romcom
item.description: Starring Simone Ashley andÂ Hero Fiennes Tiffin, Prime Video are bringing us yet another romcom andÂ weâ€™re ready to get into our feelings.
item.dc:creator: Shahed Ezaydi
item.content:encoded:
As much as I love going back to romcomÂ classics such as How To Lose A Guy In 10 Days and The Proposal, itâ€™s always exciting to treat yourself to a brand new romcom â€“ where you donâ€™t know the ending or half the script. Prime Video has already released a sweet and funny romcom this year, Camila Mendesâ€™ Upgraded,Â and the streamer has now announced that another one is on its way.

Picture This is all about how far we go to find love and the hilarious stories we pick up along the way. The best part? Bridgertonâ€™s Simone Ashley will be taking the lead. So, hereâ€™s everything we know so far about Picture This.

What is the plot of Picture This?

Pia is as single as they come and is trying to keep her failing photography studio afloat in London with her best friend, Jay. â€œAs her sister Sonal prepares to get married and her mother Laxmi urges the resolutely independent Pia to partner up, a spiritual guru at Sonalâ€™s engagement party predicts Pia will meet the love of her life among the next five dates she goes on.

As her family intervenes, setting her up on a series of increasingly desperate blind dates, Pia begins a hilarious but heartfelt quest for real love,â€ reads the synopsis.

Who will star in Picture This?

Simone Ashley stars as Pia and Hero Fiennes Tiffin (After) as, what we can only assume, her love interest.

Further cast includes Phil Dunster (Ted Lasso), Nikesh Patel (Starstruck), Adil Ray (Citizen Khan), Sindhu Vee (Matilda: The Musical), Anoushka Chadha (You), Kulvinder Ghir (Bend It Like Beckham) and Luke Fetherston (Still Up).

The film is directed by Prarthana Mohan, written by Nikita Lalwani and is based on the Australian original film, Five Blind Dates.

When will Picture This be released?

The film is currently in post-production so weâ€™re hoping we might get to see it some time this year.

Image: Getty

item.title: Netflix sitcoms and comedies: 25 uplifting shows to stream on your lunchbreak
item.description: These feel-good Netflix shows will inject some positivity into your working (from home) day in 30 minutes or less.
item.dc:creator: Kayleigh Dray
item.content:encoded:
Working from home sounded like our type on paper when we all got sent home in lockdown, but it has proven all too easy to get really, really tiresome if we donâ€™t make sure our day has some structure to it.Â

What do we mean by this? Well, we need to make sure we start and finish at set times, that we get dressed, that we take proper lunchbreaks, and that we give our brain the space it needs to breathe every so often.

Thereâ€™s lots of ways to do this, of course. You could take a walk round the block at the start and end of each day. You could set an alarm at 12:30, reminding you to go cook yourself some lunch and sit in a different room for a little while. Or you could rely on regularly scheduled Netflix breaks to lure you away from your home office (which, if we might be so bold to say, looks an awful lot like you took your laptop to bed with you).

Oh yes, Netflix reigns supreme when it comes to improving a WFH day and there are plenty of shorter feel-good options available. And, because we care about bringing a little joy to your life, weâ€™ve looked up all those sitcoms, animations and comedies which boast episodes of 30 minutes or less.

Happy viewing.

Superstore

Starring America Ferrera, Superstore is set in a big-box megastore in St. Louis, where a group of employees with larger-than-life personalities put up with customers, day-to-day duties and each other. Thereâ€™s six seasons to tuck into with the majority of the episodes sitting at the 22-minute mark.

Starstruck

Jessie, a Londoner, navigates a minefield of mishaps when her impromptu hook up with an international film star develops into a real relationship. Cue the chaos. Starring Rose Matafeo and Nikesh Patel.

Average episode length: 20-24 minutes

Big Mouth

Even for a cartoon character, going through puberty isnâ€™t easy. Andrew is learning that first hand as he experiences the nightmare that is growing up in this animated series geared toward adults. And, with every hilarious episode clocking in at around 26 minutes, they make for ideal lunchtime laughs.

That '90s Show

A spin off from the brilliant and iconic That â€˜70s Show, That â€˜90s Show sees Kitty (Debra Jo Rupp) and Red Forman (Kurtwood Smith) open their basement doors to a new cohort of teenagers as their granddaughter Leia opts to spend her summer in Wisconsin.

Average episode length: 21-30 minutes

Never Have I Ever

How do we begin to list all the things we love about Never Have I Ever? Yes itâ€™s a coming-of-age high school sitcom about teenage girl Devi Vishwakumar (Maitreyi Ramakrishnan) who wants to lose her virginity to the popular captain of the swimming team, Paxton Hall-Yoshida (Darren Barnet). But itâ€™s also about grief, friendship, sexuality, motherhood, grandmotherhood, love, sex and so much more. We could go on, but we recommend you check it out for yourself.

Average episode length: 20-30 minutes

Kimâ€™s Convenience

While running a convenience store in Toronto, members of a Korean-Canadian family deal with customers, each other and the evolving world around them. The result? A show that is beautifully, breathtakingly corny.

Average episode length: 21 minutes

Friday Night Dinner

The Goodman brothers Adam (Simon Bird) and Jonny (Tom Rosenthal) return to their parentsâ€™ home for dinner each week on a Friday night. Their parents are brilliantly played by Tamsim Greig and the late Paul Ritter and their eccentricities guarantee a meal thatâ€™s full of surprises. Get ready for crimble crumble and a lovely bit of squirrel.

Average episode length: 23 minutes

Brooklyn Nine-Nine

Andy Samberg and Andre Braugher lead the diverse star-studded cast of Brooklyn Nine-Nine, which focuses entirely on the mishaps and crime-solving adventures of New Yorkâ€™s funniest police precinct.

Average episode length: 22 minutes

The IT Crowd

Ah, we all know and love The IT Crowd. Set in the IT department of a London office (the irony!), this show tells the story of staff members Maurice (Richard Ayoade), Roy (Chris Oâ€™Dowd) and their department head Jen Barber (Katherine Parkinson)â€¦ who knows absolutely nothing about IT.

Average episode length: 24 minutes

Friends

Weâ€™re not even going to bother describing this one, to be honest: everyone in the world has seen Friends. Everyone. So succumb to temptation, wrap yourself up in a nostalgic cocoon and head back to Central Perk with Ross, Rachel, Monica, Chandler, Joey and Phoebe. You wonâ€™t regret it.

Average episode length: 22 minutes

Derry Girls

Set against the backdrop of the Troubles in Derry, Northern Island, Derry Girls follows a group of teenagers as they deal with family, friendship, school exams and the strict (and hilarious) nuns who run their Catholic school. Expect lots of nineties nostalgia and laugh out loud moments.

Average episode length: 25 minutes

Motherland

A group of mothers and a stay-at-home dad struggle to juggle childcare with self-care as they experience the thrills and trials of parenthood.Â

Average episode length: 23 minutes

Emily In Paris

Chicago marketing exec Emily Cooper lands her dream job in Paris. The series follows her new life as she settles into the metropolitan city with very little of the French language but a suitcase full of chic and glorious outfits. Emily In Paris stars Lily Collins as Emily and will definitely have you looking up Eurostar pricesâ€¦

Average episode length: 30 minutes

Big Bang Theory

Leonard, Sheldon, Howard and Raj are the socially-awkward scientists whose lives take a wild turn when the free-spirited Penny moves in next door.

Average episode length: 22 minutes

The US Office

This hit comedy chronicles the antics of a group of disgruntled office workers with hilarious consequences and - as the series goes on - heartwarming moments. Michael Scott (Steve Carell) leads a team of apathetic workers at the Dunder Mifflin paper company. Itâ€™s worth your time just for the tale of Jim (John Krasinski) and Pam (Jenna Fischer), the ultimate power couple.

Average episode length: 22 minutes

The Good Place

The Good Place is about the afterlife and the very first episode opens on a shot of Eleanor (Kristen Bell) finding out she is a) dead, and b) due to spend eternity in a suburban paradise. Too bad, then, that sheâ€™s only there because of an admin error. Can she become a better person before sheâ€™s found out and sent to The Bad Place? Watch and learnâ€¦

Average episode length: 22 minutes

Grace & Frankie

Theyâ€™re not friends, but when their husbands leave them for each other, proper Grace (Jane Fonda) and eccentric Frankie (Lily Tomlin) throw their lot in together and begin to bond. Another Emmy-nominated series worth your time.

Average episode length: 30 minutes

Peep Show

This quirky comedy, starring David Mitchell, Rob Brydon and ACTUAL OLIVIA COLMAN, follows two 20-something roommates with nothing in common â€“ save for the fact their lives are anything but normal.Â

Peep Show earned rave reviews and went on to win a Bafta TV Award when it first hit our screens all those years ago, so you wonâ€™t be disappointed if you tune back in now.

Average episode length: 26 minutes

Rick & Morty

Itâ€™s the animated television series literally everyone is talking about (seen the â€œPickle Rickâ€ memes? Yeah, thatâ€™s from this). Weâ€™d be doing the show an injustice if we tried to describe it, because it genuinely defies description. All you really need to know is that it follows the misadventures of cynical mad scientist Rick Sanchez and his good-hearted grandson Morty Smith, as they split their time between domestic life and interdimensional adventures.

Average episode length: 22 minutes

Back To Life

After 18 years in prison, Miri Matteson (Daisy Haggard) returns home to live with her middle-aged parents and what ensues is everything youâ€™d expect from a thirty-something trying to piece their life together in a small British seaside town while locals post poo through the letterbox in protest. Except itâ€™s funny. Really funny and brilliantly written, and beautifully performed â€“ a perfect lunchtime tonic.

Average episode length: 24 minutes

Schittâ€™s Creek

A married couple suddenly go bankrupt and the only remaining asset they have is an ugly small town named Schittâ€™s Creek. And voila, there you have one of 2020â€™s best, multi Emmy-award winning and most progressive comedies in a nutshell.

Average episode length: 21 minutes

Fisk

Recently divorced Helen Fisk (Kitty Flanagan) is re-entering the world of lawyering after moving from Sydney to the Melbourne suburbs. As with any work-based comedy, FiskÂ is filled with relatable moments and recognisable characters, from the easy going work-shy boss to the twenty-something receptionist who refers to himself as the â€œwebmasterâ€.Â

Average episode length: 30 minutes

Bojack Horseman

Another cartoon for adults, Bojack Horseman sees the faded star of a 90s TV show attempt to make a comeback over a decade later. Also, heâ€™s an anthropomorphic horse.

Average episode length: 25 minutes

Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt

At a glance, the critically-acclaimed Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt doesnâ€™t sound like a recipe for happiness. Our eponymous heroine begins episode one in a doomsday bunker, after being kidnapped by a crazy pastor some 15 years ago. This show, though, focuses on her life after her time in the cult, as she reclaims her life by venturing to New York and moving into a flatshare with Titus Andromedas, a gay wannabe Broadway actor. Her wide-eyed enthusiasm as she gets to grips with everyday life? Itâ€™s a recipe for the ultimate feel-good show.

Average episode length: 30 minutes

Loudermilk

Former music journalist Sam Loudermilk (Ron Livingston) is a former alcoholic grudgingly navigating the world of sobriety with hilariously surly rants, even as he guides others in recovery.

Average episode length: 30 minutes

Archer

The final cartoon on the list, Archer follows the day-to-day adventures of its eponymous character, a sexist and moronic spy loosely based on James Bond. Itâ€™s the showâ€™s women, though, who really deserve your attention.Â

Thereâ€™s Pam Poovey, the openly bisexual HR director, and Cheryl / Carol Tunt, a wildly self-aware billionaire with a strangulation fetish. Thereâ€™s Lana Kane, one of the top field agents in the International Secret Intelligence Service â€“ and a working mother, to boot, thanks to her insemination by sperm donor. And thereâ€™s Mallory Archer, a former super-spy who manages the entire operation from her luxurious office â€“ when sheâ€™s not sleeping with the head of the KGB, and Bert Reynolds, or, you know, anyone else who takes her fancy.

Average episode length: 21 minutes

This article was originally published on 13 March 2020, but has been updated to include new Netflix releases.

item.title: Everything you need to know about voter ID this election year
item.description: Since May 2023, UK voters have had to show an accepted form of photo ID at polling stations. Hereâ€™s everything you need to know about voter ID in time for the upcoming May local elections.
item.dc:creator: Shahed Ezaydi
item.content:encoded:
Since May 2023, UK voters have had to show a government-accepted form of photo ID at polling stations to vote in person at most elections. The voting ID rule was introduced in April 2022 through the Elections Act 2022, which brought in voter identification in the UK for the first time. The government claimed that new rules were needed to prevent votes from being stolen or fraudulent, even though the UK has never had a significant problem with voter fraud.

Knowing what documents youâ€™ll need to bring to the polling station can be confusing at the best of times, so weâ€™ve broken down the big questions around voter ID so that you feel prepared to cast your vote.

What are the voter ID rules?

Not all elections or voting methods will require you to show identification. The rules apply to:

  • All local elections in England
  • Mayoral elections, as well as the London Assembly
  • All by-elections and referendums in England
  • Police and crime commissioner elections in England and Wales
  • General elections

You wonâ€™t need to present your ID if youâ€™re voting by post or if youâ€™re voting in local elections in Scotland and Wales or voting for the Scottish or Welsh parliament.

What can I use as a photo ID?

The Electoral Commission lists 22 acceptable forms of identification, including:

  • Passport
  • Driving licence
  • Local travel passes for disabled and older people (60+)
  • Biometric immigration document

The ID has to be the original and not a photocopy but you can use an out-of-date version as long as you look the same in your photo.

What happens if I donâ€™t have a valid form of photo ID?

Anyone registered to vote without an accepted form of identification can apply for a free document known as a Voter Authority Certificate. You donâ€™t need this certificate if youâ€™re voting by post, only if youâ€™re planning on casting your vote in person.

The application is online (or by post) and when applying for a Voter Authority Certificate, you will need to provide your: name, address, date of birth and national insurance number. Youâ€™ll also need to submit a photo to obtain a certificate. Thereâ€™s more information on the Electoral Commissionâ€™s website but the requirements for the photo are similar to what youâ€™d need for a passport photo.

The deadline to apply for free voter ID for the elections on Thursday 2 May is 5pm on Wednesday 24 April.

Image: Getty

item.title: How to find a practical (and stylish) bag: the brands to know and finding the right size for you
item.description: Finding a perfect work bag â€“ one that fits a laptop, lunchbox and anything else you might need to throw in â€“ can be hard. Finding one that fits all this and still manages to look stylish? Even harder. So we tracked down the chicest, most practical bags on the market right now to aid your shopping woes.Â Â
item.dc:creator: Kitty Grady
item.content:encoded:
On any given day, my journey to work can feel more like a game of Buckaroo than a commute. Although I possess a smart-ish leather bag, by the time Iâ€™ve thrown in the dayâ€™s essentials, itâ€™s pretty much at capacity. When it comes to adding in any virtuous extras (packed lunch, pilates kit, change of clothing, make-up bag), I file them carefully into a cotton tote and rely on pockets for smaller items. Any semblance of order is quickly gone, and I am patting myself down at the bus stop, wondering which receptacle contains the wallet I had five minutes earlier. If the frazzled Englishwoman has a discernible street style, then this is surely it.

How is it 2024 and Iâ€™m still relying on a coterie of tote bags to carry me through the working day? Now in my late 20s, I need to find a streamlined solution to this game of sartorial logistics. While the viral Uniqlo Universal bagÂ might have been perfect for festivals and holidays, it definitely wasnâ€™t capacious enough for a working personâ€™s daily essentials. So why does a properly sized bag feel so hard to find? We can blame, in part, the rise of Y2K fashion and its micro baguette bags. But this is changing, thankfully. â€œWeâ€™re seeing a huge obsession with oversized XXL bags at the moment,â€ says Kate Devlin, assistant trends editor at Stylus. â€œWhile weâ€™ve been out of the pandemic for a while now, itâ€™s only recently that weâ€™ve started to see this huge push for people to go back into the office and to be out and about more. From apparel to footwear to bags, this is fuelling a trend towards practicality and pragmatism.â€Â

They allow for both novelty and practicality

Yet such bags donâ€™t have to be boring. Bottega Veneta, the Italian luxury fashion house has driven an aesthetic that tends towards slouchy, oversized shoulder bags in woven intrecciato leather. Elsewhere, fashionable figures such as the Olsen twins have been seen carrying beaten-up HermÃ¨s Birkins with all of their belongings. While Telfar has become another viral favourite for its practical yet fashionable vegan leather bags, often with design collabs in the mix. Brands such as Loewe, Goyard and Miu Miu have been cashing in on the luxury tote sector for years. â€œTheyâ€™re a garment that allows for both novelty and practicality,â€ adds Devlin.

Yet according to Tessa Litchfield, a senior private shopper at Matches Fashion, the most zeitgeisty XL bag right now is The Rowâ€™s Margaux. â€œDeemed by some as the new Birkin,â€ she says, â€œinfluencers are wearing them under their arm like a clutch. Even though they are huge, itâ€™s a cool aesthetic and wonâ€™t wear out the straps if you have it loaded up with a laptop.â€ Having spawned a legion of knock-offs on the high street, its colourways, available in both black and browns, makes it suitable for â€œpreppy girls as much as boho babesâ€.

When it comes to selecting your own day-to-day work bag, Litchfield suggests first considering the practicalities. â€œWhether itâ€™s a trans-seasonal piece youâ€™re after or something to last you through winter and summer, think about your lifestyle. If youâ€™re getting on the Tube, I wouldnâ€™t go for something light coloured.â€ Yet she also suggests seeing it as an investment piece: if itâ€™s something you will use every day, it needs the quality to match. Ultimately, a good, durable bag is something every working person needs, regardless of age or lifestyle. â€œEven Gen Z girls in my office need to bring their laptops to work,â€ says Litchfield. â€œThey might have their mini handbags, but then theyâ€™ll have a tote bag from Marks & Spencer, too.â€

Here, we bring you 12 day-to-day bags that will hold everything you need (and maybe even more).Â

Smart and structured bags

The Saint Laurent Shopping leather tote

The YSL leather tote is the crÃ¨me de la crÃ¨me of leather shoppers. Both sturdy and sleek, its branding is conspicuous enough for those â€˜in the knowâ€™ to know but not so loud it is distracting. With a useful â€œzipped pocket for your precious bitsâ€, notes Litchfield, the style comes in an array of smart neutrals to choose from.Â

The most appealing element of this Freja tote is perhaps the wide girth of the handles which, when carrying a heavy load, are bound to provide some relief. It is roomy enough to fit in a 16-inch laptop, while an array of smaller pockets will keep those itinerant items at bay.Â

item.title: Looking for a light brunch recipe? This Scottish beetroot and spring barley tabbouleh is perfect
item.description: We love a simple recipe that works for brunch, lunch or dinner, and this colourful beetroot recipe ticks all our boxes. Plus, it looks good and does you good.Â
item.dc:creator: Anna Bartter
item.content:encoded:
Springâ€™s finally here, with the evenings drawing out a little and daffodils and blossom in full bloom. Having that bit more daylight can have a radical impact on our mood and energy, as well as our appetite for some fresh and colourful food.

This gorgeous beetroot recipe makes the perfect spring brunch. And itâ€™s as nourishing as it is aesthetically pleasing: beetroot is packed with nutrients and its benefits range from helping to lower blood pressure and improve athletic performance to having powerful anti-oxidant properties that may help to ward off disease.

Not to mention the fact that the tabbouleh, along with providing some texture, is a great source of fibre, while a scattering of pumpkin and sunflower seeds gives our gut health a boost, too.Â

Scottish beetroot with honey and miso glaze and spring barley tabbouleh

â€œThis Scottish beetroot and pearl barley tabbouleh is the perfect healthy springtime brunch,â€ says Clare Coghill, chef and founder of CafÃ© CÃ¹il.Â

â€œThis recipe serves two, but I recommend doubling or tripling it up to store in the fridge and use as a quick and easy meal prep for the rest of the week. The pearl barley provides slow-release energy, while the mix of herbs, vegetables, seeds and grains have loads of healthy benefits.â€

For the beetroot

Ingredients

  • 1 large beetroot
  • 1 tsp miso paste
  • 1 tbsp Scottish honey (or use maple syrup to make it vegan)

Method

  1. Peel your beetroot, and boil in a pan until tender.
  2. Remove from the water and allow to cool, before chopping into rough wedges.
  3. Melt your honey (or maple) and miso paste together in a pot on the hob over a low heat.
  4. Add your wedges of beetroot, and toss in the sauce until evenly coated and sticky.
  5. Remove from the pot.

For the tabbouleh

Ingredients

  • 150g pearl barley
  • 1 leaf of spring greens, roughly chopped
  • Bunch of parsley, finely chopped
  • Bunch of mint, finely chopped
  • Cherry tomatoes, roughly chopped
  • Juice of 1 lemon
  • Handful of toasted sunflower or pumpkin seeds
  • 1 tbsp extra virgin olive oil
  • Salt and pepper

Method

  1. Rinse your pearl barley thoroughly, before adding to a large saucepan with 500ml of cold, salted water.
  2. Bring the water to a boil, and boil for 10 minutes. Reduce to a simmer and cook for a further 45 minutes. Once cooked to al dente, drain the water and add the pearl barley back to the pot, but keep it off the heat.
  3. Add in your roughly chopped spring greens and tomatoes, your finely chopped parsley and mint (leaving some aside to garnish with at the end), the juice of a lemon, and a healthy glug of olive oil. Toss until incorporated and season to taste with salt and pepper.
  4. Leave to cool to room temperature before serving.
  5. Top your tabbouleh mix with your sweet and savoury wedges of beetroot and sprinkle with fresh parsley, mint and pumpkin or sunflower seeds.

Images:Â CafÃ© CÃ¹il

item.title: 5 hotels to book for a lazy girl summer in Europe
item.description: Weâ€™ve rounded up five of the best European spots for an ultra laid-back summer breakâ€¦
item.dc:creator: ShadÃ© Owomoyela
item.content:encoded:
Spring may have sprung but the unpredictable showers and fleeting sunshine still have us dreaming of escapes to warmer shores.

And while we all love a city break full of sightseeing and exploration, thereâ€™s something particularly decadent about a holiday spent mostly horizontally.Â

Lying by the pool. Lying on the beach. Floating on a lilo. Sleeping in without guilt. All perfectly respectable holiday pastimes that just donâ€™t feel as luxurious in the UK, even when weâ€™re blessed with good weather.

Luckily for you, thereâ€™s no need to suffer through a long-haul flight to get your slice of holiday heaven. In fact, weâ€™ve found a crop of European gems that will have you donning sunnies and shorts in under four hours.Â

So, if youâ€™re looking for a break thatâ€™s positively frivolous, below is our edit of the best spots to enjoy a lazy girl holiday in Europe this summerâ€¦

Phaea Blue Palace, Elounda, Crete

Palatial extravagance meets villa chic at family-run hotel Phaea Blue Palace. Perched on the Elounda coast and overlooking the historical island of Spinalonga, thereâ€™s no better place to sunbathe, switch off and live out your White Lotus fantasies. 

Start your days nibbling fresh fruit and eating made-to-order Cretan omelette at the terrace restaurant and spend your afternoons lounging by either of two pools or on the private beach. If youâ€™re feeling adventurous, a traditional caÃ¯que boat trip is a must for expansive views of the glittering Aegean Sea.

Bed and breakfast stays for two, from â‚¬334 per night.

Cooks Club, Corfu

If youâ€™re a foodie with a penchant for the dreamy boho aesthetic, youâ€™ll be right at home at Cookâ€™s Club. Nestled in the crook of Kommeno Bay, this adults-only haven is the perfect spot to enjoy traditional Greek delicacies and conquer your list of summer reads.

Yoga, Pilates, tennis and a wellness suite (complete with spa and sauna) cater for those who like to stay active during their down time while resident DJs and live bands set the mood with uplifting beats. You can even graze on street food and Ã la carte dishes without leaving your lounger â€“ simply order via your smartphone. If thatâ€™s not lazy girl luxury, we donâ€™t know what is.

Bed and board stays for two, from â‚¬300 per night.

Hotel Claude, Marbella

If youâ€™re searching for a serene escape but want to be close enough to the action to join in as you please, this is the place for you. Once a 17th century manor house, Hotel Claude overlooks the bustling town of Marbella and is considered its first boutique hotel.Â

With seven rooms capturing the essence of Andalusia, whether youâ€™re savouring a late lunch on the rooftop terrace or sipping cocktails in the glamorous patio gallery, youâ€™re sure to feel at home. A 10-minute stroll will take you to Playa del Alicate, home to Marbellaâ€™s iconic strip of beach clubs. The best part? Itâ€™s just a two-hour flight from London.

Bed and breakfast stays for two, from â‚¬336 per night.

La Plage, Saint Raphael

Dreaming of some downtime on theÂ CÃ´te dâ€™Azur? La Plage is happy to make those dreams a reality. With two heated outdoor pools (one of which boasts a stunning sea view), an all-inclusive offering and a beach less than 50m away, the classic summer holiday comforts of this spot make it the perfect place to unwind and relax.Â

Pad down to the beach for a day of soaking in the sun and exploring the coves of the Esterel. Or, rent a bike and cycle 20 minutes into the centre ofÂ Saint Raphael to enjoy the treasures of the harbour and get the full French Riviera experience.

Comfort double for two with breakfast, from â‚¬198 per night.

Ohla, Barcelona

Renowned as one of the most vibrant city break destinations, youâ€™d be forgiven for thinking you canâ€™t find a peaceful retreat in the centre of Barcelona. But just off of the iconic Via Latena, youâ€™ll find Ohla, a stylish and elegant hotel complete with a rooftop pool and its very own Michelin-starred restaurant.

Marrying the neo-classical charm of the gothic quarter with contemporary art and the warmth of Catalan hospitality, this inner city haven makes for an opulent yet laid-back break. Plus, the beach is just a 10-minute walk away. Whatâ€™s not to love?

Room-only rates for two, from â‚¬356 per night.

item.title: â€œIâ€™m a fashion director, and I think Iâ€™ve cracked the perfect workwear formulaâ€
item.description: Is there anything harder than getting dressed for work? Well, yesâ€¦ so, so many things. But at 8.05am, when you should have left home a good 20 minutes ago, getting dressed feels really hard.Â Â
item.dc:creator: Lucy Reber
item.content:encoded:
In my mind, workday dressing should be a wonderful ritual that sets you up for the day. The reality is that I spend an hour lovingly doing my daughterâ€™s hair, carefully washing her face and helping her pick out her perfect pink-on-pink outfit. Afterwards, a scrappy four minutes remain for me to throw on anything clean and vaguely presentable.

I think about clothes all the time â€“ obviously, thatâ€™s my job â€“ and Iâ€™ve been trying to move away from a formulaic way of dressing to something more creative and joyful. But, you know what? 7.55am on a Monday calls for formulaic; itâ€™s all my busy mind and schedule can take at that time.

So, I am pleased to report that Iâ€™ve finally cracked it. The perfect workwear formula that works every time. Itâ€™s based on three core elements that I am reasonably confident most of us already have in our wardrobes. And if you donâ€™t? Buying them will be a smart investment for your sanity.

First up, the core of the outfit is a wide-leg trouser. We have talked about these so much at Stylist recently and the reason isâ€¦ they are fabulous. Smart yet relaxed. They mean business but are of the moment. And crucially, theyâ€™re comfy. I bought a pair from The Frankie Shop in December and I wear them three times a week, maybe four. Cost per wear, you canâ€™t fault them. Theyâ€™re black, high-waisted and have a pleated front. Cos also has a brilliant pair â€“ see below.Â

Cos

Merino wool knitted top, Â£35

Classic leather belt, Â£45

Wide-leg tailored trousers, Â£95

Then with this core trouser you need to wear a basic top. Depending on the type of day you have in front of you, this could be a crisp white T-shirt, an oversized shirt, a v-neck knit or a slimline cardigan. All of the above will work with minimal fuss â€“ just pick what works best for you. If your office requires a smarter outfit, opt for a masculine shirt tucked in and wear with square-toe loafers. You can even add a blazer if you wish. If your office is more informal, a T-shirt and bright retro trainers will look slick.Â

And the final piece of the magic wardrobe puzzle is a belt. When some of my chicest friends started to wear belts again after many years in the sartorial wilderness, I was unconvinced. But, as ever, they were right and a slim leather belt with a metal buckle is the quickest way to elevate a simple look for the workday. It pulls together two simple basics and turns them into something more.Â

This workwear formula has got me through the first three months of 2024, and I plan to utilise it for the rest of the year. So my advice is: buy yourself a belt. It will update your simple separates in an instant. You wonâ€™t regret it.Â Â

Jigsaw

Leather belt, Â£60

Kemp wide leg trousers, Â£220

item.title: Beetlejuice 2 has released a brand-new trailer and release date
item.description: After years of speculation, a sequel to beloved cult classic Beetlejuice is coming to our screens this autumn â€“ with Wednesday star Jenna Ortega in a leading role.Â
item.dc:creator: Amy Beecham
item.content:encoded:
The horror genre has experienced something of a revival in recent years, with cult classics includingÂ Scream,Â The Exorcist and The Addams Family all being reimagined for contemporary audiences via sequels and spin-offs. Last spring, Warner Bros announced that a sequel to Tim Burtonâ€™s 1988 filmÂ BeetlejuiceÂ was in the works (aptly named Beetlejuice Beetlejuice).

The first snippet of info we got about the film was last month, when Jenna Ortega, star of Netflixâ€™s Wednesday, revealed she was taking a starring role.Â

â€œI donâ€™t know how much Iâ€™m allowed to say, but I am Lydia Deetzâ€™s daughter, so Iâ€™ll give that away,â€ Ortega revealed in an interview with Vanity Fair.

Played by Winona Ryder, Lydia Deetz was the character at the heart of the original Beetlejuice film. A teenage goth who can see ghosts, Lydia has more than a little in common with Wednesday Addams, the role that catapulted Ortega to global fame back in 2022.Â

In a full-circle moment, Wednesday was also directed by Tim Burton, who has returned to direct the Beetlejuice sequel.

Hereâ€™s everything else we know about the repriseâ€¦Â

Who is starring in Beetlejuice Beetlejuice?Â

Fans of the original will be thrilled to learn that Michael Keaton is reprising the role of Beetlejuice himself, while Winona Ryder returns as Lydia Deetz and Jenna Ortega will take on the role of Lydiaâ€™s teenage daughter, Astrid.Â

Astrid is â€œweird, but in a different way and not in the way youâ€™d assumeâ€, Ortega said on the role, adding that her characterâ€™s relationship with Lydia will be a â€œvery importantâ€ part of the upcoming film.

While Astrid wonâ€™t be seen â€œwearing pink and [being] a cheerleaderâ€, she will want to push â€œagainst [her] momâ€™s history or pastâ€, Ortega said: â€œAny kid who becomes a teenager wants to be removed from their parents. I think they instantly just fight whatever it is that their parent loves.â€Â

As a result, Lydia and Astrid will â€œbutt heads quite a bitâ€ in the film, she continued.Â

The brilliant Catherine Oâ€™Hara (Schittâ€™s Creek) also returns in her role as Lydiaâ€™s step-mother Delia Deetz, while new cast members will be introduced including Justin Theroux (Star Wars: Episode VIII â€“ The Last Jedi), Monica Bellucci (Spectre, The Matrix), Arthur Conti (House Of The Dragon) and Oscar nominee Willem Dafoe (Poor Things, At Eternityâ€™s Gate).

What is the plot of Beetlejuice Beetlejuice?Â

The film will again be set in the fictional town of Winter River in Connecticut. When an unexpected family tragedy occurs, three generations of the Deetz family return home. Still haunted by Beetlejuice, Lydiaâ€™s life is turned upside down when her rebellious teenage daughter, Astrid, discovers the mysterious model of the town in the attic and the portal to the Afterlife is accidentally opened. With trouble brewing in both realms, itâ€™s only a matter of time until someone says Beetlejuiceâ€™s name three times and the mischievous demon returns to unleash his very own brand of mayhem.

Tim Burton returns to direct the film, alongside Wednesday screenplay writers Alfred Gough and Miles Millar.Â

When does Beetlejuice Beetlejuice come out?Â

It looks like we donâ€™t have to wait tooÂ long to get our fix, as the film will hit UK cinemas on 6 September 2024.Â

The original Beetlejuice film was a critical and commercial success, grossing US$74.7 million (Â£60m) from a budget of just $15 million (Â£12m). It followed a deceased couple who enlist a spirit named Beetlejuice to help them rid their home of its new inhabitants.Â

In a new interview, Keaton said that he and Burton were initially nervous about making a Beetlejuice sequel, but it was worth it in the end.

â€œWe thought, â€˜You got to get this right. Otherwise, just donâ€™t do it. Letâ€™s just go on with our lives and do other things.â€™ So I was hesitant and cautious, and [Burton] was probably equally as hesitant and cautious over all these years,â€ he told People magazine. â€œOnce we got there, I said, â€˜OK, letâ€™s just go for it. Letâ€™s just see if we can do it, if we can pull this off.â€™â€

Beetlejuice Beetlejuice is out in UK cinemas on 6 SeptemberÂ

Images:Â Warner Bros

item.title: The preppy bob is a super-chic haircut that requires minimal effort to maintain
item.description: Taking inspiration from Hailey Bieber, this is what you need to know about this seasonâ€™s coolest style.Â
item.dc:creator: Lucy Partington
item.content:encoded:
You might have seen videos of the preppy bob doing the rounds; like so many other things in your beauty routine and wardrobe, itâ€™s a style thatâ€™s inspired by Hailey Bieber.

But more than that, itâ€™s a style thatâ€™s ideal if youâ€™re at the stage where you feel like your hair needs a break, whether thatâ€™s from regular heat styling, colour or something else entirely. â€œItâ€™s a mid-neck, jaw-skimming sort of cut thatâ€™s designed to be understyled,â€ says Adam Reed, founder of Arkive Headcare.

â€œIâ€™ve seen various iterations of this sort of cut trending since the spring, and while it is a version of Hailey Bieberâ€™s style, the thing thatâ€™s nice about it is that itâ€™s so undone that you really donâ€™t need to over-do it with styling,â€ explains Reed.Â

How to get the preppy bob look

If itâ€™s a style youâ€™re thinking of getting, Reed says you should ask your stylist for a â€œmid-neck, jaw-skimming shapeâ€ and then make sure that thereâ€™s some softness added around the front, so the cut is working to help contour your face. â€œThen the weight of the hair needs reducing â€“ thatâ€™s something thatâ€™ll be personalised for each individual â€“ but thatâ€™s what will give it a slightly grungy, worn-in feel,â€ he adds.

Another thing thatâ€™s great about the preppy bob is that itâ€™s not a high-maintenance cut by any stretch. Reed even suggests going a little bit shorter and then you can let it grow through for longer. â€œThe key is that youâ€™re really not doing that much to it at all, and if your hair is in good condition to start with then this sort of style will allow it to stay that way.â€

When it comes to styling, less is more. â€œItâ€™s supposed to look groomed rather than rigidly styled,â€ says Reed. â€œMy recommendation is to use shampoo and conditioner as normal, and interchange that with masks every few washes. Then you can work a hydrating cream â€“ like Arkiveâ€™s The Good Calmer, Â£13, into damp hair. I like to comb it through to ensure even distribution, and then let it dry naturally or use a diffuser; not to create a curl but just to dry it off.â€

And there we have it: the ultimate low-maintenance, on-trend style thatâ€™s loved by Hailey Bieber. Consider us sold.Â

item.title: Everything you need to know about the H&M x Rokh collaboration
item.dc:creator: Emma Ã“ CuinneagÃ¡in
item.content:encoded:

But joining the line-up of famous luxury labels â€“ including Rabanne, Simone Rocha, Moschino and Erdem â€“ is an emerging designer whoâ€™s relatively unknown compared to the partnerships who have come before.

Partnering withÂ H&M is likely to launch Rokh into the limelight, propelling it from a fashion insider favourite to a household name.Â

Speaking about the collaboration, Rok Hwang says: â€œRokh designs have a classic appearance with a radical construction for a timeless approach to design. Iâ€™m very excited to share our vision with more customers around the world thanks to this milestone collection with H&M.â€

Ann-Sofie Johansson, creative advisor and head of design womenswear at H&M, added: â€œRokh is at the forefront of a new wave of Korean designers whose conceptual yet wearable clothes are captivating fashion right now. Weâ€™re proud to present a curated edit of designer Rok Hwangâ€™s adaptable wardrobe classics, and we canâ€™t wait to see how our customers wear them.â€

The curated edit is rumoured to be a 58-piece collection launching in-store at select locations and online at H&M on 18 April. Hero pieces will include Rokhâ€™s signature styles, such as a double-layer trench coat, detachable-hem dresses, corset-style pieces, office-ready bags and statement jewellery.
