item.title: â€œWhoever you are, you are the lead in your own storyâ€: Wunmi Mosaku on the power of fear and her new thriller Passenger
item.description: Ahead of the ITV premiere of Passenger, Stylist caught up with its lead, Wunmi Mosaku, to talk all things thrillers, the power of fear and the importance of representation on screen.
item.dc:creator: Shahed Ezaydi
item.content:encoded:
It can be a tricky thing trying to balance comedic elements with a suspenseful thrillerÂ but ITVâ€™s new series, Passenger, strikes that balance perfectly. The tense pacing of the series coupled with witty one-liners brings a freshness to the genre thatâ€™ll keep you gripped from the first episode. Thatâ€™s not to mention how great it is to hear northern accents on TV as a Yorkshire girl myself.

Set in a fictional town called Chadder Vale, the six-part series explores a small town community that shares a real distrust of outsiders. Five years before the drama begins, former Met police detective Riya Ajunwa arrives in town and has been waiting for a proper crime to investigate ever since. There are only so many stolen bins her police officers can look intoâ€¦Â

But one night, local girl Katie Wells disappears. However, the weirdest part of Katieâ€™s disappearance is that the next day she reappears, seemingly totally fine. The townâ€™s residents remain unbothered, but Riya thinks thereâ€™s something off about the whole thing. She might be right. And as more crimes begin to unfold, the viewer is left wondering: why is the show called Passenger?

Leading the charge in Passenger as DIÂ Riya Ajunwa is Bafta-winning actor Wunmi Mosaku, best known for her roles in Loki, His House and Lovecraft Country. â€œIâ€™m nervous! It feels surreal that itâ€™s finally happening and will be out in the world soon,â€ Mosaku tells Stylist over Zoom. The actor came across the project in a slightly unconventional way, having heard about it from Andrew Buchan (the writer of the series) after theyâ€™d reconnected at a fundraiser a few years ago.

â€œWe were just catching up on what we were doing and I had mentioned how much I love boxing and he told me that what he was writing might be for me. He sent me the script, and from that moment on, he started working on drafts with me in mind,â€ says Mosaku. She was drawn to the script from the very beginning and credited Buchanâ€™s writing with how gripped she was. Mosaku is dyslexic so reading is often â€œa choreâ€ for her. â€œItâ€™s rare that I find a script that I can get through relatively quickly.â€

A major element of Passenger is fear and what that emotion can make people do. â€œFor Riya, Chadder feels like a safe space in a way but thereâ€™s also a lot of frustration. Itâ€™s fear that keeps her there and itâ€™s fear that affects and shapes the local community. What do we do when we have to face those feelings? And to what lengths do we go to avoid facing those fears?â€ asks Mosaku.

Even though the actor has been involved in several thriller-esque projects, sheâ€™s not typically a fan of the genre as a viewer. â€œItâ€™s not something I tend to watch as I donâ€™t like the feeling of being scared; I find myself drawn to light-hearted comedies,â€ she says. Mosaku is mostly drawn to good writing that â€œholds my attentionâ€ and thatâ€™s been clever dramas and thrillers of late. Interestingly, she enjoys reading thrillers but watching them? Not so much.

Rooted in the north of England, the Loki actor felt at home on set as she grew up just down the road in Manchester. â€œThe warmth and welcoming energy of the north was definitely present on set.â€ However, as itâ€™s Mosakuâ€™s first time leading a show, she wanted to make sure the energy on set was light and joyful â€“ especially when filming a thriller. The actor explains that sheâ€™s been on sets where the showâ€™s lead has been grumpy or tense and she wanted to do things differently.

So, who did she take inspiration from? â€œTom Hiddleston was such a joyful leader and you could ask him anything â€“ he honestly knew the Loki scripts inside out â€“ and I wanted my set to feel like that too.â€

FromÂ VigilÂ toÂ Happy Valley and nowÂ Passenger, weâ€™ve seen several thrillers and crime dramas being led by women in recent years. But this series is one of the first British thrillers to be led by a Black woman, which is something that Mosaku hasnâ€™t really seen before. Representation is important for the actor as it allows everyone to feel seen and valued, and we all deserve to see reflections of ourselves on screen.Â

â€œIt feels great to have a Black full-figured woman lead on a TV show like this because whoever you are, whatever your background, you are the lead in your experiences.â€

Passenger launches on ITV1 and ITVX on Sunday 24 March at 9pm

Images:Â Ashley Randall; ITV

item.title: Nine Perfect Strangers season 2: everything we know about the Liane Moriarty drama sequel
item.description: Nine Perfect Strangers, theÂ Liane Moriarty adaptation, is returning for season 2 â€“ watch this space for your next TV thriller addiction.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Rapana
item.content:encoded:
Nine Perfect Strangers was a huge hit when it aired back in 2021. A psychological thriller, starring Nicole Kidman, Melissa McCarthy, Manny Jacinto and Luke Evans, it follows the story of nine strangers who are pitched together at a remote health resort led by an enigmatic, cult-like figure. Each has their own reasons for checking in, from grief-stricken parents to a struggling novelist and a Lottery-winning couple whose marriage is on the edge.Â And now the TV show is back for season two, still revolving around the same wellness resort and Kidmanâ€™s intense character Masha.

Based on Liane Moriartyâ€™s novel by the same name, the TV adaption was created by David E Kelley, who also bought the Moriarty adaption Big Little Lies to HBO.Â

Who is in the cast of Nine Perfect Strangers season 2?

Nicole Kidman returns as Masha, but this time featuring a new cast of strangers, including Henry Golding (Peter), Mark Strong (David) and Lena Olin (Helena).Â

They join a cast including Christine Baranski (The Good Fight, The Good Wife, Mamma Mia!)Â The White Lotusâ€™s Murray Bartlett, Schittâ€™s Creek star Annie Murphy and other recurring cast members including Dolly De Leon, Maisie Richardson-Sellers, King Princess, Aras Aydin and Lucas Englander.

What is Nine Perfect Strangers about?

The first season focused on nine strangers who are thrown into one anotherâ€™s lives as they arrive together for an intensive programme at a much-hyped wellness retreat tucked away in the Australian outback. Each has their own reasons for checking in, from grief-stricken parents to a struggling novelist and a Lottery-winning couple whose marriage is on the edge.Â

The resort is run by Masha, a glamorous yet elusive figure who is on a mission to reinvigorate her guests â€“ and possibly mess with their minds. The writer, Frances, is grappling with a broken heart, but she soon becomes transfixed by the retreatâ€™s charismatic host.

Is Masha really as devoted to wellbeing as she seems? Or is there something more sinister lurking beneath the surface of her clean-living facade?Â

Who was in season one ofÂ Nine Perfect Strangers?

An all-star cast featured in season one alongside Nicole Kidman, withÂ Melissa McCarthyÂ playing one of the protagonists, lost-soul novelist Frances, as well as serving as an executive producer for the show. This marked the actorâ€™sÂ first leading TV role since her 2016 Emmy-winning performance in Mike & Molly.

Michael Shannon, Asher Keddie and Grace Van Patten starred as the Marconi family, grieving the death of their son and brother, while Luke Evans took on the role of Lars Lee, an undercover journalist there with a hidden agenda.

Melvin Gregg and Samara Weaving portrayed a young couple who had won the lottery, Regina Hall took on the role of a single mother of four children whose husband left her for a younger woman, and Bobby Cannavale plays Tony Hogburn, an ex-American football player struggling with a drug addiction.

Is there a trailer for Nine Perfect Strangers season 2?

Not yet, but what we do know is that the guests will stay at a Swiss Alps resort this time rather than the Australian outback.

When will Nine Perfect StrangersÂ season 2 air?

Thereâ€™s no definitive word on when the new season will air, but watch this space.

Images: Getty

item.title: â€œMy experience of a missed miscarriage changed everything â€“ we need to have the space to talk about baby lossâ€
item.description: â€œMy experience of a missed miscarriage was everything youâ€™d expect it to be, but itâ€™s also been the catalyst for great change,â€ writes Freya Bugeja.Â
item.dc:creator: Freya Bugeja
item.content:encoded:
Content note: this article contains descriptions of miscarriage and baby loss that readers may find upsetting.

â€œIâ€™m so sorry,â€ she said.

Somewhere inside, I already knew the worst had happened. Call it womenâ€™s intuition, but the day before our early 10-week scan I had told my husband that Iâ€™d be more surprised to hear a heartbeat than not. He looked at me as if I was going mad. After all, everything seemed to be ticking along nicely. But â€˜knowingâ€™ didnâ€™t lessen the pain of learning I had lost my baby.

Itâ€™s funny: we always knew weâ€™d have two kids, but weâ€™d never discussed having more than that. It became clear to me when my youngest was about 18 months old that I wasnâ€™t done. I felt a strange ache I couldnâ€™t shake.

I pushed hard to get my husband on board. Eventually, after heâ€™d reviewed the finances with multiple fine-toothed combs, he said yes, and we agreed to start trying in September 2023. It was all mapped out: we wanted a three-year school gap, I was hellbent on being 34 and we had a trip to Australia planned in February that I didnâ€™t want to be in the first trimester for. We even discussed how weâ€™d amend our childcare situation, how weâ€™d secure a nursery place shortly after conception and brainstormed how weâ€™d spend my husbandâ€™s new 10-week paternity leave allowance, which would land over the summer monthsÂ â€“ perhaps a month away in Lisbon?Â

Iâ€™ve never seen my face so swollen, crumpled and red

After becoming pregnant on the first attempt with our two daughters, sailing through both pregnancies and experiencing uncomplicated births, we were quietly expecting things to fall into place for us again. But as we started trying, I had a strange sense that something was different this time around. In the run-up to September, I had the unpleasant sensation of treading water as I waited for my â€˜fertile windowâ€™, and when it came to the dreaded two-week wait before you get a reliable test result, I found myself manically peeing on plastic sticks even though I knew it was way too early. I did one in the grubby loos of a train back from London after work, and one in a department store toilet in Tunbridge Wells, where I live, on the walk home from the station. Despite knowing it was too early, I would still feel depleted when the second line didnâ€™t show. It was exhausting and felt compulsive. Finally, at home with my husband at 6.15am, we saw the second line faintly appear on the test. Weâ€™d managed it after only one attempt for the third time, and I was both relieved and thrilled and hoped my nerves would finally dissipate.

And they did for a bit. The first few weeks were great, but the feeling didnâ€™t last. Around week five, my anxiety bubbled up. At six weeks, nausea and food aversions kicked in. But I couldnâ€™t shake the niggling thought that something wasnâ€™t right. At nine weeks, I went to the toilet and saw a smear of blood on the tissue â€“ not much, not even enough to have left a stain, but I was sufficiently worried that I went to the GP, dragging my daughters with me.

That was on a Friday. The doctors said they couldnâ€™t tell me anything without a scan, and booked me in for one on Wednesday before sending me off with a pamphlet about miscarriage, printed on greying NHS paper.Â

In the days between, I tried to ignore that pamphlet. I told myself everything would be fine. Finally, the day of the scan arrived and I headed to the hospital alone â€“ my husband had to be in Margate for an interview, and I assumed it would be fine for him to miss such an early scan. On arrival, I filled in a form, oscillating between hope, confidence and preparation for the worst. I imagined the call I would make to my husband to tell him everything was fineâ€¦ and the one Iâ€™d have to make if it wasnâ€™t.

I lay down on the bed, braced for the cold of the ultrasound gel and waited to hear a heartbeat. Nothing. The sonographer noted the measurements of the foetus at seven weeks, so perhaps it was too small for the heartbeat to be heard using this method. But at that moment, I knew. We did an internal ultrasound regardless, only to hear more deafening silence. Finally, the sonographer said it: â€œIâ€™m so sorry. Thereâ€™s no heartbeat.â€

I was told it was protocol to get a second opinion, so a second nurse repeated the test. To hear that silence, followed by the confirmation that there was no heartbeat, not once but twice was agony. I lay there sobbing. Iâ€™d had whatâ€™s called a missed or silent miscarriage, where the foetus dies or stops developing but there are no physical symptoms. According to What To Expect, a pregnancy advice website, one study estimates that fewer than 3% of pregnancies end in a missed or silent miscarriage. The odds were so low, yet there I was.

When I called my husband, I didnâ€™t know how to say it, so I went with: â€œI was right.â€ AndÂ when he didnâ€™t quite understand what I meant I followed it up with: â€œThereâ€™s no heartbeat.â€Â

I have never experienced crying like I did then. I sobbed in the toilet as I put my clothes back on, then in a quiet room where I sat on my own for an hour and waited for my husband to pick me up. Iâ€™ve never seen my face so swollen, crumpled and red. I didnâ€™t look like myself anymore.

During that hour, I got in touch with my friends. I told my best friend that I didnâ€™t want the doctors to take my baby out of me, the obvious next step. I told her that I felt I had failed. She did all the right things: she didnâ€™t try to make it better, and just said how awful it was, how unbelievable, and that she was as broken by it as I was â€“ the exact validation I needed. Another friend immediately went into â€˜mumâ€™ mode and told me she would pick up my eldest daughter from school and bought us sandwiches and snacks so weâ€™d have something to eat when we arrived home. It hit me in that moment that my friends are truly heroes.

Just over an hour later my husband arrived, red-eyed. There we were, together in the god-awful quiet room with lavender and butterflies crawling up the walls and an inexplicable lava lamp in the corner. Waiting. Crying. Talking. Itâ€™s one of the few times in as long as I can remember that we have had the chance to really talk to each other; life is hectic all the time and at the end of the day we just want to turn into TV zombies and forget the stresses. I told him that maybe we were meant to be a family of four. I had said previously that if this pregnancy didnâ€™t work out, we wouldnâ€™t try again â€“ something said flippantly by someone with the quiet confidence that all would be fine. He surprised me by saying that this had made him realise he wanted to be a family of five. Sometimes it takes a huge loss to help you realise what it is you truly want.

A doctor came in to explain our three options: to wait for my body to expel the tissue naturally, to use a pessary to soften the cervix and induce contractions (I was horrified to hear that sometimes not all the tissue passes and surgery is needed, and other times it doesnâ€™t work at all) or to undergo surgery under general anaesthetic.Â

I opted for surgical management, known as a dilation and curettage procedure (D&C for short). We were having our kitchen done and downstairs floors put in. We were living in chaos, with workmen coming in and out. No kitchen sink meant we were washing up outside in a basin and you had to crawl over boxes to get to the sofa or a pan. It was a lot on its own with two small children, but going through a physical miscarriage at home, with the pain and the blood, was unfathomable. We were booked in for the following Monday, the earliest they could do, and after almost five hours in hospital, we finally went home. I am so grateful to that friend who bought the sandwiches and snacks.

The next few days were a mess of more crying and absolute exhaustion. My body had been trying to tell me for months how rundown I was, but I hadnâ€™t listened, ignoring the eczema on my face, the small fissures that refused to heal, the overwhelming anxiety. Now, it all seemed to be piling on top of me at once. I found myself crying at random intervals of the day because everything felt pointless. I kept carrying the mental load of maintaining the house, despite the monotony of daily life seeming futile.

On a particularly difficult day, the day I had my pre-surgery swabs, I raged at my husband and jumped out of our slow-moving car to get away from him, spitting some of the cruellest things that have ever come out of my mouth. At the time I very much meant it, but of course my hormones were raging, and I just didnâ€™t know how to cope.

The surgery went well. I had been terrified that it would start naturally beforehand but it didnâ€™t. I cried right before I was taken down for the operation, struck by the realisation that when I woke up I would no longer be pregnant.

Two weeks later, I had to take a pregnancy test to make sure my body had responded. All those times I had stared at tests searching for that second pink link â€“ it felt like a cruel twist to now be hoping for the opposite.Â

My body had been trying to tell me how rundown I was

Itâ€™s now months later and I have used this immense low as the urge I needed to make some radical changes to my life. I took the entirety of December off work to recalibrate, quitting my job and going freelance to have more control over my hours. Iâ€™m prioritising myself more, ensuring I have non-negotiable time alone carved into my week. My husband and I are communicating better. Iâ€™m letting go of my passive aggression and being more direct with what I need.Â

The biggest change for me, though, is accepting and asking for help more readily. Iâ€™ve found this hard to do in the past as I have felt like a failure if I canâ€™t do it all. But my experience of miscarriage has taught me I canâ€™t do it all, and people really do want to help. These tiny, incremental changes have helped in mammoth ways. My anxiety has been tempered, my eczema has cleared, my shoulders have descended back to where they should be, Iâ€™m less angry and Iâ€™m only crying at appropriate moments.Â

Aside from these smaller lifestyle changes, I have also started therapy and Iâ€™m even working with a life coach, something I never thought Iâ€™d do. Iâ€™ve learned that I canâ€™t look after anyone properly if Iâ€™m not looking after myself. You really do need to put your oxygen mask on first before helping others.

Out of that dark pit of despair, I am hopeful that one day in the not-too-distant future I will look back and be able to say that if the miscarriage hadnâ€™t happened, I wouldnâ€™t be where I am today, and I will smile in thanks to that baby who never was.Â

Despite most people knowing that one in five pregnancies end in miscarriage, for some reason it is still a taboo subject. And once the dust has settled, there rarely feels like an appropriate time to bring it up. How do you drop the topic of baby loss into a conversation? Despite this, over the past few months, Iâ€™ve mentioned my miscarriage and, in turn, Iâ€™ve heard the stories of others. It doesnâ€™t make it hurt any less, but it has felt cathartic and has removed some misplaced shame I have felt. I want women â€“ and men â€“ to be able to talk about their experiences more openly, so if one day someone finds themselves going through it, they donâ€™t feel alone.

Images: Freya Bugeja; Getty

item.title: Greyâ€™s Anatomy season 20: weâ€™re finally getting new episodes of the medical drama â€“ with Ellen Pompeo, no less!
item.description: Itâ€™s been a long time coming, but the UK will soon be able to head back to Grey Sloan Hospital in Greyâ€™s Anatomy season 20.Â
item.dc:creator: Kayleigh Dray
item.content:encoded:
If youâ€™re in the mood for a series filled to the brim with impossibly attractive people in surprisingly well-fitting scrubs, youâ€™re in luck! The much-anticipated return of Greyâ€™s Anatomy is finally upon us, with its 20th season (yes, really) poised to drop on Disney+ this month.

This season of Greyâ€™s will be markedly different to all those that have come before it, as itâ€™s the very first not to feature Meredith Grey (Ellen Pompeo) as a series regular.

While her character said goodbye in season 19, longtime fans of the show neednâ€™t fear: much as Vanessa Redgraveâ€™s Jennifer Worth still narrates Call The Midwife (despite the fact her on-screen counterpart left the show many seasons ago), Pompeo will still be voicing the intros and outros to each episode. And she will appear in four episodes of season 20, too â€“ hopefully in a less dark and twisty way than weâ€™ve become used to over the years. Hell, if anyone can use a little happiness, itâ€™s Meredith â€˜Bad Luck Follows Me Wherever I Goâ€™ Grey.

Watch the trailer for Greyâ€™s Anatomy season 20 below:

Intrigued? Hereâ€™s what you need to know about the upcoming episodes.

What is Greyâ€™s Anatomy season 20 about?

As ever and always, the series will follow â€œthe team of doctors at Grey Sloan Memorial who are faced with life-or-death decisions on a daily basisâ€, as per the official synopsis.

â€œThey seek comfort from one another, and, at times, more than just friendship. Together they discover that neither medicine nor relationships can be defined in black and white.â€

So, expect a lot of medical jargon, high-octane drama and sexual tension. Not necessarily in that order.

Who will star in Greyâ€™s Anatomy season 20?

Pompeo may be stepping out of the limelight, but that doesnâ€™t mean there wonâ€™t be more than enough doctors and interns to root for this time around.

Chandra Wilson, for starters, is back as our beloved Dr Miranda Bailey, while James Pickens Jr will be reprising his role as Dr Richard Webber.

We have a ragtag group of interns in the form of Lucas (Niko Terho), as well as Blue (Harry Shum Jr), Jules (Adelaide Kane), Mika (Midori Francis) and Simone (Alexis Floyd) â€“ all of whom face an uncertain future after the events of last season.

We will also see the return of:

  • Kevin McKidd as Owen Hunt
  • Kim Raver as Teddy Altman
  • Caterina Scorsone as Amelia Shepherd
  • Camilla Luddington as Jo Wilson
  • Scott Speedman as Nick Marsh
  • Chris Carmack as Atticus â€˜Linkâ€™ Lincoln
  • Anthony Hill as Winston Ndugu
  • Jake Borelli as Levi Schmitt
  • Jessica Capshaw as Dr Arizona Robbins
  • Alex Landi as Dr Nico Kim

Natalie Morales and Freddy Miyares will also be joining the cast as a paediatric surgeon and a likeable patient, respectively.

What are people saying about Greyâ€™s Anatomy season 20?

Succeeding Krista Vernoff as the series showrunner, Meg Marinis has promised that this season will take things â€œback to basicsâ€ with a surprising reset twist.

More importantly, she told Deadline that fans neednâ€™t worry about Meredith Grey being written out of the show permanently.

â€œHer status is that sheâ€™s always a huge part of the show. I donâ€™t know the answer to your question about why they choose to list it that way. But we have an open-door policy with her. When she is able to be here, we welcome her with open arms. We work with her schedule, she still does the voice-over. She was a huge part of the premiere for me, she and I have a great relationship. Sheâ€™s constantly in my head, her voice. She cares very deeply for the show and even in the episodes that sheâ€™s not in, sheâ€™s interested to know whatâ€™s happening. So, youâ€™ll see her come and go and she will always remain a very important part to the show.â€

When can we watch Greyâ€™s Anatomy season 20?

The season 20 premiere of Greyâ€™s Anatomy will drop via Disney+ on Thursday 28 March, with episodes dropping weekly on Thursdays thereafter.

Will you be tuning in?

item.title: BBC Oneâ€™s Big Gay Wedding is the feel-good TV youâ€™ve been dreaming of
item.description: â€œItâ€™s a statement that we, as gay people, are actually equal to others, worthy of relationships and deserving of the same rights as everyone else,â€ says Tom Allen of BBC Oneâ€™s Big Gay Wedding.Â
item.dc:creator: Kayleigh Dray
item.content:encoded:
If youâ€™ve grown gloomy with the general state of the world (and who can blame you?), then the TV gods are here to remind you that love, actually, is all around. Enter the fray, please, Big Gay Wedding With Tom Allen.

The BBC One special has been commissioned to mark a truly momentous occasion: the 10th anniversary of the first same-sex wedding in the UK.

This means that the 60-minute film will not only see the aforementioned Allen pull out all the stops to arrange a dream wedding for one gay couple it will also explore how LGBTQ+ campaigners won the fight to have equal marriage legalised in the UK in 2003. Along the way, Allen will speak with activists, including Lynn Sutcliffe and Sarah Hews, who made headlines in 1992 for presenting themselves at Westminster Registry Office to be married â€“ as well as Angela Eagle, the MP who helped introduce civil partnerships in 2004.

â€œWhen I was growing up, the idea that gay people could be accepted by society, never mind get married, was as mad as a sack of chihuahuas,â€ says Allen matter-of-factly.

â€œNow, every year, thousands of same-sex couples get married, and thatâ€™s certainly something to celebrate. Now two people can say they love each other in front of their friends and families and have it recognised by all of us in society, and thatâ€™s a wonderful thing.â€

Allen â€“ who will work alongside the likes of Oti Mabuse and Sophie Ellis-Bextor to plan a wedding in just three months â€“ continues: â€œIn the eyes of the law means more than just â€˜a weddingâ€™. Itâ€™s a much more profound symbol â€“ a statement that we, as gay people, are actually equal to others, worthy of relationships and deserving of the same rights as everyone else. In partaking in marriage we are part of the rest of the world and the history of humankind.â€

â€œMaybe that seems like a grand statement but for so much of history, queer people have been made to feel less than everyone else or outside of society,â€ he finishes.Â

In the one-off film for BBC One and iPlayer, Allen will reflect on his own experiences of growing up gay as he considers how far LGBTQ+ rights have advanced.

Best of all? Well, the whole thing will culminate in the wedding of the happy couple, in what the BBC has promised will be a â€œjoyous celebration of love, community and hard-won equalityâ€.

Consider us sold!

Big Gay Wedding With Tom Allen will drop at 9pm, Wednesday 27 March on BBC One.

Images: BBC/Minnow Films

item.title: From Pammy blonde to refined naturals, these will be the big hair colour trends for spring 2024
item.description: Spring is here at last, and what better way to mark the occasion than with a fresh new look?Â
item.dc:creator: Aidan Milan
item.content:encoded:
While most of us canâ€™t really go around changing our hair colour every single season, thereâ€™s something very special about spring when it comes to making us want to try something new.

Maybe itâ€™s the longer days or how tantalisingly close we are to warm weather at this time of year. Maybe itâ€™s something to do with the fact that spring is so closely associated with renewal and rebirth. Whatever it is, it can be a good time for a change.

If youâ€™re in the mood to spring clean your look, so to speak, these are the colour trends that expert stylists believe are going to be big for the new season.

Refined naturals

Jason Crozier, art director at Neville Hair & Beauty, tells Stylist: â€œThe trend towards natural-looking hair colours continues to dominate, but with a refined twist. Think rich brunettes, warm blondes and radiant coppers that are deep, glossy and meticulously tailored to enhance the natural complexion of the wearer. These hues are not just about looking natural; theyâ€™re about perfecting and elevating oneâ€™s inherent beauty with subtle nuances in shade.â€

Luxurious metallics

Crozier says: â€œMetallic shades are making a luxurious comeback, with rose gold, silver blonde and metallic lilac leading the charge. These colours offer a sophisticated, fashion-forward edge. The key to these metallics is a seamless blend, creating a luminous finish that catches the light beautifully.â€Â

Bold statement streaks

â€œIn contrast to the more subtle trends,â€ says Crozier, â€œbold statement streaks in vibrant colours like electric blue, neon pink and Gen Z yellow are emerging as a form of personal expression for the bold at heart. These are not all-over colours but rather strategic accents that add a unique pop to the hair â€“ perfect for clients looking to make a statement without committing to a full head of vivid colour.â€

Dimensional pastels

â€œPastels have evolved into more dimensional, layered hues,â€ says Crozier. â€œPastel balayage and under-lights offer a fresh take on soft colours. These arenâ€™t the pastels of yesteryear; theyâ€™re sophisticated, with depth and movement, designed to look incredible in both natural and artificial light. Think soft lavender, peachy pinksÂ and pale mint greens applied with a technique that ensures they grow out beautifully.â€

Buttery blondes

Hair stylist and colouristÂ Carley BayneÂ tells us: â€œAt the end of summer 2023, I noticed a big change in clients and their need for cool ashy blondes â€“ the ones that reach for the purple shampoo at every given chance. This was the start of the buttery blonde and itâ€™s going to be huge this year. â€˜Butteryâ€™, â€˜creamyâ€™ and â€˜goldenâ€™ are the words you want to use to describe these bright, more flattering tones. Lighter skin tones will suit the buttery tones best whereas darker skin and more lived-in blondes work best with the creamer golden tones.â€

Caramel balayage

Bayne says: â€œThis trend is perfect for clients wanting a more natural result and works great on all skin tones. Soft caramel tones on a lighter base will add movement and shine to the hair. On darker hair colours, think dark chocolate with bright caramel highlights throughout, which makes for a great contrast. This colour works beautifully on curly hair too. Just make sure you ask your stylist for a root shadow to ensure a perfect blend from root to tip.â€

Ranch ribbons

Larry King Hairâ€™s Amy Fish says: â€œWe are really loving the cowgirl scene we are seeing in fashion at the moment and feel it is going to get bigger over the spring. We have created our own hair trends to complement this new vibe, the first of which is â€˜ranch ribbonsâ€™. We love taking hair that little bit lighter in springtime. It gives us all a little bit of lift. This trend involves soft ribbons of colours painted from the ear downwards. Think wearing a cowboy hat and the way sunshine hits the hair from the hat downwards.â€

Western bay

Fish says: â€œA new take on cowboy copper. Itâ€™s more of a subtle brown red shade that can suit most skin tones. This is great for clients that have a darker skin tone and tighter curls.â€

Smoked copper

Fish says: â€œThis oneâ€™s for the braver clients ready to commit to a full impact copper colour. This is not a bright copper; it has an edgier smoked feel. Itâ€™s great for paler skin tones.â€

Pammy blonde

â€œOur take on the new It blonde,â€ says Fish. â€œThink Pamela Anderson in the early 2000s. Not a bleach white blonde, but a softer sunset blonde that can be created with no bleach to keep the hair in that perfect condition.â€

Images: Getty; Larry King Hair

item.title: Always tired? It could be down to having one of these 5 personality types
item.description: Do you struggle to find the energy to get through the day? If you fall into one of these personality types, that might be why, says Karina Antram.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Scott
item.content:encoded:
Constantly exhausted? You shouldnâ€™t be putting up with it. Low energy levels can be caused by a wide range of factors, such as illness (which is why, if youâ€™re constantly tired, itâ€™s vital you talk to a medical professional), stress, diet, and poor-quality sleep. But one cause you probably havenâ€™t considered? Your personality type.

In her book, Fix Your Fatigue, coach and nutritionist Karina Antram notes that certain personality types are prone to feeling more tired, pointing to research (Greenberg, 2002) that found that people with any of these four key characteristics are more prone to fatigue and burnout: hard-working, perfectionist, obsessive-compulsive and overactive. 

â€œType A personality types, such as those who are competitive, highly motivated, organised and ambitious, according to science have a greater risk of fatigue and burnout than Type Bs who are more relaxed, content and less ambitious,â€ Antram tells Stylist. 

She goes on to describe five personality types that are also likely to be more tired, more often. Do any of them resonate?

The supporter

Are you someone who gives, gives, gives, only to find youâ€™ve got no time or energy left to take care of yourself? Thatâ€™s being â€˜the supporterâ€™, and, as youâ€™d expect, results in tiredness.Â

The mood depleter

â€œYou focus on past events, ruminating on what you could have done differently or failed at,â€ Antram explains. â€œAs a result, you struggle to root yourself in the present day.â€

When your brain is so busy thinking about the past and beating itself up, itâ€™s no surprise that youâ€™re exhausted by lunchtime.Â

The futuristic

If the mood depleter is all about the past, the futuristic isÂ â€“ you guessed itÂ â€“ the same pattern, but about the future. You worry so much about what will happen next that you canâ€™t be in the present moment.Â Â

The overthinker

Of this type, Antram says: â€œYou are always in fight or flight mode, which uses up a lot of energy. You often give thoughts far too much time and attention, creating fear or anxiety about what is to come.â€

Sounds tiring, right?

The captive

Empaths, prepare to be @-ed.Â

Of the captive personality type, Antram says: â€œIf your family or friends are going through a tough time, you have a tendency to absorb these emotions. This can eat away at energy.â€

Basically, youâ€™re like a sponge, soaking up other peopleâ€™s negative vibes and mishaps. When youâ€™re carrying not only your own emotions, but everyone elseâ€™s, youâ€™re bound to feel wiped out.Â

Feel like youâ€™re ticking off multiple types? Thatâ€™s normal.Â

â€œWe may naturally fall into one personality type but the likelihood is we may fall across some or all of them,â€ Antram notes. â€œIf we all just fit into one personality type we would do our wonderful personalities a disservice.

â€œWhat this is suggesting is to be mindful of some of the traits you have, as they may cause energy leaks.Â

â€œTake the futuristic. You may be someone who really struggles to be present. You are always planning the next task, meal, event, holiday or project and canâ€™t ever be content with your present reality. This may manifest in constantly moving from one thing to the next and never really appreciating what you have at any given moment.â€

Donâ€™t stress about this too much, though. Having these personality types does not mean you have a life sentence to the always-tired club. Antram emphasises that we can change, improve and tackle any tiredness triggers at the sourceÂ â€“ and understanding where your low energy comes from is the first step.Â

â€œAccording to the research, 8% of us genetically are predisposed to having low energy levels,â€ she tells us. â€œThat said, we know we do have the capability of switching our genes on and off, due to epigenetics. If your tiredness is due to a biochemical reason or perhaps because you have one of these personality types like the futuristic, then I always believe we have the capacity to change.â€

One way to approach this change is by using the ACE technique. This helps you to stop negative thought loops (which are a big part of the personality types above) in their tracks and come back to the present moment. Antram breaks it down ahead.Â

How to use the ACE technique

Antram says: â€œControlling how and what we think might sound impossible, but itâ€™s actually easier than you think. With a little practice, you can learn to notice unhelpful thoughts and stop them from draining your energy. This is particularly helpful if you are struggling with long-term fatigue. To do this, use the ACE acronym.â€

A: acknowledge thoughts and feelings

â€œTry naming the thought process (eg â€˜Thereâ€™s an anxious/worried/frustrated thoughtâ€™) and notice where you feel the emotion in your body.â€

C: connect with your body

â€œGround your feet into the floor, stretch your back, press your hands and fingers together. Bring your focus of attention to your physical being as encapsulating your thoughts and feelings.â€

E: engage with the world around you

â€œNotice four things you can see, four things you can hear and four things you can touch.â€

Fix Your Fatigue: 5 Steps To Regaining Your Energy by Karina Antram is out now.

Main image: Getty; Stylist

item.title: Zone 2 cardio might be the best kind of heart rate training (and it's much easier to do than you think)
item.description: We should all be doing more of this lighter form of exercise, according to experts.Â
item.dc:creator: Chloe Gray
item.content:encoded:
Do you finish every cardio session looking as red as a beetroot and sweating from every pore? While getting your heart rate up close to its max has its benefits, not every session needs to be incredibly intense. Actually, training with a lower heart rate can be good for you.

Thatâ€™s particularly true of â€˜zone twoâ€™ cardio. â€œZone two training is a form of aerobic exercise thatâ€™s loosely defined as 65-70% of someoneâ€™s maximum heart rate,â€ explains Richard Malpass, a personal trainer and founder of â€‹â€‹FACTR gym.Â

â€œGenerally speaking, this will mean exercising with a heart rate of around 120-140 beats per minute. For most people, it will be an easy pace, a bit tougher than a warm-up but maintainable for an extended period of time.â€

What are the benefits of zone two cardio? 

Like any form of exercise, zone two is packed with muscular and cardiovascular benefits. â€œZone two training enhances your endurance and stamina by improving bone density and muscular adaptation while reducing the chance of injury when performed consistently over time,â€ says UK Athletics coach Arj Thiruchelvam.

â€œIt is particularly effective at capillarisation, the process of increasing the number of capillaries that serve a muscle and thus improve your muscular and aerobic endurance by delivering oxygen to that area of the body.â€

For Malpass, the benefits go beyond just the physical changes: â€œIt can be a far more social activity and due to the reduced intensity it can often be less daunting. The barrier to entry for this type of workout is lower, as you are able to spend time having a chat and you wonâ€™t be too fatigued.â€

Yes, itâ€™s good for beginners, but even pros should do zone two training, says Thiruchelvam. â€œItâ€™s often overlooked by runners and cyclists because itâ€™s â€˜not challengingâ€™, but it should be an integral component of their training,â€ he says.

How to do zone two cardio training  

First, you need to pick your workout. You can use any form of cyclical cardio, like running, cycling, rowing or even a brisk walk. Avoid HIIT or weight training as this makes your heart rate go up and down, rather than stay within one zone.

â€œMany people struggle to actually slow down enough to stay in zone two and their heart rate often strays above the desired rate,â€ says Malpass. â€œSo when choosing a method, ensure you pick something that you are proficient at and have some element of control over the pace or intensity.â€

That might mean an indoor treadmill where you can pick the pace, but one of the joys of zone two is that it can be done with friends or without too much struggle. â€œThe best method is the one you enjoy most; if you prefer hiking rather than an indoor bike in the gym, then thatâ€™s absolutely fine,â€ says Malpass.

Thiruchelvam adds: â€œIf you are including zone two cardio as part of your training for an event, itâ€™s best to mimic the activity, like running if you are working towards a half marathon.â€

Ideally, zone two will make up the bulk of your cardio, says Thiruchelvam. â€œVery often it will form around 60-70% of your entire aerobic training. Faster and more intense sessions should only contribute to about 30% of your week,â€ he explains.Â

That might sound like a lot, but it doesnâ€™t necessarily mean you need to swap all of your HIIT sessions for lower-intensity movement. A brisk walk will probably get you in the heart rate zone, which most of us will already be doing daily â€“ a reminder that your daily walk has huge health benefits.

How to measure zone two cardio  

If youâ€™re serious about keeping yourself in the zone, use a tracker. You can either measure your maximum heart rate then work out what 65-70% of it is or simply aim to keep it within the general 120-140bpm range.

If you donâ€™t have a tracker or donâ€™t like using them, they try the â€˜talk testâ€™. â€œIf you can maintain a steady conversation whilst exercising, then youâ€™re probably in zone 2, whereas if your conversation is broken up and it feels unnatural, then you may have strayed into zone 3 or above, which is more intense,â€ says Malpass.

Images: Getty

item.title: Poor gut health might be making you weaker and less fit â€“ try these nutritionist-backed tips for making noticeable improvements
item.description: Struggling to make progress at the gym? It might be time to look at how good your gut health isâ€¦
item.dc:creator: Miranda Larbi
item.content:encoded:
Thereâ€™s nothing worse than spending hours at the gym slogging your guts out, only to feel as though youâ€™re not making much progress. You might be progressively overloading your key moves, getting a decent sleep most nights and eating well but still not see great returns on your investment.Â

The missing keyÂ â€“ the one that just about impacts every part of our physical and mental healthÂ â€“ may be gut health. If youâ€™re someone who struggles with bloating, sluggishness, non-regular loo habits, then itâ€™s time to see if your gut microbiome is actively usurping your efforts to get fitter.Â

5 reasons poor gut health is making you weaker

Lower levels of nutrient absorptionÂ

â€œThe gut plays a vital role in absorption and utilisation of essential nutrients that are needed all around the body for many different functions. This can include energy production and metabolism,â€ explains allplantsâ€™ nutritionist Ally Findlay.Â

We all know that nutrition plays a big part in athletic performance and â€œwith a weakened or unhealthy gut, youâ€™re less able to fully absorb the nutrients in the food you consume, which could have a knock-on effect on your progress and health in general.â€Â

Increased inflammation

Of course, itâ€™s not just that poor gut health can make us weaker; doing too much intense exercise can weaken out guts. According to Michelle den Hollander, nutritionist and hormone expert, lots of intense exercise can cause the body to release hormones that promote the growth of â€œbadâ€ bacteria and other inflammation-promoting substances.Â

â€œIf you are training intensively, you may also experience a â€˜leaky gutâ€™ where the intestinal lining opens up, making room for bad bacteria to leave the intestinal canal and start moving around your body. This compromises the immune system significantly and needs to be treated as soon as possible.â€Â

The key, she says, is to listen to your body as you know your body best. â€œBy ignoring signs like a bloated belly or pain, you can make things worse. So if any of these symptoms happen regularly, reduce your exercise impact or take a day off and if it disappears and does not come back then continue.â€

Risk of constipation

Another factor, when it comes to exercise, is dehydration. If you donâ€™t come up with a plan for taking on fluids on a long run or commit to rehydrating once you finish your work out, you might run into further digestive issues.Â

Findlay explains that the large intestine soaks up the water it has access to, making your digestion slow down â€“ resulting in constipation. If you are experiencing gut related problems when exercising, Findlay says that â€œthere is likely another factor involved and it is worth checking in with your doctor.â€

Increased discomfort

denÂ Hollander warns: â€œBloating and inflammation will definitely get in the way of training and thus hinder you from your fitness goals. Gut health is often underestimated when, in fact, itâ€™s a big factor to consider when you want to getÂ fit.â€Â

If youâ€™re used to feeling bloated during or after a run, you might be tempted to change how and when you fuel. While the timing of when you eat wonâ€™t impact your gut health itself, food can get in the way during training if you leave too little time between a meal and a workout. Choose an easily digestible snack like a banana or bread and nut butter before a workout but give yourself an hour between a meal and movement.

Slower lactic acid clearanceÂ

den Hollander explains that our gut not only helps with digestion, it also plays a role in our metabolism, immune and hormonal system and even our cognitive functions â€“ all of which affect our physical performance.

Â â€œItÂ has also been proven that our gut breaks down lactic acid that is needed to build up muscles, so if your gut health is poor it wonâ€™t be able to work effectively to help your strength and muscles grow.â€

Symptoms of poor gut health

Our guts are always busy. If theyâ€™re not absorbing nutrients to keep us nourished, energised and strong, theyâ€™re supporting the immune system. A â€œhealthyâ€ gut has a rich array of gut microbiota (the millions of microorganisms within your digestive tract) so that it can carry out all of its functions properly. That means having lots of different kinds of bacteria; the more diverse the microbiota, the stronger the gut.

â€¨There are lots of factors that lead to poor gut health, including:

  • High-stress levels (emotional and physical)
  • A diet high in processed and refined foods (especially foods containing lots of additives and preservatives)
  • Too much exposure to antibiotics or other drugs

Given how important our guts are, itâ€™s pretty noticeable when things go wrong. Common symptoms to look out for are bloating and gas, which Findlay says â€œcan signal high levels of bad gut bacteriaâ€.Â

Food intolerances can also be a sign that the gut is not functioning correctly; you may not be able to break down food correctly and that causes reactions in the body. Oh, and because gut bacteria is linked to the immune systems, gut problems can negatively impact immune health too.Â Â

Can exercise actually improve gut health?

Research shows that regular aerobic exercise can actually beneficially change your gut bacteria and microbiome.Â

A 2019 study published in the journal Experimental PhysiologyÂ concluded that those people with higher cardiorespiratory fitness tend to have a more diverse bacterial population in the gut, compared with those with a lower level of cardio fitness.

Another study found that exerciseÂ promotes the growth of bacteriaÂ which produce the fatty acid,Â butyrate. Butyrate is thought to reduce inflammation (reducing the risk of issues like inflammatory bowel disease and insulin resistance), as well as help to heal the gut lining. But you donâ€™t have to do HIIT or sprints to reap the gut benefits. The same paper found that women who do at leastÂ three hours of light exerciseÂ (such as a brisk walk) per week have been found to have increased levels of anti-inflammatory bacteriasÂ compared with more sedentary individuals.Â

Women who do 3 hours of light exercise a week have better gut health

If youâ€™re a runner or cyclist, youâ€™ve got a reason to feel good: researchers have shown runners and cyclistsÂ produce more endocannabinoidsÂ in their blood, which provides some pain relief andÂ improves mood.Â Endocannabinoids are involved in controlling gut inflammation and protecting our gut barrier. Whatâ€™s not yet been established, however, is how short-lived these changes are or whether that boost can lead to long-term changes in the gut microbiome.Â

Given that â€œrunnerâ€™s stomachâ€ is such a thing (ask anyone whoâ€™s trained for a long-distance event and theyâ€™ll tell you that their guts have become incredibly sensitive), however, surely thereâ€™s a limit to how much movement is goodÂ for a gut?

Our digestive systems may be able to handle a lot but ultimately, they arenâ€™t designed to experience the kind of incessant stress that hours of running can create. When we run or engage in lots of high-intensity activity, our blood flow moves away from the digestive system to the cardiovascular system. That then can trigger an inflammatory response in the gut.Â

6 tips for a happier, stronger gut

1. Eat the rainbow

Thereâ€™s no one hero food but a wide range of natural foods will lead to a diverse microbiota. Having a diet of whole foods such as fruits and veg is the best way of nourishing a healthy gut. They are rich in fibre and promote the growth of beneficial gut microbes. 

2. Fill up on fibre

There are two different types of fibre. Most whole foods have both soluble and insoluble fibres. Insoluble fibre â€“ the roughage like stalks, seeds, skins of foods â€“ helps to move things along and keep us regular, which is key for good gut health. Water-soluble fibre binds with water and creates a gel that can feed healthy gut bacteria. It can also help to reduce cholesterol.

3. Prioritise food- based probiotics

Prebiotics are fibrous foods that when digested, ferment in the gut and feed the healthy bacteria, promoting the growth of more healthy gut microbes. Prebiotic rich foods are very simple foods such as onions, garlic, bananas, oats, legumes and whole grains. 

4. Enjoy a side of probiotic

Fermented foods including kimchi, sauerkraut and kombucha are rich in live bacterial cultures which feed the healthy bacteria in the gut. People can often be sensitive to these types of food, so if you are increasing the amount of them in your diet, make sure to do so slowly so the body has time to get used to them.  

4. Calm it down

Too much stress or anxiety (which can also be caused from exercising too intensely!) can cause your digestive system to go into overdrive and your body to go into fight or flight mode. This means that your gut health will decrease, your digestion will be affected and you may suffer from constipation. Try out slow and grounding activities like yin yoga, meditation, reading or walking. 

5. See your GP

If gut issues persist, it is worth trying to find out if you have any food intolerances that could be causing these reactions.

6. Hydrate

Water is a key component of digestion and ensures the proper absorption of nutrients. Water also keeps food moving through the intestines. If you donâ€™t have enough water in your body, water is reabsorbed from the colon often leading to hard stools and constipation. 

Images: Getty

item.title: Chocolate and seed snack recipes that are high in protein and good for your gut
item.description: Put a nutritious twist on your chocolate bars with these seed and nut-based cacao snacks.Â
item.dc:creator: Chloe Gray
item.content:encoded:
With Easter just around the corner, chocolate is on all of our minds. Do we buy our own egg or email a suggestion to our nearest and dearest? Is there any point in buying a specific egg to eat on Easter Sunday when weâ€™ve been having daily 3pm Mini Egg break since February? Chocolate is one of those tricky nutritional areas; we know that for the most part, itâ€™s best enjoyed in moderation and yet some types of chocolate are absolutely brimming with nutrients. 

We know, for example, that dark chocolate with a high cacao percentage is chockfull of magnesium (which is what you actually crave when you suddenly get a pang for Dairy Milk the day before your period). And the dark stuff also tends to contain loads of fiber, antioxidants and gut-loving polyphenols. In fact, Zoeâ€™s Dr Tim Spector has said that dark chocolate has several times more antioxidants than green tea or red wine.

With that in mind, weâ€™ve gathered together three simple chocolate recipes that use added beneficial ingredients like omega 3-rich hemp seeds and a bunch of other natural goodies. 

Chocolate and seed snack bar

Ingredients

6 tbsp Good Hemp hemp seeds

6 tbsp sunflower seeds

300g rolled oats

4 tbsp flax seeds

1 tsp cinnamon

40g chopped hazelnuts

150g vegan butter

2 tsp vanilla extract

25g light muscovado sugar

100g maple syrup

150g agave nectar

200g 70% dark chocolate 

1 tbsp coconut oil (optional)

Salt flakes

Method

  1. Pre-heat the oven to 180Â°C. 
  2. Melt the butter, vanilla extract, sugar, maple syrup and agave nectar in a small pan on low to medium heat.
  3. Add the rest of the ingredients (except the dark chocolate, coconut oil and salt flakes) to a large bowl with the melted mixture. Stir well, making sure the dry ingredients are evenly distributed throughout the mixture.
  4. Transfer your mixture to a lined 9-inch baking tin, ensuring itâ€™s evenly spread throughout. Use a flat spatula to firmly press down the mixture into the corners of the tin.
  5. Bake for 25 minutes until golden brown around the edges. Whilst you wait for the bars to cool, prepare your chocolate layer.
  6. Melt the chocolate and coconut oil (if using) in a microwave or using a bain-marie until fully melted (be careful not to burn it). Then, pour the melted chocolate on top of the bars, using a flat spatula again to ensure the chocolate is spread evenly.
  7. Place into the fridge for 2 hours, and once set, cut into desired shapes and top off with salt flakes. 

Chocolate and seed energy balls

Ingredients

400g pitted dates

5 tbsp Good Hemp hemp seeds

2 tbsp cocoa powder

50g cashews

A pinch of salt

Extras: 50g cashews for rolling

Method

  1. Soak the dates in a bowl of very hot water for 10 minutes to soften.
  2. Add the drained dates to a food processor and process until left with a smooth paste.
  3. Add the rest of your ingredients to the food processor and then blitz very quickly for about 10-15 seconds, until all of the ingredients are just combined. You should be left with a thick dough-like mixture, which you should be able to roll into balls. If the mixture falls apart when rolled, mix in a teaspoon of water.
  4. Roll the mixture into 14-16 equally sized balls, then into the finely chopped cashews or extra hemp seeds for a crunchy coating. 

Cacao, seed and nut protein bars

Serves: 4 

Ingredients

75g medjool dates

30g peanuts

10g cacao powder

10g vegan protein powder

15g Good Hemp milk

Method

  1. Throw everything into a food processor and blend until it forms a ball.
  2. Press into a small lined tin, depending on your desired thickness.
  3. Chill in the fridge for at least two hours before slicing into bars.

Recipes and images courtesy of Good Hemp.Â

item.title: â€œI want kids. My partner doesnâ€™t. What now?â€: 4 relationship therapists share their honest advice
item.description: â€œThereâ€™s a chance that he might change his mind, but I canâ€™t bank on it. Not having children would be painful, but so would breaking up, and Iâ€™m running out of time to decide,â€ writes one reader. Here, a panel of four top therapists respond with their adviceâ€¦
item.dc:creator: Holly Bullock
item.content:encoded:
â€œLiving with resentment might make things complicatedâ€Â

Charlotte Fox Weber is a psychotherapist who works with couples and the author of What We Want.

â€œI feel for you. This issue comes up all the time in therapy, and when one person doesnâ€™t want to have children, itâ€™s usually not a hard no, but a kind of â€˜Iâ€™m not readyâ€™, which can be maddeningly vague. For heterosexual couples it can feel particularly unfair because there are biological limitations for women that just donâ€™t exist as much for men â€“ and certainly donâ€™t exist as much in terms of societal timelines. At the moment, because there are uncertainties about whether his decision is final, no one wants to close the door. And the plot could dawdle unless you move forward and deal with the difficult loss either way. Thereâ€™s no getting away from the grief. The idea that youâ€™ll get away without loss if you just navigate the situation is sadly not true.

â€œIâ€™ve worked with people whoâ€™ve survived and dealt with the loss of not having children because one person doesnâ€™t want to. The grief that comes with this choice in a relationship can be complicated when thereâ€™s resentment. This is going to be hard, but facing the fact that the man youâ€™re in a relationship with cannot offer you a major thing youâ€™re looking for is important. Iâ€™d challenge you on why you want to give your future to someone who is uncompromising. If you really want children and he doesnâ€™t, itâ€™s worth asking yourself why you want to have children with him. You might struggle to make peace with the compromise whatever happens, but donâ€™t pressure yourself to be entirely resolved and sorted out either way. You can make a choice about the relationship for now without feeling like youÂ must then have your revised life plan sorted out.â€

â€œTalking is the only solution: talk about your childhood, your family and what you might lose out onâ€

Susanna Abse, psychotherapist specialising in relationships and author of Tell Me The Truth About Love.

â€œThis situation isnâ€™t uncommon, and it can feel like itâ€™s irresolvable. Unlike deciding where to live, thereâ€™s no middle ground when it comes to having children. Talking is really the only solution to this. Keep talking. Talk about why you want children. Talk about your own experience of children in your life, what it was like to be a child, what you felt about family, whether you thought your parents liked having children, what you feel youâ€™ll lose if you donâ€™t have children. Conversations with your partner around having children should have a quality of open exploration where you can be curious about each otherâ€™s point of view (if it feels a bit â€˜my way or the highwayâ€™ then you might need someone else â€“ like a therapist â€“ to help you).

â€œYour situation goes to show how important it is that couples talk about things like having children early on. Lots of relationships are what we call â€˜slide, donâ€™t decideâ€™, where you slide into a relationship, even a marriage, without ever really having a conversation about what each of you wants out of life. I notice this in a lot of couples who come to see me: suddenly, theyâ€™re 37, havenâ€™t really ever had any real conversations about what they want, and feel like theyâ€™re running out of time to come to an agreement. The good thing is that you do have time to find out what this means to you and your partner. And while the nature of a relationship is often bearing and tolerating differences between you, you also have to be able to feel that together you can foster a shared vision of what life will be.â€Â

â€œThis is a dealbreaker; one of you will always feel like youâ€™ve lostâ€

Michaela Thomas is a couples therapist and author of The Lasting Connection.

â€œThe three-year mark is often when we have conversations about where weâ€™re going and how serious the relationship is, and Iâ€™m very glad youâ€™ve talked about whether you want children or not. Itâ€™s important to be aware that time spent together just waiting to come to a decision is not necessarily time spent enjoying your life together. When couples realise that one of them wants a child or children and the other one doesnâ€™t, itâ€™s whatâ€™s called a dealbreaker â€“ because itâ€™s often impossible to come to a compromise.

â€œLiving in this type of limbo can be really stressful. Youâ€™ve decided different things, and when weâ€™ve come to these types of crossroads, the incompatible life choices, the clashes of our values, the clashes of our wishes for their lives, itâ€™s rare for that to ever work out. One of you will always feel like youâ€™ve lost â€“ thereâ€™s a difference between a compromise and a sacrifice. If one of you makes a sacrifice or feels like a choice was taken away from you, you are more likely to feel resentful towards your partner, and it might create discord in the future. Try to find an unbiased, external person to talk things through with â€“ it sounds like you have a solid relationship that should be strong enough to tolerate these conversations and make a wise decision together, regardless of whether that means staying together or growing apart.â€

â€œWhen you feel time is running out, the pressure makes everything harderâ€

Andrew G Marshall is a marital therapist and host of The Meaningful Life podcast.

â€œThe first thing Iâ€™d say is that the minute you think time is running out, you increase the pressure on both you and your partner. And when youâ€™re making big decisions, pressure is the last thing you need. The thing we tend to do in these kinds of conversations is that when our partners share an issue â€“ for example, they donâ€™t feel ready yet â€“ our initial response is to try to persuade them otherwise. Instead, we should be asking questions. Can you tell me more about that? What would be the signs that you might be ready? What things do you want to achieve in your life before you have children? Trying to find out as much as possible is a good place to start.

â€œYou donâ€™t have to try to diagnose problems, but asking questions like this takes us to a different place, with more exploration and less pressure to make a decision. Similarly, share how your thoughts have evolved over time so he has a clear idea of where youâ€™re coming from. The likelihood is that youâ€™ll probably both be worried about saying what you truly want and believe because of what it might mean for the relationship, but itâ€™s important to express what you both want â€“ and why you feel that way â€“ so that you donâ€™t end up having the same argument 30 times over and can understand each other better.â€

item.title: 5 ways to use ankle weights to boost strength and supercharge your workouts (and why theyâ€™re so effective)
item.description: Looking for an easy way to build strength and boost fitness? Hereâ€™s why the humble ankle weight could be the key.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Geall
item.content:encoded:
We all have those days when we just canâ€™t be bothered. When your mind is preoccupied with your growing to-do list or your energy levels are slumping, working out just isnâ€™t appealing.

Sometimes, though, you have days that are the complete opposite â€“ when the idea of just going through the motions isnâ€™t enough to satisfy the urge to push yourself. On those days, you want an easy way to give yourself a little extra challenge â€“ and thatâ€™s where ankle weights come in.

Ankle weights can be used in a variety of ways, but theyâ€™re especially helpful for making pre-existing activities more challenging, as we found out when we put them to the test on a normal walk.Â

So, whether youâ€™re looking to speed up your progress in the gym or boost your cardiovascular fitness, hereâ€™s why picking up a pair of ankle weights is a good idea. Plus, we look at some of the techniques you can use.Â

Why are ankle weights so good for building overall fitness?Â

As far as fitness equipment goes, ankle weights are small but mighty. Theyâ€™re relatively cheap, easy to use and can make a serious difference to the difficulty of many workouts â€“ especially for beginners who arenâ€™t ready to make the step up to bigger free weights.

â€œAnkle weights can be effective tools for building strength and improving fitness when theyâ€™re used appropriately and in conjunction with a well-rounded exercise programme,â€ explains Ali Malik, a personal trainer and founder of Fit Labs Kensington. â€œThey provide progressive resistance, allowing for gradual overload and muscle adaptation, leading to strength gains and improved muscular endurance.â€

There are, of course, many ways to build muscle, so the resistance ankle weights provide isnâ€™t exactly unique. But what makes them stand out is the way they do so while also providing extra benefits.Â

â€œBy placing an added weight onto the outer parts of our body we are changing our centre of gravity,â€ Gemma Folkard, founder of Shape Pilates, points out. â€œThis means the ankle (or wrist) weights not only increase the work for the limb theyâ€™re attached to, but also the centre of the body â€“ the core.â€

She continues: â€œUsing light weights also means that you can still mobilise the joints while increasing resistance for the surrounding musculature.â€ This means you can pay attention to specific muscles and areas of the body, something that can be hard to do with larger weights.

The accessibility of ankle weights also makes them useful, Folkard adds. â€œYou can throw them on during a pilates class or take them off if your body isnâ€™t asking for more in that moment,â€ she says. That might mean popping on your ankle weights for the moves youâ€™ve mastered but want to improve on, and then slipping them off for the moves youâ€™re a bit shaky on.Â Â

How to use ankle weights to supercharge your workoutÂ

1. Counteract the impact of desk-based work

Sitting at a desk for most of the day can lead to weakened muscles, especially in the hip flexors. But ankle weights are a great tool for undoing some of this effect.

â€œPerforming a leg raise in a seated, standing or lying position can help to strengthen our hip flexors while providing a challenge for our core too,â€ says Natalie Holmes, a personal trainer at Fit And Food PT. â€œDead bugs, bicycle crunch and plank with knee drives â€“ all with weights around the ankle â€“ are great exercises to challenge the core too.â€Â

2. Up your heart rate during cardio sessions

Ankle weights arenâ€™t just great for building strength; theyâ€™re ideal for getting your blood pumping, too. You may not notice the extra weight at first, but the added effort builds up over time.

â€œWearing ankle weights during cardio activities like walking, jogging or aerobic exercises increases intensity,â€ Malik explains. â€œThis helps to improve cardiovascular endurance and adds a challenge to traditional cardio routines.â€

If you donâ€™t fancy a full-on cardio workout, wearing ankle weights as you do some chores around the house can also increase the intensity of the movement and elevate your heart rate a little higher than normal.Â

3. Build muscle across the body

Doing any kind of activity which builds strength while wearing ankle weights will supercharge the workout by adding increased resistance. Strapping them on during a bodyweight routine â€“ such as pilates â€“ can be especially beneficial, Folkard adds.

â€œDoing a pilates side series with weights on your leg will challenge pelvic stability, as the abs have to work hard to hold the pelvis in place,â€ she explains. â€œRaising the leg from the hip also activates the side glute, which is an important stabiliser for functional movement and is often the key to decreasing lower back pain.â€

You can even find dedicated ankle-weight pilates workouts on YouTube that are designed to help you reap the full benefits of your equipment.Â

4. Make your balance and stability training more challenging

Balance and stability training may not be the most exciting area of exercise out there, but itâ€™s incredibly beneficial. Using ankle weights during these workouts will help to boost your progress and improve your bodily awareness, Malik adds.

â€œPerforming balance exercises like standing leg lifts or single-leg squats with ankle weights challenges proprioception and improves balance and stability, while also strengthening the lower body muscles,â€ he says.Â

5. Use them to activate your muscles before a workout

Activating your muscles before you work out â€“ to wake them up and get them working correctly â€“ can make a big difference to your ability to hold correct form and perform well.

Using a pair of ankle weights is a great way to do this, Holmes suggests. â€œWhile ankle weights may not provide enough stimulus to build strength past a certain point for those who are more experienced, they are still a great option for activation prior to a workout.â€

Ankle weights are particularly helpful when activating the glutes, which is important for maintaining strong and stable hips. â€œTo make sure the glutes kick in when theyâ€™re supposed to, you can use ankle weights to do kneeling or standing single-leg kickbacks and abductions,â€ Holmes adds.Â

item.title: Avoid coffee at breakfast and other tips for making your diet super nutritious, according to nutritionists
item.description: Thinking about cutting caffeine before breakfast? Well, nutritionists explain why having a cup of coffee with your breakfast might actually not be a good idea â€“ especially if youâ€™re eating eggs. They share their top tips for making the most of your first meal of the day.
item.dc:creator: Miranda Larbi
item.content:encoded:
While fruit and vegetables are obviously good for us, how we eat them matters. We know, for example, that boiling broccoli into a brown goo is a surefire way to strip it of most of its vitamins. But what about actually making food more nutritious?

â€˜Bioavailabilityâ€™ is a buzzword thatâ€™s become increasingly common. A favourite topic among biohacking enthusiasts and nutritional professionals, increasing the bioavailability of food means making their vitamins and nutrients easier to absorb. While lots of plants are packed with antioxidants, theyâ€™re not always user-friendly. 

Kale is a good example. Itâ€™s packed with vitamin A, K and B5, as well as potassium, copper and manganese. But grab a piece without any preparation and you may find it impossible to digest â€“ which is why we talk of the need to â€˜massageâ€™ the kale. By rubbing ultra-fibrous kale with olive oil, the leaves become easier to chew and digest without the need for cooking.Â

Add a squeeze of lemon juice or some vinegar, and you start to break down the cellulose in kale which again, will reduce the risk of indigestion while keeping all the health benefits intact (and adding a punch of vitamin C into the mix).

The question is: are there any big health benefits to be had from concentrating on increasing bioavailability and if so, what other hacks should we be employing?

â€œWhile eating five portions of fruit and vegetables a day is great, we should always ensure that we are maximising the number of nutrients we can receive from our diet,â€ says James Brady, qualified nutrition coach at Origym Centre of Excellence.Â

Why bother making foods more bioavailable?

â€œAs our body canâ€™t make nutrients itself, we can only obtain them from food and not receiving enough may result in disease and deficiency,â€ Brady explains. That means trying to eat as much locally-sourced fruit and veg raw as possible. If you donâ€™t like raw veg, steaming is a great way of retaining many of the nutrients as you cook. However, if you want to max out the nutrient profile of your food, Brady confirms that â€œbaking or roasting results in a greater loss of nutrients because of the high temperatures required to do thisâ€.

â€œOur food is made up of complex chemical structures, which interact with one other as well as with our gut microbes and our cells,â€ explains Dr Federica Amati, nutritionist and scientist at Zoe.

She says that the most important thing to consider when it comes to nutrition is eating colourful plants at every opportunity as doing so is â€œone of the simplest ways to ensure fibre and polyphenol diversity which are key for good gut health and immune functionâ€.

â€œThis can come from seasonal fruits and vegetables, nuts and seeds or from dozens of herbs and spices that you can add for extra flavour,â€ she says. She suggests adding mixed herbs to scrambled eggs, sticking frozen berries into a pot of overnight oats, adding a handful of mushrooms to a stir fry or blending your own pesto using basil, nuts and extra virgin olive oil (youâ€™ll also need either pecorino or nutritional yeast for that cheesy element).â€

The aim, she says, is to have 30 different plants per week. By opting for a plants-first approach that includes going for dried spices, olive oil, whole grains, nuts and seasonal veggies, youâ€™re going to automatically consume a variety of prebiotic fibre and polyphenols that ensure a healthy, diverse gut microbiome.

9 hacks for boosting the nutrient profile of common foods

Crush garlic to release antioxidants

â€œCrushing and chopping onion and garlic releases an enzyme called alliinase that helps form the nutrient allicin,â€ Brady says. â€œWhen this nutrient is consumed, it may protect us against disease by forming other compounds.â€

While most academic studies look at the impact of taking garlic supplements on health, itâ€™s largely the allicin that is thought to offer health benefits. In fresh garlic, itâ€™s only fleetingly present â€“ just after the clove has been cut or crushed. A 2014 review published in the journal Molecules found that the compound has a variety of health-promoting properties such as lowering cholesterol and blood pressure and has been found to kill antibiotic resistant strains of the MRSA bug as well as cancer cells.Â

Refrigerate vegetables to keep them powerful

Brady says that oxygen, light and heat can all cause nutrient loss in plants. Itâ€™s important therefore to store all vegetables that arenâ€™t of the root variety in the fridge until you need them. Think of it this way: if youâ€™d roast them, theyâ€™re probably better stored somewhere dark and dry and if youâ€™d eat them fresh, they belong in the fridge.Â

Soak grains to build strong bones

Soaking beans and grains reduces the intake of phytic acid. Brady says that doing so can â€œpotentially stop the absorption of calcium, zinc, and magnesiumâ€. Too much phytic acid, he says, can weaken bones, induce stomach cramps and cause headaches.

Cook carrots for healthy organs and skin

â€œCooking carrots improves beta carotene absorption,â€ says Dr Amati. A comparative study, published in the European Journal of Nutrition, looked at the difference in beta carotene availability in cooked, pureed and raw, chopped carrots. Researchers found that significantly more beta-carotene was absorbed from meals containing cooked, pureed carrots than from meals containing the raw stuff.Â Â

Watch what you drink your coffee with

Dr Amati warns against eating eggs alongside caffeine, as doing so apparently impedes micronutrient absorption. But itâ€™s not just eggs that might become less nutritious with your morning latte.

The tannates in coffee also make it harder to benefit from plant-based (non-heme) iron, which you get from soy products, chickpeas and nuts. Caffeine can also boost the amount of calcium you excrete in your urine (which means having less available to strengthen your bones). All of this doesnâ€™t mean that you absolutely need to cut out coffee at breakfast but if youâ€™re already anaemic, vitamin D deficient or looking to simply boost your mineral absorption, it might be worth having your coffee before or after a meal.

Pair your eggs with avocado

Pair fat-soluble vitamins A, D, E, and K with small portions of dietary fats to help your body dissolve and absorb them, Brady advises. That means, for example, having a few slices of avocado with your eggs benedict.

Drizzle lemon juice on spinach to unlock the iron

Pairing vitamin C-rich citrus or peppers with iron-rich plants like lentils, kale and spinach can aid nutrient absorption. A paper in the Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences explains that animal-based iron doesnâ€™t usually need much help with being put to use, but that non-heme iron sources (plants) are aided by the ascorbic acid found in citrus, which it calls a â€œpowerful enhancer of nonheme iron absorptionâ€ which can â€œreverse the inhibiting effect of substances such as tea.â€ 

Go for sourdough over regular bread for more iron

â€œChoose sourdough over regular bread to enhance iron absorption,â€ advises Signe Svanfeldt, nutritionist at Lifesum. Again, itâ€™s all to do with that pesky phytic acid: â€œWhen the (sour) dough is fermented, it breaks down the phytic acid that exists in whole grains, which makes it easier for the body to absorb the iron.â€Â Â

Choose omelettes for a calcium punch

Svanfeldt flags that in order to get a big vitamin D boost (crucial as we move through winter), we might want to pair vitamin D-rich foods like eggs and salmon with calcium like dairy and leafy greens. Thatâ€™s because vitamin D activates calcium absorption. Some milks may be fortified with vitamin D (and calcium if youâ€™re a plant milk drinker) so thatâ€™s a hole in one, but otherwise, omelette or scrambled eggs with milk and spinach is super nutritious.Â
