item.title: The most delicious and beneficial condiments and spreads, according to nutritionists
item.description: Packaged sauces and spreads can get a bad rap, but not all condiments are created equal. We asked nutritionists for their most-loved condiments and spreads to add some zing to our dishes, without compromising on nutrition.Â
item.dc:creator: Anna Bartter
item.content:encoded:
Letâ€™s be honest, pre-prepared foods have been having a hard time lately. You donâ€™t have to search too hard to find information about how harmfulÂ ultra-processed foods can be, and it makes the weekly shop a bit of a minefield.Â

And when you think about healthy food, itâ€™s likely that dips and spreads donâ€™t immediately spring to mind â€“ but they can be a useful and nutritious addition to your larder.Â

While weâ€™d all love to have the time to create delicious and varied dishes every night at home, the reality is that most of us have times when we need to reach for something quick and easyÂ â€“ and thatâ€™s where condiments and spreads can add a dollop of flavour to elevate the simplest of dishes.Â

The good news is that you really donâ€™t have to make all these from scratch to reap the benefits â€“ itâ€™s entirely possible to have quality processed items without compromising on nutritional valueÂ if you know where to look.Â Â

So in the spirit of ease, we asked nutritionists for their favourite must-have condiments and spreads that they always have in their store cupboards to add flavour and interest to their food. Here are nine you can slather, squeeze and spread to your heartâ€™s content.Â

1. Nut butter

It probably wonâ€™t surprise you to learn that the nutritionists were unanimous in their love forÂ nut butters. And while there are options loaded with salt and sugar, itâ€™s really easy to find good quality versions.

â€œI love almond, peanut and cashew butters,â€ says nutritionist GQ Jordan. â€œThey provide a healthy dose of fats and protein supporting heart health, stabilising blood sugar, and supporting muscle and nerve function thanks to their vitamin and mineral content. For a healthier fix, always go for products made from 100% nuts with no added sugar.â€

2. Kimchi

If youâ€™re yet to try this traditional Korean spicy, fermented veggie dish, youâ€™re missing out. Not only does it pack a real punch, flavour-wise, adding depth and sour notes to all kinds of dishes, but itâ€™s great for gut health, too.

â€œA big dollop of kimchi makes an excellent replacement for hot sauce,â€ advises nutritional therapist Alex Allan. â€œIt gives a kick of spice without the sugar. Plus, if you get an unpasteurised version, itâ€™s teeming with good bacteria, making it an excellent choice for gut health, lowering cholesterol and boosting immune tolerance.â€

3. TahiniÂ

Tahini is a real winner, nutritionally speaking. Studies show that the nutrient-dense ground sesame seed paste can help to lower blood pressure (although itâ€™s worth noting that the studies have only been conducted on males), while being an excellent plant-based source of protein.

â€œTahini really lovely nutty flavour to dishes and dips, and can be used to thicken sauces,â€ says registered nutritionist Eva Humphries. â€œHealth-wise, itâ€™s a great source of key minerals including calcium, iron and magnesium.â€

4. Pesto

Not simply a staple for tired parents everywhere, pesto is a rich source of antioxidants and healthy fats which can promote heart health, reduce inflammation and supply the body with essential nutrients.

â€œWhether homemade or store-bought, pesto often has a lineup of wholesome ingredients that offer numerous health benefits,â€ says functional health coach Jodi Montlake.Â

â€œBoth delicious and healthful, pesto is packed full of nutrients. Basil is an excellent source of vitamin K, essential for blood clotting and bone formation, while pine nuts provide a rich source of vitamin E, helping to protect against chronic diseases and boost immunity.

â€œMeanwhile, the extra virgin olive oil and parmesan cheese aid in the absorption of dietary fats, enhancing the bodyâ€™s utilisation of nutrients.â€

5. GuacamoleÂ

â€œFor those of us struggling to get extra veg into our diets, guacamole can come to the rescue,â€ says Allan. â€œThis makes a perfect condiment to spicy dishes like chilli and fajitas, but you can also have it alongside salads. Itâ€™s easy to make, so donâ€™t rely on the additive-laden shop-bought ones.Â

â€œAvocados are a great source of fibre plus theyâ€™re high in folate. Adding onions, garlic, lime juice, fresh coriander, cumin and tomatoes not only adds to the flavour but helps us get to our 20-40 plant foods per week for optimal gut health.â€Â

A real winner.

6. MarmiteÂ Â

Love it or hate it, Marmite has a myriad of nutritional benefits.Â

â€œThis yeast extract, made from leftover brewersâ€™ yeast, has good levels of B vitamins and minerals such as magnesium and calcium,â€ says nutritionist Hannah Hope.Â

â€œB vitamins are great for your energy and protect your nervous system, while the minerals provide other health benefits such as sleep support. Itâ€™s also gluten-free and vegetarian so can appeal to many on special diets, even if you arenâ€™t a marmite fan, and you can add a tablespoon to many dishes (such as chilli) to enhance the flavour and you wonâ€™t taste a thing!â€

7. KetchupÂ

In excellent news for all of us, everyoneâ€™s favourite dip has some surprising health benefits.

â€œWhile ketchup may have gained a less-than-ideal reputation, its primary ingredient (tomato) offers potential health benefits worth considering,â€ agrees Montlake.Â

â€œTomatoes are a nutritional powerhouse. Notably, they contain the carotenoid lycopene, which research suggests possesses anti-inflammatory and antidiabetic properties. Some studies have also linked lycopene to cancer prevention and cognitive support â€“ just be sure to choose a version lower in sugar and salt for optimum health benefits.â€

8. TzatzikiÂ

A Greek yoghurt-based dip, tzatziki offers probiotics for gut health and protein for muscle repair.

â€œKnown for its antibacterial properties and fibre content, garlic supports gut health, clears mucus from the lungs and sinuses, and provides selenium, an essential mineral,â€ says Montlake.Â

9. Harissa

If youâ€™re not familiar with this north African red chilli paste, it offers a subtle yet rich flavour to dishes. If youâ€™re making it yourself, you can make it as fiery or mild as you like. The jarred paste is versatile and lends a tasty kick to shakshuka, veggies or chicken recipes.Â

â€œThe capsaicin in this spicy chilli paste can support your metabolism, helping you burn energy more efficiently,â€ says Allan. â€œThe paste also has anti-inflammatory properties that can reduce pain and swelling.â€

Images: Getty

item.title: Are you addicted to achievement? Hereâ€™s how to tell
item.description: Always looking for the next goal to tick off? You might be addicted to achievement. Expert Dr Mandy Lehto explains how to tellÂ â€“ and how to thrive in spite of it.Â
item.dc:creator: Amy Beecham
item.content:encoded:
Everybody likes reaching their goals. Whether itâ€™s the fanfare that comes from buying a house or the buzz of finally securing that promotion, thereâ€™s nothing more satisfying than fulfilling something youâ€™ve always aimed for. But can there ever be too much of a good thing, where our desire to achieve turns into something closer to addiction? According to Dr Mandy Lehto, an executive coach and the host of Enough, The Podcast, the answer is yes.

â€œItâ€™s entirely possible to become addicted to behaviours, and achievement is a potent drug that is positively reinforced and often celebrated by society,â€ she explains.

Defined as the over-consumption of work (or other goal-focused pursuits) even when it has a negative effect on our own wellbeing or the wellbeing of others, achievement addiction often looks like a compulsive need to tick things off a list, hit goals, gather external accolades and relentlessly produce at the expense of simply being. Sound at all familiar? Youâ€™re far from alone.

As an executive coach, Dr Lehto says that she sees a lot of similarities in the types of people who come to her with achievement addiction. â€œThey are often go-getting Type As who love to win and struggle to relax,â€ she shares.Â â€œPeople who are addicted to achievement are usually very future-focused, constantly moving towards an imagined ideal because the present isnâ€™t really working as they want it to.

â€œItâ€™s a need to have something to strive towards whether thatâ€™s an event, a package from Asos or completing a goal. If you feel afraid of ordinariness, you might be addicted to achievement.â€

However, itâ€™s important to remember that none of us are immune to addiction. â€œWe live in a very â€˜addictogenicâ€™ world that constantly encourages us to chase dopamine through social media validation, endless consumption and 24/7 stimulation,â€ she adds.Â

How to spot the signs of achievement addiction

According to Dr Lehto, one of the signs of achievement addiction is the loss ofÂ boundariesÂ when it comes to work (if thatâ€™s where youâ€™re getting your achievement fix).

â€œYou might find yourself sending emails at 3am or working on holiday â€“ perhaps secretly,â€ she shares. â€œThereâ€™s no â€˜offâ€™ button; all conversations and thoughts revolve around work, but you might get tetchy and defensive if others mention it as an issue. But it really becomes a problem when it starts to have an adverse effect on your mental health, physical health and relationships.â€

Another sign of achievement addiction is that everything becomes about productivity, even hobbies and reading for leisure. Everything you do becomes a lever for optimising yourself and hitting goals â€“ you might find yourself using your â€˜downtimeâ€™ to consume personal development books and train for a marathon.Â

â€œThere is often a sense that even when you do reach the pinnacle of achievement, it still doesnâ€™t feel â€˜enoughâ€™,â€ Dr Lehto explains. â€œAchievement addicts might really be addicted to anticipation and striving. To the hope that this time the reality is going to match the expectation. Then a deep disappointment follows if it doesnâ€™t. Youâ€™re left with the feeling of never being satiated and a compulsive need to look for the next â€˜thingâ€™â€¦ again.â€

How to deal with achievement addiction

To work on achievement addiction, Dr Lehto stresses the importance of recalibrating your relationship with the present. â€œNot everything is supposed to be exceptional and extraordinary. Learning to be here, in the present moment, is the first step,â€ she says. â€œThere is loveliness and joy to be found in everyday moments. The more we can appreciate these and resist the urge to rush towards an imagined pot of gold on the horizon, the more balance and contentment we will experience.â€ Whatâ€™s more, itâ€™s important to remember that if we put all our eggs in the basket of achievement, weâ€™re neglecting other aspects of our lives, such as connection, relationships, rest and wellbeing.Â

Ultimately, we need to create distance from overachieving behaviours. â€œItâ€™s helpful to run little experiments to see how changing certain behaviours over a few weeks makes you feel,â€ Dr Lehto advises. This could mean setting boundaries around work where you leave on time and donâ€™t check emails on your phone after 6pm or before 8am, or spend a month filling your leisure time with hobbies and activities that bring you joy, instead of ones that â€˜improveâ€™ you.

â€œIf youâ€™re addicted to achievement, itâ€™s not really about making money, gaining accolades and gathering praise â€“ it means a deeper need is going unmet,â€ she adds. â€œIn all likelihood that need is connection. Thatâ€™s why support can also be so helpful, whether itâ€™s a support group, a therapist or a coach.â€Â

Images: Getty

item.title: 3 fresh and delicious folate-rich recipes to up your intake (and why itâ€™s so important for all of us)
item.description: Vitamin B9 isnâ€™t just needed during pregnancy, so here are three recipes to help you reach your daily recommended folate consumption.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Geall
item.content:encoded:
Getting plenty of folic acid is vital during pregnancy, which is why the NHS recommends women who are pregnant or trying to conceive take a 400mg folic acid supplement daily. But did you know that folic acid â€“ also known as folate or vitamin B9 â€“ is something all of us should be consuming?

According to a new survey by Discover Great Veg, one in five of us think pregnant women are the only people who need folate, with 75% of us being unaware that folate can be found naturally in food.

Itâ€™s hardly surprising, then, that the latest National Diet and Nutrition Survey report showed that levels of folate (of which folic acid is just one form) in the UK diet are not as high as they should be, with average blood folate concentrations decreasing by 25-28% over the last 11 years across all age groups. Thatâ€™s concerning because vitamin B9 plays a crucial role in red blood cell formation and healthy cell growth and function.Â Â

In fact, a vitamin B9 deficiency has been linked to outcomes ranging from tiredness and fatigue to anaemia and mental health issues including depression and anxiety. And in the long-term, eating a folate-deficient diet has also been linked to cardiovascular issues and even cancer.

So, how can you get more of the stuff? The NHS recommends we get 200mg of folate every day, but there are plenty of ways to bring more vitamin B9 into your diet: for example, dark leafy vegetables such as spinach and kale contain 194ug and 141ug of folate per 100g respectively. Other folate-rich food sources include chickpeas, kidney beans, broccoli and brussels sprouts.

There are, of course, plenty of ways to cook with spinach, kale and other folate-rich food sources, but to get you started, nutritionist Jenny Tschiesche has partnered with Discover Great Veg to create three delicious recipes packed full of folate and other essential nutrients. Check them out below.Â Â

Spinach and kale mini quiches

Serves: 8

Prep time: 10 minutes

Cooking time: 25 minutes

Each portion (two quiches) contains 30% of your daily recommended folate requirement.Â You will need an 8-hole muffin baking tray â€“ each muffin hole should have at least a 125ml capacity.

Ingredients

  • 90g spinach
  • 90g kale
  • 3 tbsp water
  • 6 large eggs
  • 180g fresh pesto
  • Ground black pepper
  • A little olive oil for greasing

Method

  1. Preheat your oven to 190ÂºC. Heat a medium saucepan over medium heat and add the spinach, kale and water. Cook for a few minutes until the leaves have wilted and reduced. Leave to cool. Pop these leaves into your food processor and blend on medium speed.
  2. Meanwhile, beat the eggs with the pesto and pepper then add to the cooled leaves in the food processor before blending on top speed.
  3. Grease the eight holes of your muffin tin with a little oil or use cases to avoid sticking. Fill each of the eight greased muffin holes with equal amounts of the eggy mixture. Put the tray in the oven and cook for 20-25 minutes or until a cocktail stick inserted into the quiches comes out clean.
  4. Serve warm or cold (theyâ€™re ideal for a quick breakfast or lunchtime add-on).

Lemony chicken tray bake with kale and potatoes

Serves: 4

Prep time: 10 minutes

Cooking time: 30 minutes

Each portion contains 40% of your daily recommended folate requirement.Â

Ingredients

  • 1 large leek, sliced
  • 300g miniature/baby potatoes, boiled then halved
  • 4 cloves garlic, peeled and lightly smashed
  • 2 tbsp olive oil, divided into 1â…“ tbsp and â…” tbsp (2 tsp)
  • 8 skin-on, bone-in chicken thighs
  • 1 tsp sweet smoked paprika
  • 2 tsp lemon zest
  • Juice of 1 lemon
  • One small pack of fresh thyme
  • 350g kale

Method

  1. Preheat the oven to 210ÂºC .
  2. Toss the leek slices, potatoes, and garlic in 1â…“ tbsp olive oil in a large bowl. Season to taste.
  3. Spread out on one-two baking trays.
  4. Add the chicken thighs to the same bowl and toss with the paprika, lemon zest and lemon juice. Season to taste.
  5. Place the coated chicken portion on top of the vegetables, each with a sprig of thyme on top.
  6. Bake for 15 minutes. Meanwhile, toss the kale in the remaining â…” tbsp olive oil. Stir to coat each piece well then add to the baking tray/s giving everything a good stir in the process.
  7. Bake for a further 15 minutes, stirring once. Check that the chicken juices run clear and if you have a meat thermometer that the internal temperature at the thickest part is at least 74C.

Kale pasta

Serves: 4

Prep time: 10 minutes

Cooking time: 10 minutes

Each portion contains 30% of your daily recommended folate requirement. This recipe is easily veganisedÂ â€“ simply swap the parmesan and cream cheese for vegan alternatives.

Ingredients

  • 500g pasta
  • 1 tbsp olive oil
  • 280g kale
  • 3 cloves of garlic, chopped
  • 3 tbsp water
  • 90g grated parmesan
  • 240ml vegetable stock
  • 180g cream cheeseÂ

Method

  1. Cook the pasta according to packet instructions.
  2. Meanwhile, in a medium saucepan heat the oil over a medium heat. Add the kale and garlic and fry for about 1-2 minutes, until the leaves start to wilt a little then add the water and keep stirring for a further couple of minutes.
  3. Transfer the kale and garlic to a food processor and blend for a few minutes then add the grated parmesan, vegetable stock and cream cheese. Blend at full speed until you have a bright green and creamy texture.Â
  4. Stir this in to your cooked pasta then warm through gently before serving.

item.title: â€œI had my fine hair cut into a blunt bob and it feels like itâ€™s doubled in thicknessâ€
item.description: I had the same hair style for 25 years, but when I finally got my hair cut into a blunt bob, I let go of all of my hair insecurities and halved my morning routine too.
item.dc:creator: Kitty McGee
item.content:encoded:
Since a particularly savage haircut in my first year of secondary school (my first experience of layers and above-the-shoulders-length hair), I have exercised extreme caution at the hairdressers. Iâ€™ve asked for nothing more than a trauma-free trim for over 25 years and have existed with a basic, easy, midi-length haircut that hasnâ€™t changed and has suited me just fine.Â

With the meteoric rise of the bob, however, I started seeing inspiration everywhereÂ â€“ from Gigi Hadidâ€™s new beachy bob to Sydney Sweeneyâ€™s Hollywood bobÂ â€“ and started to question just how fond I really was of my thin, lacklustre hairstyle that even my hairdresser has been politely suggesting that I should update.

Some of my absolute favourite bobs includeÂ Kelly Rutherfordâ€™s sleek, preppy bob; Laura Jacksonâ€™s undoneÂ midi bob; Zendayaâ€™s elegant French bob; Alexis Foremanâ€™s cool, blunt shoulder-length bob; Ambika Modâ€™s collarbone bob and Ayo Edebiriâ€™s versatile chin-length bob.

So, I decided to make the leap, book an appointment and get the haircut. I chose a hairdresser I respect (and who also cuts Laura Jacksonâ€™s hair) at a brilliant salon â€“ I wanted their advice and to feel confident that I could trust in the process.Â Formerly Luke Hershesonâ€™s assistant, Jordan G at Hershesons Fitzrovia has over 15 years of experience cutting and styling hair in London, LA, San Francisco and New York â€“ heâ€™s well known as the guy that gets you cool-girl hair.

With my inspirations spanning such a vast range of lengths and hair types, I thought it best not to bring photos or references, and instead to ask lots of questions and agree on a length I feel comfortable with after the consultation.Â

Jordan goes reasonably easy on me but also stands firm about the length. He explains: â€œWith any haircut, but especially with bobs, the length sets the tone. You can be the coolest chick in the world but if youâ€™ve got a dead-length haircut it just projects the wrong look, so Iâ€™ve got this rule: youâ€™ve got great zones and no-go zones and hair touching the shoulder is a no-go zone. You just end up with this weather girl flick thing. It doesnâ€™t look good.â€

He urges me to go for a shorter length than I was imagining, adding that â€œbobs look great with a clear gap between your hair and your shoulders. If you arenâ€™t going as short as that you should go for a collarbone bob.â€

While Iâ€™m processing his advice he adds something that puts me at ease: â€œAs most peopleâ€™s hair is thicker closer to the root than the ends, cutting a bob will make your hair look way more dense. You have lots of hair, but individually itâ€™s fine, so I would never put layers in your hair.â€

I decide to go above the shoulder. In terms of styling, Jordan keeps it simple: he uses some Kerastase mousse to â€œmake it feel a bit thickerâ€ and then finishes with some Hershesons Almost Everything Cream, advising me to â€œapply it with your fingers acting like a comb to separate the hair up a bitâ€.

And thatâ€™s it. I now have a bob and it looks much better than I thought it would and nothing at all like the humbling haircut of 2001. It looks much thicker now, too. When I wash it, I leave it to dry naturally and it dries great â€“ the hallmark of a great cut â€“ and it cuts my morning routine in half too.Â

This wonder product was created to streamline hair routines. Use it as a daily hydrator on wet hair through the mid-lengths and ends to kill frizz and protect the hair before heat styling. Or use it to address dryness in between washes.

item.title: These are the annoying co-worker behaviours that make us avoid going into the office
item.description: Some of us are finding our colleagues so deeply irritating that weâ€™re avoiding going into the office entirely. But which behaviours annoy us the most?Â
item.dc:creator: Ellen Scott
item.content:encoded:
Have you ever noticed that you get so much less work done when youâ€™re in the office? The distracting background chatter, the constant interruptions, the pointless meetings where you canâ€™t get away with typing as you listenâ€¦ it all seems to conspire against you and stops you from getting on with your tasks. And thatâ€™s if you have predominantly well-behaved, well-intentioned colleagues who donâ€™t send your blood pressure rocketing. Once you add in irritating co-workers, the office becomes the last place you want to be.Â

No wonder, then, that research from Indeed has found that more than a fifth of workers are deciding to work from home just to avoid sitting among their irritating co-workers. Indeed points to reduced tolerance for workplace irritation, noting that the pandemic and all that time working from home has made us more sensitive to the tribulations of being in the office.Â

But which behaviours drive us most around the bend? Is it the loud typing, the messy desks, the microwaved fish?Â

The research found that itâ€™s actually gossiping (annoying 34% of workers surveyed) that tops our irritation list, followed by swearing, flirting and oversharing. One in five of those surveyed reported hearing too much information from their co-workers every day they were in the office.Â

Of course, your colleagues can make you prickle even when youâ€™re not in the same physical space. Remote working faux pas mentioned in the survey included not responding to messages and emails, vaping or smoking on video calls and forgetting to mute or unmute. More than one in 10 employees experience the pain of digital micromanaging, with their co-workers monitoring when theyâ€™re online.Â

And regardless of being in the office, colleagues taking credit for our work irks 46% of us, while being talked over was listed as a major annoyance for 36% of those surveyed.Â

Danny Stacy, UK head of talent intelligence at Indeed, said: â€œOur data underlines the changing workplace behaviours over time, influenced by the huge shift caused by the pandemic with more employees working remotely. There are always going to be colleagues with habits that frustrate us and some behaviours that are simply unacceptable in the workplace. But whatâ€™s important for employers is to create moments of connection for employees, no matter where theyâ€™re based, to maintain relationships and ensure environments where everyone can do their best work.

â€œAccording to our research, over half (55%) of workers say being able to behave informally (within reason) at work makes them enjoy their job more, while 41% agree that experiencing behaviour thatâ€™s informal but still professional in an interview would make them more likely to take a job. For employers, itâ€™s about striking that balance between employees feeling like they can be themselves, while maintaining a professional working environment where all colleagues feel comfortable.â€

Images: Adobe; Getty

item.title: Jacqueline Wilson is back with a new sequel to Girls In Love, nearly 30 years later
item.description: Jacqueline Wilson is publishing a new adult sequel, Think Again, in her Girls series â€“ nearly 30 years after the first one was released.Â Hereâ€™s everything we know so far.
item.dc:creator: Shahed Ezaydi
item.content:encoded:
Itâ€™s an especially great day for millennial women, and thatâ€™s not just because the sun is shining and iced coffee season is nearly here. One of the UKâ€™s most iconic writers, Jacqueline Wilson, has revealed that sheâ€™s publishing a new sequel, Think Again, in her Girls series â€“ nearly 30 years after the first one was released back in 1997.

For many, Wilson represented a typical 00s childhood with Tracy Beaker on TV after school, battered copies of Lola Rose passed around friendship groups and sleepovers hosted with the sole aim of dissecting the teenage messiness of Ellie, Nadine and Magda.

The original four-part Girls series started in 1997 with Girls In Love, followed by Girls Under Pressure (1998), Girls Out Late (1999) and Girls In Tears (2002). Now, over 20 years after the fourth book, we get to dive back into the world of Ellie, Nadine and Magda as they navigate the chaos of adulthood.

The synopsis reads: â€œBeing an adult isnâ€™t quite what Ellie Allard dreamed it would be when she was 14 years old. Though sheâ€™s got her beautiful daughter Lottie, lifelong best friends Magda and Nadine and her trusty cat Stella, her love life is non-existent and she feels like sheâ€™s been living on auto-pilot, just grateful to be able to afford the rent on her pokey little flat.

But this year, on her birthday, the universe seems to decide itâ€™s time for all that to change â€“ whether Ellie wants it to or not. As she navigates new, exciting and often choppy waters, sheâ€™s about to discover that life will never stop surprising you â€“ if only you let it.â€

On the adult sequel, Wilson said: â€œIâ€™ve always wondered whatever happened to Ellie, Magda and Nadine, the teenagers in my Girls series. Iâ€™ve decided to find out what theyâ€™re up to nowadays. Itâ€™s been great fun writing for adults for a change. I think everyone reading Think Again will be surprised.â€

Itâ€™s safe to say weâ€™ll be counting down the days until we can grab a copy of Think Again to find out what happened to the girls all these years later, aged 40.

Think Again will be published by Transworld in September 2024, while the Girls novels will be reissued by their original publisher, Penguin Random House.

item.title: That Christmas: Richard Curtis is adapting his childrenâ€™s book into a Netflix festive adventure
item.description: Love Actuallyâ€™s Richard Curtis is teaming up with Netflix to bring his childrenâ€™s book to the screen. Hereâ€™s everything we know so far about That Christmas.Â
item.dc:creator: Shahed Ezaydi
item.content:encoded:
We know what youâ€™re thinking: Why on earth are we talking about Christmas films when weâ€™re gripping onto the first days of spring? Well, when Richard Curtis is behind a new festive film, we canâ€™t help but get excited. And thatâ€™s not to mention the stellar cast involved in the upcoming Netflix film.

What is the plot of That Christmas?

That Christmas follows a â€œseries of entwined tales about family and friends, love and loneliness, and Santa Claus making a big mistake â€“ not to mention an enormous number of turkeysâ€, reads the synopsis.

Who will star in That Christmas?

The film stars Brian Cox as Santa, Fiona Shaw as Ms Trapper, Jodie Whittaker as Mrs Williams and Bill Nighy as Bill â€“ all residents of a charming seaside town where things turn upside down one Christmas.
